column2: HARTFORD, Oct. 1 -- A new Connecticut Penal Code permitting homosexual relations between consenting adults went into effect today.

The United States and Britain agreed yesterday that the Soviet Union and its allies must clarify the aims and dimensions of their proposed European security conference before the West could join them in preparations for it.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- A British soldier was killed and a civilian sniper shot and captured in separate incidents in Belfast today.
The New York State Banking Board denied yesterday an application by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation to acquire a small bank upstate.

The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, the nation's largest food chain, made its poorest showing in sales and earnings in more than 10 years, according to results issued yesterday for the second fiscal quarter and half-year periods ended with August.
Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, yesterday reorganized the top management of the New York City Transit Authority, which runs the city's subways and buses.

The great marble hall of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street will become a mart for bibliophiles and film buffs on Thursday with an auction and over-the-counter sale of duplicate library possessions.

In the obituary on J. D. Bernal [Sept. 19] you quote Home Secretary Sir John Anderson, who appointed the scientist to the Home Office at the outset of World War II, as telling critics of the appointment that he would employ Bernal "even if he was as red as the flames of hell."

RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Tropical depression Ginger, no longer a hurricane but still posing a flood threat in the already hard hit North Carolina farm belt, continued its slow movement northwestward today, dumping heavy rains along the way.

Enrique Pinder of Colon, Panama, showed his superior ring savvy last night by scoring a unanimous 12-round decision over Davey Vasquez, the local Puerto Rican favorite. A bipartisan crowd of 4,012 attended the bout in the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Wesley Hall, M.D., the president of the American Medical Association, visited Britain last summer and went away distressed. He observed the National Health Service in a small mining town in Scotland and found it so bad that Americans would never tolerate it.

During his eleven months in office, President Allende has often promised fair compensation for American and other foreign enterprises nationalized in Chile. He has now defaulted on that pledge with a bizarre bookkeeping maneuver that effectively nullifies the possibility of any payment for three nationalized copper mines previously owned by two American firms.

MADRID, Oct. 1 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco observed the 35th anniversary of his rule today, saying to an applauding crowd that he would remain in power "as long as God gives me life and a clear mind." He also ordered a wide amnesty.
Chancellor Harvey Scribner has properly called attention to the fact that school reform must mean more than the redistribution of powers; the heart of the matter is the reshaping of institutions.

The Soviet Government once insisted piously that only "treacherous imperialist states" engaged in international espionage. A dramatic public turnabout in Moscow's approach took place roughly a decade ago when a group of Soviet master spies -- men such as Victor Sorge, Col. Rudolf Abel and Kim Philby -- were acclaimed heroes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Two scientists and four atomic clocks will fly around the world next week to test one of the crucial implications of Einstein's theory of relativity.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Oct. 1 (AP) -- A Marin County grand jury indicted Stephen M. Bingham, a missing lawyer, and six San Quentin convicts on murder charges today in the Aug. 21 violence at the prison in which George Jackson and five others died.

The M.P. at West Point's Washington Gate can expect a restful tour on a mild, fall Sunday afternoon. He'll wave on a handful of sightseers or occasionally snap to and salute an officer leaving that northwest portal for a round on the nearby West Point Golf Course.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 -- The San Francisco Giants, who who almost didn't make it, regrouped today for the National League playoff, which opens in Candlestick Park tomorrow with Gaylord Perry pitching against Steve Blass of the Pittsburgh Pirates.
ATLANTA, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- The arms race in tiny Hancock County, where opposing governmental groups brought weapons by the dozens, has come to an end, Gov. Jimmy Carter said tonight.

Pat Greathouse, vice president of the United Auto Workers of America, entered into the lion's den yesterday and told an American Management Association seminar that "profits had kept pace with wages."

Your Sept. 24 editorial on the Medina acquittal is quite incredible in view of the evidence adduced at the trial. Not only was there no evidence demonstrating Captain Medina's participation in the slaughter but there was none indicating any awareness of the incident.

Alarmed by the decline in attendance and handle at Belmont Park that will result in a reduction of $7,000 a day in purses, representatives of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association met yesterday for two hours with Howard J. Samuels, the president of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The Home Office disclosed today that a Soviet woman official had defected to Britain at the same time as a K.G.B. agent, Oleg Lyalin.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- Monsanto Company, the leading producer of synthetic turf, denounced today demands made recently by the National Football League Players Association calling for a moratorium on further installations of artificial turf pending completion of a study on incidence of injuries by Dr. James G. Garrick of Seattle.

In jazz, familiarity is less likely to breed contempt than to set up a challenge. What, for example, can you do with such spavined warhorses of the traditional jazz repertory as "Muskrat Ramble," "Fidgety Feet," "At the Jazz Band Ball" or "Bill Bailey"?

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1 -- Bobby Fischer, the 28-year-old Brooklyn school dropout who won the United States chess championship eight times in the last 13 years, had decided it was time to take the world title away from Boris Spassky of Moscow.

Five black Roman Catholics -- a priest, a nun and three lay persons -- plan to leave tonight for Rome to discuss with Pope Paul VI what they describe as the "disastrously poor" relationship of the church in this country to black Americans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board withheld approval late yesterday of a number of proposed international air cargo rate increases that appeared to contravene President Nixon's order freezing rates and prices.

Thousands on the Long Island Railroad were delayed up to an hour during the evening rush yesterday when a train from Great Neck to Pennsylvania Station stalled midway through a tunnel underneath the East River.

The stock market, putting together two consecutive gains, moved higher yesterday. In the forefront of the advance were some automotive, retailing, drug-chain, mobile-home and recreational-vehicle issues.

There has been such a mountain of material written about the Middle East problem by writers with varying measures of expertise that one hesitates to add to the verbiage. Yet Norman Dacey's letter of Sept. 25 contained a degree of speciosity that cannot go unchallenged.

BACOLOD, the Philippines, Sept. 20 -- The exploitation of labor on the rich sugar plantations of Occidental Province on Negros Island has in recent years become a principal issue for social reformers and is widely regarded as a glaring example of social injustice.

FREDERICTON, New Brunswick, Oct. 1 (Canadian Press) -- An injunction against management officials of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., was dissolved today by the appeals division of the New Brunswick Supreme Court. The injunction, obtained by dissident shareholders following a stormy I.O.S annual meeting June 30 in Toronto, prevented management from performing any but routine company duties.

Lorin Maazel, the 41-year-old American conductor, has been appointed music director of the Cleveland Orchestra despite an informal poll taken by the orchestra players in August in which, by a vote of 77 to 2, they indicated that he was not their choice.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--The Senate voted today to direct the Nixon Administration to borrow sufficient funds to feed the nation's needy school children.

MIAMI, W. Va. -- Most articles written about the coal miners are by people with little or no knowledge of truth in regard to these men and their families. The miners have no way to fight back and defend themselves.

Chief of Detectives Albert A. Seedman said yesterday that he had no firm leads on the man who raped a 31-year-old woman Thursday night in a 12th-floor penthouse while another woman fell to her death trying to escape.

FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 1 -- The court-martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson was conducted out of the presence of the jury today to allow for argument and testimony on a defense motion to prevent a key witness from appearing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Daily index numbers and spot{ primary market commodity{ prices Sept. 21, 1971, to Sept. 28, 1971:

ATHENS, Oct. 1 -- The American Embassy confirmed tonght that United States Ambassador Henry J. Tasca met yesterday in Paris with Constantine Caramanlis, the right-wing critic of the Athens regime whom many Greeks believe will figure strongly in any civilian government succeeding the country's present military one.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 2 (AP)--Despite a nightlong pounding by allied aircraft, North Vietnamese troops were reported to have launched another ground attack early today against a South Vietnamese artillery base in eastern Cambodia.
If difference of opinion makes a good race, then today's $115,000 Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park already has passed its first test.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- The Egyptian mission to the United Nations said today that the proposal for talks on the Middle East made here yesterday by the Israeli Foreign Minister, Abba Eban, contained "the same Israeli obstructions to all United Nations efforts to end Israeli hostilities and to bring a just and durable peace to the Middle East."

SAN DIEGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Nine young crewmen of the Constellation stayed inside a Roman Catholic church as the attack carrier sailed on schedule today for Vietnam. They were then declared deserters by the Navy.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 1 -- More than 1,000 students from Nassau Community College boycotted classes today and marched to the State Supreme Court Building here to protest the continued impasse in contract negotiations between the county and the teachers.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 1 -- Mrs. Sara Allison, a member of the Gu-ya-no-ga chapter of the New York State Daughters of the American Revolution, places her hands on the piano and the music begins.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- President Pompidou had the nine members of a Chinese delegation in for lunch at the Elysee Palace today and took the occasion to criticize the presidential election in South Vietnam Sunday and the American bombing of North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- The Administration asked the Supreme Court today to permit it to wiretap without a court order whenever the President or the Attorney General determined it is required by the national security.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 1 -- The Government has invited President Idi Amin of Uganda to visit here.
A ten-age couple, characterized by the police as a prostitute and her pimp working West Side streets, were arrested yesterday in the slaying of a former official of a New Jersey military academy.

The appointment of three new top executives of the Municipal Loan Program as a further step in its reorganization in the wake of disclosures of alleged corruption and misuse of funds was announced yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 1 -- Bruce Goldsmith's Schroeder from Chicago won the fifth race in the world Soling Class championship today on Long Island Sound and moved into second place in the series standing.

Police Commissioner Murphy deserves and, indeed, needs the support of all residents of New York in his efforts to restore discipline and maximum integrity at all levels of the police force. His efforts are not merely correct administrative and managerial steps.

The ninth annual New York Film Festival opened at Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater last night with the presentation of a Russian film and the prospect of capacity audiences for all 18 performances.
The American Stock Exchange finished the week on an uptick yesterday as the list advanced in the heaviest trading n more than three weeks.
TOKYO, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- Japan appears worried that she might be placed in an embarrassing position by Secretary Connally's call for free floating of currencies.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art opened five new permanent galleries for American painting and sculpture yesterday, and the most succinct comment would be "Hooray?" The American collection has been visible only occasionally and spottily for a long, long time, and the new installation is not only a reminder but also in many ways a revelation of its richness.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J. -- Richard Mozdiak of the Internal Revenue Service telephoned me recently and offered me a last chance to pay three telephone tax bills from last year. No, I said, I won't pay -- not while the Government uses my money for its illegal, immoral, inhumane and purposeless war in Indochina.
DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Domestic auto production dropped by 3,000 units this week even though five plants are scheduled for overtime tomorrow.

Neighborhood polling places throughout the state open today for the final day of registration for the November election for potential voters in the 18-to-20 year age group and for others who have moved or did not vote in the last two elections and thus lost their permanent registration.
The bodies of two inmates of the Attica Correction Facility were buried yesterday beneath an oak tree in simple ceremonies at a Staten Island cemetery.

In other years a virtually complete shutdown of the country's deep-sea ports and its soft-coal mines would have brought swift White House moves for national emergency injunctions under the Taft-Hartley Act. But President Nixon, despite his recent shift to economic activism, is hoping that he will be spared the necessity for such back-to-work orders by quick settlements of the strikes now paralyzing the waterfronts and the mines.
ROME, Oct. 1 -- Roman Catholic bishops today began talks on the crisis in the Roman Catholic priesthood.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway and its more than 90 per cent controlled subsidiary, the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, reported yesterday that consolidated system earnings had plummeted in the September quarter to $2-million, or 21 cents a share, from $12-million, or $1.39 a share, in the corresponding quarter last year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Nationwide extension of a New York-based securities depository could reduce physical movement of stock certificates by 75 yer cent, Congress was told today.

A former official of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines testified yesterday that the bus company had paid $300,000 to Roy M. Cohn to enable him to repay money he had borrowed from the company's top officials.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- New construction spending rose $2.4-billion in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $108.3-billion after a $400-million increase in July, according to preliminary Commerce Department estimates today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 2 -- South Vietnamese riot policemen made a tear-gas attack last night on a Buddhist rally of about 300 people who were protesting tomorrow's uncontested presidential election.

For more than two decades, the chief trouble shooter for three Secretaries General of the United Nations has been Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, an American activist-scholar with an extraordinary flair for diplomatic conciliation and an untiring commitment to peace and justice.
Ron Johnson will probably start for the New York Giants against the St. Louis Cardinals tomorrow, as part of a "new look" offense on which the Giants will rely.
DANTE, Va., Oct. 1 -- They squatted in the bright sunlight, joking and whittling and waiting for their last shift of coal mining for perhaps a month or two.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today that, starting in January, Medicare recipients would have to pay the first $68 of their hospital bill instead of $60 as at present.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- The Commerce Department announced today a 1/4 per cent reduction in interest rates on Federal-development loans effective today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie of Illinois announced today that his office had helped to set up a trading venture between Negro businessmen in this state and African businessmen in Ghana and Nigeria that should have "a dollar value of nearly $50-million over the next two years in business contracts." Mr. Ogilvie spoke at a breakfast meeting at Chicago's Amphitheater attended by nearly 1,000 black and white purchasing agents.

The current revival of what, for want of a better name, must be called realism among a great many painters of the younger generation in New York -- and indeed, a great many painters outside New York -- is a subject guaranteed to send entrenched partisans of the modern movement into paroxysms of complaint, criticism md paranoia.
It is always somewhat painful for a defender to discover in the post-mortem that he has missed an inspired play that would have defeated the contract.
DETROIT, Oct. 1 -- Neal Kizer, after getting up at 5 A.M. for most of his 35 years at the Cadillac assembly plant here, slept until 7 today, the first day of his retirement.

OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Eisaku Sato said today that he will not negotiate an agreement with the United States Government for control of Japanese textile exports unless the Japanese textile industry consents to it.
BONN, Oct. 1 -- West and East Germany today resumed their negotiations on implementing the Big Four agreement on West Berlin, and after a four-and-a-half-hour session both sides reported progress.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 1 -- President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union arrived for a brief visit in India this afternoon. His visit is another public demonstration of the closer ties that the two countries have been promoting since they signed a friendship and cooperation treaty in August.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The normally gentlemanly Senate got into one of its rare squabbles last night. Before it was over, the majority leader and his assistant had incurred the displeasure of the liberals, Southern conservatives found themselves openly fighting with their Northern colleagues, and Hubert H. Humphrey had reasserted his old role as a leader in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)--The Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, Dr. Jesse L. Steinfeld, reiterated today the Government's advice to housewives to buy detergents that are not required to carry a warning label. In most cases, he said, these will be phosphate detergents.

ATTICA, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- The committee set up by Governor Rockefeller to oversee conditions at the Attica Correctional Facility called today for the withdrawal of a state police captain from the state's investigation of last month's rebellion.
At the age of 17 I had a habit. I was addicted to heroin. I began using heroin shortly after my 17th birthday at the insistence of a friend who had long been going that route himself.
TOKYO, Oct. 1 -- The Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan said today that Japan's balance of international payments reached a record surplus of $3.3-billion in August.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 -- The crowd of about a thousand pushed its way into the old French opera house across the street from the United States Embassy in what seemed at first to be a gathering of political figures to mark the end of the presidential election campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Four truck drivers told a Congressional panel today that from 75 per cent to perhaps as many as 90 per cent of all truck drivers use pep pills and amphetamines at least occasionally to stay awake during long hauls.

The help-wanted advertising index leveled off in August, The Conference Board reported yesterday. At 85 per cent of the 1967 base, the index remained unchanged from the July figure, but was four points below its level of August, 1970.
Federal employes from the New York and New Jersey area marched down Broadway and held a two-hour rally at Manhattan Center yesterday to protest President Nixon's freeze of their wages.

One winter day in 1964, William H. Tehan was driving through the Catskills when he rounded a curve and skidded on a sheet of ice into the opposite lane. In a fraction of a second his car hit another car head-on and he hurtled through the windshield.

An editorial in this week's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association urges that a large number of qualified American applicants be accepted into American medical schools to reduce a growing tendency of rejected applicants to seek their training abroad.
The new issue market, in which shares of companies are traded publicly for the first time, turned in a good performance this week although the number of stocks going public declined.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Autumn in the Finger Lakes district is heralded not only by the fall colors that emblazon the rolling countryside, but also by the shattering roar of Grand Prix racing cars.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 -- The Soviet reaction to the British expulsion of 90 officials from Britain and the ban on the return of 15 others intensified today as the Government newspaper Izvestia published a purported interview with H.A.R. (Kim) Philby, the former British intelligence agent, charging that London was seeking to disrupt the relaxation of tension in Europe.

The Appellate Division reversed yesterday a ruling handed down on Tuesday by State Supreme Court Justice Paul A. Fino that had postponed examinations to qualify residents of Model Cities areas for the fire, police and housing patrol forces here.
Dean Witter Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, announced yesterday that Lawrence B. Morris Jr. had resigned as president and said the firm had no immediate plans to replace him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- A California company specializing in pollution control received patents this week for a smog-free automobile. Richard D. Smith, president, and Dale A. Furlong, chief engineer of the Combustion Power Company, Menlo Park, were granted Patents 3,608,529 and 3,608,660. The HyOx engine, which has been built but not yet road.tested, is designed to burn pure hydrogen or gasoline as fuel, with the injection of pure liquid oxygen.

Classics, as everybody knows, constitute the big fashion news for fall for both men and women. So when Ohrbach's presented its international collection of men's clothes yesterday in a show that is a modest version of its women's import-copy gala, it made sure it included clas sic British tweeds, classic cowboy denims, classic Army fatigues and classic Chinese proletariat suits.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1 -- Vida Blue, one of baseball's most electrifying personalities this season, was as gloomy as the weather today as he and the rest of the Oakland Athletics prepared for their American League playoff opener with Baltimore tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Ever since she met him more than 40 years ago at a Sunday afternoon neighborhood ballgame, the biggest fan of Mayor Richard J. Daley has been his wife, Eleanor -- known to close friends as "Sis."

It is the aim of the New York Philharmonic to shed light on Franz Liszt this season by reviving a series of long-neglected works. Thursday night's concert was dedicated in its entirety to Liszt's "The Legend of St. Elizabeth," and already the Philharmonic is accomplishing its aim.

A Roman Catholic priest yesterday said the "right to shelter" should outweigh any "right to private property," and a builder in northern New Jersey told how zoning regulations were used to keep him from constructing low or moderate-cost apartments on a piece of property he owns.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The tomato, that solanaceous perennial beloved of salad makers, will come under the scrutiny of consumers next Monday as to size, quality and nutritional value.

Judge John M. Canella of the United States Southern District Court in New York yesterday asked attorneys for trustees of Beck Industries, Inc., in reorganization, to submit their recommendations for selling the company assets by next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- About 80,000 miners walked out of their pits and strip mines today, effectively shutting down the nation's soft-coal industry. The strike spread across the coal fields after negotiators for the United Mine Workers and the Bituminous Coal Operators Association failed to reach an agreement at midnight last night, when the old national contract expired.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., Oct. 2 (UPI) -- John Atkins spent three weeks in jail, lost his job and faced possible imprisonment after being accused of selling heroin.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 2 (UPI) -- Larry Russell passed for a touchdown and ran for a 2-point conversion in the second half to lift Wake Forest to a 18-14 victory over Maryland today. The Deacons trailed at half-time, 14-0.

SAIGON -- For President Nguyen Van Thieu, the sole candidate in today's Presidential election, it was a fairly easy campaign. He remained close to the Presidential Palace, made four television speeches and one trip to the countryside, tended to the nation's problems and watched his favorite television programs on the American military network -- boxing, wrestling, football and "Mission Impossible."

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 2 (UPI) -- Jerry Tagge passed for two touchdowns and ran for two more in a 42-6 victory for the No. 1-ranked Nebraska Cornhuskers over Utah State today.
KENT, Ohio (UPI) -- Reggie Shoemake kicked a 36-yard field goal with 1 minute 19 seconds left today to give Iowa State a 17-14 victory over a Kent State team today that picked off four passes.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Paul Mellon's diminutive champion colt, Mill Reef, will go off the odds-on, favorite tomorrow in the 50th running of the $471,000 Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe, the world's richest thoroughbred race.

OXFORD, Ohio, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- Bob Hitchens ran for three of his teams nine touchdowns today as Miami routed Marshall, 66-6, for its fourth victory. The losers were held to a minus 21 yards in rushing.

Farrell Jr. of Darien, Conn., demonstrated that characteristic today when he was named best of 1,817 dogs at the 49th annual show of the Westbury Kennel Association.

The tour guide to a Middle East peace settlement which Israeli Foreign Minister Abba Eban mapped out for the United Nations General Assembly last week was an excursion into familiar byways. When stalled peace talks are desperately in need of new directions, Mr. Eban charted five "roads to peace." All have been tried before; all have failed so far to bring any measurable progress toward Mideast stability.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 -- First-half razzle-dazzle and second-half cliff-hanging brought the New York Giants a gratifying 21-20 upset victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today, while a crowd of 49.571 booed the home team lustily.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- Paul Mellon's 3-year-old bay colt, Mill Reef, blazed home free today to win the 50th Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe by three lengths from Mrs. Alec Head's filly, Pistol Packer, in record time at Longchamp.
Americans of Polish descent marched, strolled, skipped, cartwheeled, polkaed, cycled and rode up Fifth Avenue yesterday in the city's 35th annual celebration of Pulaski Day.

Continuing losses in the container shipping business of Seatrain Lines, Inc., coupled with a sharp downturn in spot bulk charter rates in the latter half of the fiscal year ended June 30, resulted in a loss of $143,000, the report disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- More than 180 Soviet citizens, many of them diplomats and trade officials expelled on spying charges, left Britain by ship today for Leningrad.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The American fertility rate, adjusted for seasonal variations, declined in July to the lowest monthly rate since the late nineteen-thirties.
Homer D. Babbidge Jr., who was the youngest state university president in the country when he became head of the University of Connecticut in 1962, has told his trustees he is resigning.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Israeli Government has appointed a Druse leader, Sheik Jaber Muadi, as Deputy Minister of Communications, making him one of two Arabs to have achieved deputy ministerial status in Israel.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Robert Deindorfer, a New York writer, was here with his family last summer in Lower Slaughter, a Cotswold village. His four-year-old son, Scott, became seriously ill and spent three nights in a hospital, having numerous tests and intravenous feeding.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI) -- Rod Laver of Australia subdued his fellow countryman, Ken Rosewall, in three sets today to win the $50,000 Redwood Bank international tennis tournament and take home the $10,000 first prize.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 3 -- Bobby Unser, the older of the rival driving brothers from Albuquerque, N. M., won the $93,050 Marlboro 300-mile national championship race in record time under a yellow flag over the mile-and-a-half Trenton Speedway course today, but the flag didn't bother him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- United States public schools "amount to an establishment of religion" in violation of the First Amendment, Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle said today.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 3 -- The Eurobond market has started the fourth quarter with the new-issue total for 1971 already equal to that of all of 1970, with the dollar on its way back as a financing vehicle and with a solid rally gaining ground on the secondary market.

SEATTLE, Oct. 3 -- An international panel of doctors said here yesterday that their limited experience had shown that automated procedures in medical practice -- to get pertinent facts from patients and to do many laboratory tests -- could help physicians work more efficiently.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 -- Eugene J. McCarthy, private citizen and professor of poetry, came to California last week, making speeches, talking politics, and looking more and more like a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Last week as the world's finance ministers debated the future of gold as a backing for currency, the beleaguered United States gold mining industry sat forlornly in the wings, hoping in vain for some action that would result in a sharp increase in the price of gold.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday the appointment of two women -- the first in the foundation's 20-year history -- to its 16- member board of trustees.
An off-duty city detective was shot and critically wounded by two gunmen early yesterday morning after he was apparently lured to a Harlem parking lot by a young woman, the police said.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that a station would be built at 96th Street for the new Second Avenue subway system.
The Police Department reported yesterday that 137,155 new voters had registered for the November election during the three-da local voter-registration period that ended Saturday night.

The Rangers and Boston Bruins, who have been seeing a lot of each other lately, meet tonight at Madison Square Garden in a tune-up for the National Hockey League season.

The widespread expectation in the financial community that interest rates are headed lower, at least in the immediate future, has led to renewed speculation that a reduction in the prime rate may be imminent.

Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's second-largest food chain, realized a 12.4 per cent increase in earnings for the 12 weeks ended Sept. 11 and a gain of 12 per cent for the 36-week period. WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally suggested today that more steps needed to be taken in the tax field -- as well as the areas of monetary policy and trade -- if all nations were to have "a fair opportunity" to participate in "the betterment of the world economy."

ATHENS, Oct. 4 -- Greece's military - backed Government, vexed by the American Ambassador's contacts with its political opponents, warned tonight that it proposed to curb the activities of foreign diplomats and deny them access to former politicians.

Ken Dyer of the Cincinnati Bengals is in St. Mary's Hospital at Green Bay, Wis., with a severe Contusion of the spinal cord at the neck. In layman's language, that means a broken neck. "There is no danger to his life," said Dr. Hiro Nishioka yesterday, "but I doubt he'll play foot ball again."

Called "Everyman and roach," this has been written by Geraldine Fitzgerald and Brother Jonathan, O.S.F., with music by John Orlando. It was full of good intentions, but its achievements seemed to be more in the realm of sociology than art.

Y., Oct. 5 -A little course knowledge is useful in golf, said Gene Borek after he shot a 67 today to lead the first round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Sunningdale Country Club. Rainer Barzel won his campaign for the chairmanship of West Germany's biggest party in the cut and thrust of parliamentary debate. " Look Me Up," the musical revue playing in the Plaza 9 Music Hall of the Plaza Hotel, is a compilation of songs from "the years of sophisticated innocence" -meaning the 1920's. Actually, the songs are more '20ish than strictly 20's, reaching back to the teens and forward to the thirties.

But expand the question: "I wonder what happened to that Black Actor . . .?" Change the word "Black" to suit your upbringing, you know: Negro, Colored, Nigra, Nigger, etc., et al, and then you, by definition, impart a totally different solution.

NORTH LOUNGE BAR, U.N. Headquarters -- The cozy, cliquish bar of The United Nations north delegates' lounge is considered by connoisseurs to be "the best bar in the world." One wit has named it the Seventh Committee of the General Assembly. It is a setting in which many a calculated indiscretion has been transmitted into the ready ears of the correspondents who professionally frequent the area. It is an honored tradition of the house.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 -- An 85-yard touchdown drive that consumed almost eight minutes of the fourth quarter assured the Cleveland Browns today of a victory, by 27-17, over the Pittsburgh Steelers before 83,391.

Now another South American country with a deeply-rooted democratic tradition, tiny Uruguay, may be on its way down the same road.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that defeat by the voters of his $2.5-billion transportation bond issue would mean that New York City would have to raise the transit fare to 45 cents or impose new local taxes of more than $200-million to keep the fare at 30 cents.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 12 -- A draw in 20 moves was the result tonight of the fourth game of the match between the United States chess ace, Bobby Fischer, and a former world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, in the Teatro San Martin here.
Transit policemen arrested five youths they said were armed with a pistol, a spear and chains in a subway station yesterday near Charles Evans Hughes High School.
The Air Force grounded yesterday all of its 47 C-5A cargo planes, the largest aircraft in the world.
New York City has survived another summer without a major power crisis. This may have the effect of lulling us into a false sense of security.

Liquidation, short selling and stop-loss orders sent silver futures prices down charply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here. The result was that prices hit new life-of-contract and four-year lows.

CAMBRIDGE, England -- Along Sidgwick Avenue, the cars crammed with luggage line up each morning at the entrance of Newnham College. The young women step nervously onto the graveled courtyard and walk into the school.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12 -- The maternal death rate in New York City has been cut by more than half since the liberalization of the state's abortion law 15 months ago, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The rate of drug dependency among servicemen in Vietnam "seems to have reached a plateau" at 5.1 per cent, Dr. Jerome K. Jaffe, the President's director of antidrug programs, said today.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the nation's largest investment concern, reported yesterday that its earnings in this year's third quarter rose 16 per cent on a 35 per cent increase in gross revenues.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The debate over Government regulation of private pensions was rekindled here today as employers testified that their companies could not afford the reforms called for by a bill pending before the Senate Subcommittee on Labor.
The American Stock Exchange managed to make a slight advance yesterday in stepped-up trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -The Supreme Court rejected today a challenge to the constitutionality of the Nixon Administration's Philadelphia Plan, which requires building contractors on federally financed jobs to meet certain percentage goals in employing nonwhite workers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Some noted students of the securities markets outlined today the steps they believe should be taken -- many of them radical steps -- to enable the securities markets of the future to handle both individuals' orders and large blocks of stock more efficiently and fairly.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 -Steve Blass pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates back from the brink today by stopping the Baltimore Orioles on three hits, 5-1, for Pittsburgh's first victory of the 68th World Series.
The Transit Authority has a new hit on its hands: a bus route from the midtown Port Authority bus terminal to Rockefeller Center and the East Side.
Having tied one game and won another in admirable style on the road in the first weekend of play, the Rangers open their home season tonight against the surprisingly defused Boston Bruins.

The ruling by a three-judge Federal court in Philadelphia that the State of Pennsylvania must provide free public education to all retarded children constitutes a historic step in an area that has suffered from public and professional neglect. Similar court tests will inevitably be instituted elsewhere unless school systems across the country move toward voluntary compliance with what will surely become the universal legal requirement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -Organized labor pledged its support today for President Nixon's program to fight inflation after the current 90-day wage-price freeze expires.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a Securities and Exchange Commission ruling that abolished customer-directed commission-splitting among brokers trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -Philadelphia's one-two punch -Archie Clark and Hal Greer -produced 57 points tonight to lead the 76ers to a 114-100 victory over the Chicago Bulls in their National Basketball Association season opener.
The International Business Machines Corporation showed a small profit in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, the giant computer manufacturer reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court today dismissed a bid to overturn the controversial "Baby Lenore" case brought by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino of Brooklyn and Florida.

Many bridge-players are devotees of other intellectual games such as chess, backgammon, Scrabble and go, but club facilities are seldom provided for more than one of these activities. Perhaps this is because one tends to become dominant, and drives out the minority interests.

Digging in congealed sand in the floor of a Pyrenees cave, French paleontologists have found bony remains of a face that looked on the world some 200,000 years ago. It is like no face previously known.
SHIRAZ, Iran, Oct. 12 -- The Shah of Iran borrowed a palace tonight for the first party of the Persian Empire's 2,500th anniversary celebration.

A real-estate developer who in 1968 started quietly buying up the block bounded by Second and Third Avenues and 52d and 53d Streets says that the bitter opposition from much of the neighborhood will not stop his plans to build luxury apartment towers and townhouses.
The International Business Machines Corporation showed a small profit in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, the giant computer manufacturer reported yesterday.

SHIRAZ, Iran, Oct. 12 -- The Shah of Iran borrowed a palace tonight for the first party of the Persian Empire's 2,500th anniversary celebration.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 12 -- The Israeli Government tonight voted to go along with the search for an agreement with Egypt to open the blocked Suez Canal for international shipping but rejected points advanced by Secretary of State William P. Rogers as a basis for an agreement.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 12 -- Miss Eleonora Nazar Anchorena of Buenos Aires was married here this afternoon to V. Peter Mortensen, a landowner in Argentina and former vice president of the International Basic Economy Corporation (IBEC) in Buenos Aires.

Thirty-six Democratic legislators yesterday urged Federal price-freeze authorities to prohibit the city from putting into effect a long-planned system of computer-determined rent increases designed to encourage better maintenance of rent-controlled housing.
The Knicks began their 26th season in the National Basketball Association last night with one of their worst games.
BOSTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Four associates of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg have been subpoenaed to testify before a Federal grand jury in Boston tomorrow and Thursday on the leaking of the Pentagon papers.

In the long, staid history of the New York football Giants, there has never been a year so filled with zany occurrences as this one, and Monday night's 20-13 loss in Dallas fit the weird pattern perfectly.
Stock prices made only a token advance yesterday, despite the apparent removal of a stumbling block to the economic recovery.

Robert Ardrey [Op-Ed Sept. 27, 28] claims that most animal species have genetic mechanisms that limit the size of their populations and cites man and lemmings as the major exceptions to this rule. He predicts that man, like the lemming, will soon have to resort to "such painful expedients as suicide and dropping dead."

" The Headhunters," a new play by Henry Denker, starring George Grizzard in the role of a Russian playwright who has been released from a prison camp, will be produced on Broadway by Lester Goldsmith in January.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Supreme Court laid to rest today any lingering thoughts that it might declare the Vietnam war unconstitutional.

Councilman Robert I. Postel charged yesterday that a "major borrower" from the city's Municipal Loan Program had obtained approval of loans after having pressure brought to bear by an aide to Mayor Lindsay.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Gerardo Catena, who was sent to prison 19 months ago for refusing to cooperate in a New Jersey crime investigation, must remain there even though his contempt conviction has been upset, the Supreme Court ruled today by 5 to 1. Justice William O. Douglas was the dissenter.

MOSCOW -- It is with deep feeling that I address you tonight for I stand here not only as a musician but as a Russian Jew, as one whose parents were born in this land, for which they both retain a deep attachment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, urged tonight that the United States explore re-establishing diplomatic relations with Cuba. He blamed the Nixon Administration for allowing United States relationships with Latin America to decline.
Jack Musick expressed satisfaction with Cornell's fine defensive efforts in beating a strong Princeton team on the slippery Poly-Turf of Schoellkopf Field last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 --President Nixon said today he would announce next week his selections to fill the two vacancies on the Supreme Court, and he did not rule out the possibility that one of the nominees would be a woman.

The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to order a halt to the state's interrogation of prisoners at the Attica Correctional Facility. Justice William O. Douglas dissented in a 6-to-1 decision.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation realized a 50.9 per cent increase in third-quarter profit and a 24.1 per cent rise in the first nine months of 1971, setting records for the periods along with sales, Donald C. Burnham, chairman, reported yesterday from Pittsburgh headquarters.
ATHENS, Oct. 12 -- The Government today published a law applying to local and foreign journalists working here that carries penalties ranging from light fines to a lifelong ouster from journalism.

George Meany, the stocky, blunt president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. detailed a few weeks ago labor's conditions for cooperating with President Nixon's Phase Two economic controls. He said that the federation would go along with an autonomous wage board but would not buy any "camouflaged" plan that attempted to use labor and management as window - dressing while the real power of decision remained in the Justice Department or the Cost of Living Council.

Memorial services for Jean Crez, a 24-year-old exchange student from France, were held yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital, where he died last week from injuries sustained during a mugging in July. Services also were held in Ecully, a small town near Lyons, France, where he was born.
The crowd chanted, "Defense, Defense," but what the Knicks needed more last night against the Detroit Pistons was offense.

The corporate carnage wreaked by the RCA Corporation's two-decade-long attempt to become a major factor in the computer business made itself apparent on the company's balance sheet yesterday. Robert W. Sarnoff, company chairman, announced a $231.1-million loss for the third quarter of 1971 and a loss of $187.8-million for the first nine months of the year.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 -- Fred J. Borch, board chairman of the General Electric Company, said today that the United States should seek an agreement with major trading nations that would put an end to all import surtaxes and export subsidies.
A 96-1 shot named Sea Step threw the Offtrack Betting Corporation into momentary panic yesterday by completing a $2,049.60 daily double at Belmont Park.
The sun shone bright over Shea Stadium yesterday as Joe Namath engaged in his first workout in two months, but the immediate prospects of the undermanned Jets were bleak.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- President Nixon said today that the United States will move against Japan and other textile-exporting nations if no agreement is reached or significant progress made by Friday toward limiting exports.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12 -- Further research by scientists at Johns Hopkins University has supported earlier findings that women who take oral contraceptives have a greater risk of developing blood clots than women who do not take the pill.
A driver who suffered severe burns in an explosion of his 1967 Mustang was awarded $400,000 yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

The United States Court of Appeals here yesterday reversed a lower court decision that would have required the Occidental Petroleum Company to give up $23.5-million of profits and interest allegedly obtained in violation of the Securities Exchange Act.

The appointment of Bryan T. Rollins, a 33-year-old urban affairs consultant and former newspaper reporter, as executive editor of The New York Amsterdam News was announced yesterday by Clarence B. Jones, editor and publisher of the Harlem-based weeklyn newspaper. He succeeds Jesse Walker, who is retiring after 15 years with the paper.
The Federal Reserve System disclosed yesterday that it drew a record $3.6-billion on short-term, international credit lines in the first eight months of this year.
One of the Bruins' forgotten men, Ed Johnston a goalie, helped bring his club back to the heights they're accustomed to as the opportunistic Bostonians walloped the Rangers, 6-1, last night.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 13 -- Clinking their beer glasses in a farewell toast, South Korean and North Korean negotiators smilingly agreed to try again next Wednesday after failing today to set a date for the opening of full-scale talks on the humanitarian problems left by the war that ended 18 years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird expressed concern today over what he said was a continuing Soviet build-up of land-based and sea-based missiles. This build-up, already "far outdistancing" the estimates he offered Congress seven months ago.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -"Well," said Brooks Robinson, "it's now two out of three, right?"
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) Two Nebraska newspaper executives said today that Vice President Agnew has sometimes been right in his attacks on the press.

The effort of Representative Paul G. Rogers to win Congressional approval for a sensible approach to cancer research has apparently produced panic among the proponents of a rival measure that was passed by the Senate. Such panic is the only explanation for the high-powered advertising campaign launched by the American Cancer Society in support of the Senate measure.

The Federal Trade Commission announced yesterday that the Ez Painter Corporation of Milwaukee had agreed to an F.T.C. antitrust order to sell off certain of its paintbrush and roller operations. Ez Painter has agreed to divest itself within a year of the corporate name and certain trade accounts of the American Brush Corporation, which makes rollers used for the application of paints.

Nicholas J. Capozzoli, who delivers the mail on West 85th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, says that about 25 people on the block are now getting unemployment checks. He says that they are nearly all young and unmarired, and that this baffles him.

What kind of cook would you expect a pop singer in her 20's to be? Especially if she stands tall, has a big tough voice and was recently to her dismay labeled by one rock writer as the prototypal new woman, "a Tanganyikan distance runner?"
Prince Rahim, an 8-pound son and heir, was born to Aga Khan IV, the Harvard graduate who is spiritual leader of 15 million Ismaili Moslems in Asia and Africa, and his wife, the Begum Aga Khan.
The chairman of the City Council committee charged with watching the progress of capital construction projects said yesterday that school construction was "proceeding with the rapidity of a snail."

The freeze -- President Nixon's price freeze, that is -- has hit the city's ice skating rinks, prompting the Parks Department to roll back its new rates for adults at general skating sessions.

The temporary 5 per cent increase in Consolidated Edison's electricity rates for commercial and residential customers, granted June 15, is one of five cases under investigation for possible rollback under President Nixon's wage, price and rent freeze program.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13--Bruce Kison and Milt May, the 21-year-old heroes of Pittsburgh's victory over Baltimore in the World Series tonight, were born 5 1/2 months apart in 1950. Now they will be married 7 1/2 weeks apart in 1971.

The Eastman Kodak Company's sales and earnings were the highest in its history in the 12 weeks and 36 weeks periods ended Sept. 5, according to a report yesterday from its Rochester, N.Y., headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- A Federal Transportation Department official disclosed today that Long Island Sound had been rejected as a possible site for a proposed floating jetport.
Julian Clarence Levi, a Columbia College graduate of the class of '96, bequeathed $5-million to the university, Dr. William McGill, president, announced yesterday.

Dusan Makavejev's new Yugoslav film, "WR -- Mysteries of the Organism," is an occasionally comic and brilliant collage movie that leaves me cold, yet filled with a certain admiration for its adventuresomeness, even when that adventuresomeness appears to be the result of Makavejev and his editor's making do, as best they can, with the material at hand.
A Staten Island landmark dating from 1871, the former village hall in the community of New Brighton, was purchased at a city auction by a community group yesterday for its headquarters.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- The head of B'nai B'rith called tonight for rebuilding "the shattered relationship" between the black and the Jewish communities and reviving the "liberal coalition" that succeeded the civil rights campaigns of a decade ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A House committee voted today to guarantee an estimated 1.4 million maids and other domestic workers a minimum wage of at least $1.80 an hour next January and $2 an hour a year later.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- British exports were at a new high last month and September merchandise trade was in substantial surplus for the sixth straight month, the Department of Trade and Industry reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers sharply reproved Chile today for what he termed a "serious departure from accepted standards of international law."

The brief (but probably funfilled) relationship between Alberto-Culver and Norman, Craig Kummel has come to an end by "mutual agreement."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- With the China debate scheduled to open on Monday, the United States is applying the full weight of its diplomacy and prestige in scores of foreign capitals for its policy of dual Chinese representation in the United Nations.
A 68-year-old Orthodox rabbi and three of his relatives were indicted in the Bronx yesterday on charges that they took money for cabalastic faith-healing rituals that never took place.

BONN, Oct. 13 -- West Germany's central bank decided today to lower its discount rate to 4 1/2 per cent from 5 per cent. To take effect tomorrow, the action is aimed chiefly at easing the mounting pressure on exporting industries.

AURORA, Colo., Oct. 13 (AP) -- S. Sgt. John C. Sexton Jr., who walked to freedom Friday near the Cambodia-South Vietnam border after having been a prisoner of war for two years, was reunited with his parents today.

YONKERS, Oct. 13 -- The campaign headquarters of Mayor Alfred Del Bello was riddled by gunfire late last night or early this morning, the police reported. No one was in the one-story building at 310 Yonkers Avenue, when the shooting occurred sometime after 9 P.M., when the office was closed.

The police arrested two men yesterday they said had bilked credit card companies, department stores and airlines of more than $2-million by using stolen traveler's checks, fake credit cards and bad checks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Republicans are inviting alternatives to President Nixon's revenue-sharing plan, now locked in committee, thus keeping alive the possibility of some help this year for hard-pressed local governments.

College football upstate has been as crisp and attractive as one of those wonderful autumn days in the Finger Lakes region. Colgate, Rochester, Ithaca, Union and St. Lawrence have sparkling teams and individuals like Cornell's Ed Marinaro and Ithaca's quarterback, Doug Campbell, brighten the scene. .

Before practice Weeb Ewbank walked up to Bob Davis.

Mike Curtis and the rest of the Baltimore Colts will come jogging into Yankee Stadium on Sunday to play the Giants. They were here three years ago and won, 26-0, putting Fran Tarkenton out of the game in the fourth quarter because of frustration rather than injury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The constitutional amendment prohibiting sex discrimination that sailed through the House yesterday will not be considered by the Senate until sometime next year.

MIAMI, Oct. 13 -- The Federal Aviation Administrator, John H. Shaffer, said today that his agency would issue an order soon requiring airlines to install noise-suppression devices on all their 1,100 two- and three-engine jets.
Roy M. Cohn won the dismissal of a conspiracy charge against him yesterday as his trial neared an end in Federal Court here.

A protest by parents against removal of the principal forced the closing yesterday of Junior High School 263 in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 13 (AP) -- A waitress and a soap salesman were millionaire winners today in the second double-drawing of the state lottery.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians, coming off their second worst season in history, said tonight that the interim manager, Johnny Lipon, would not be rehired. The club lost 102 games and finished last in the American League East.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -The Federal Government today authorized hazard pay for teachers in schools in slum areas.
The executive council of the United Church of Christ rejected yesterday any weakening of the fairness doctrine of the Federal Communications Commission.

Total output in the American economy, propelled by a massive increase in Government and investment spending, will more than double in the decade of the seventies to more than $2,000-billion, Chase Econometric Associates predicted yesterday.
Ten months ago Massachusetts became the first state to enact a no-fault auto insurance law, and already it is talking of reducing insurance rates next year.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- In the first night game in the 68-year history of the World Series, the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4-3, this evening and dead locked the Series at two games apiece.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- President Nixon's announcement of his forthcoming visit to Moscow was hailed in East Germany today as a move that "foils the plans of Peking's leaders to use their latest flirtation with Washington for the establishment of anti-Soviet bloc."

BASIN HARBOR, Vt., Oct. 13 -- Volkswagen, the largest seller of foreign cars in the United States, announced today a 6.8 per cent price increase for most of its 1972 models, giving Detroit a price edge in its battle with the import.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (Reuters) -- The House Ways and Means Committee today approved legislation to allow United States sudsidiaries operating abroad to apply foreign tax credits against their United States tax liability on income derived from mining and mineral operations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Efforts to get representatives of the United Nations stationed along the tense border between East Pakistan and India remained deadlocked today, despite three months of intensive private negotiations within and outside the world organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -The General Motors Corporation, responding to the Federal Trade Commission's demand for documentation of advertising claims, has listed an automatic choke and body by Fisher among the Chevrolet Chevelle's "109 advantages."

The Victor Comptometer Corporation announced yesterday the election of A. C. Buehler Jr. as chairman. He succeeds his late father, A. C. Buehler. In another executive change, Alvin F. May, in addition to his current duties as president and chief operating officer, will assume the duties formerly held by Mr. Bakewell.

The Collins Aikman Corporation has developed and is selling a new line of fire-resistant fabrics for commercial and industrial uses, the company announced yesterday.
