SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Utah Stm's broke open a close game early in the fourth quarter . tonight and opened the 1971-72 AmeriCan Basketball Association season: with' a 135-121 victory over theJ Denver Rockets. [ Utah was led by Glen combs,] a guard, who scored 36 points,]

The fate of 70 apartment tenants at 101 West 55th Street hangs on a decision, expected within a few days, that may also mark a shift in city policy toward the demolition of housing in Manhattan to make way for office buildings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- An Administration spokesman rejected today Senator James L. Buckley's proposal that Congress cut back United States financing of the United Nations if Nationalist China is expelled from the international organization.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 13 -- A British soldier was wounded by sniper fire from across the border today as troops began blowing up secondary roads between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.

SAN ANTONIO, oct. 13 (AP) -- The Soviet Union won the individual and team world modem pentathlon titles today. Hungary the defending champion, took second place in both categories as the United States team finished third.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- Not concerned with World Series activities but hoping they would be again in the future, the top field management of the New York Mets engaged in some frank discussions today. Bob Scheffing, general manager, and Gil Hodges, field manager, made the following observations:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Communications Workers of America has asked the Federal Communications Commission to force radio and television broadcasters to accept advertisements from unions during labor disputes if they also air company ads.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music will become an independent cultural institution operated by a private nonprofit body, the St. Felix Street Corporation, instead of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, the 113-year-old academy's parent organization since 1936.

Critics and advocates of a proposed 400-home development project in the town of Rockland, N. Y., will, have an opportunity to air their views at a public hearing set for next Thursday at 11 A.M. at the Fire Hall in Livingston Manor.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -President Nixon acted today to strengthen the Administration's program to aid businesses operated by members of minority groups.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct., 13 -Mayor Lindsay yielded the microphone to hecklers last night before a turbulent audience of 2,300 Cornell University students who focused their questions on conditions in the city's prisons.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A small band of enemy demolition men slipped into an allied base eight miles northeast of Saigon early yesterday, blew up two helicopters and heavily damaged three others.
Two Jewish members of the City Planning Commission denounced yesterday a rabbi's written charge that introduction of a public housing development would destroy a Jewish neighborhood.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Senators from New York and New Jersey urged a Senate subcommittee today to approve a compact between the two states to prevent airport thefts.

Five printing concerns have banded together to form what is believed to be the first industrial condominium in the United States to acquire an 11story building at 535 West 45th Street with the help of state and Federal agencies.

Religious opinion continued to be divided sharply yesterday over the merits of the rock opera "Jesus Christ Superstar," but the secondnight audience at the Mark Hellinger Theater appeared unconcerned about the theological constroversy and gave the cast a standing ovation at its conclusion.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Democratic Congressional delegation from New York had lunch today -- together.
Thousands of tenants in rent-stabilized apartments will receive refunds from landlords who unilaterally extended two-year leases by one year and raised rents by up to 10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, charged today that the United States Postal Service was about to grant the International Business Machines Corporation a "massive anticompetitive boondoggle" in contracts to develop an automated letter-sorting system.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened hearings on a complex set of issues that boil down to one: What is to be the structure of the securities industry in the United States?

Performances of large-scale Cherubini works are not to be run across very often, and so a large audience took advantage of the Clarion Concerts program at Tully Hall on Tuesday night. Newell Jenkins and his forces were heard in Cherubini's Missa Solemnis in D minor.

It's not widely known outside of trade circles, but some experts are now saying that Prudhoe Bay crude oil may not reach American markets until 1977 or 1978. That's the pitch, for instance, from Oil Statistics Bulletins, Babson Park, Mass., a widely read trade publication.
The Sergeants Benevolent Association filed suit in State Supreme Court here yesterday to bar the Knapp Commission, which is investigating police corruption, from opening public hearings next Monday.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- A large increase in the number of legal abortions, accompanied by a striking advance in abortion safety, was reported today by Britain's chief medical officer in his annual review, "On the State of Public Health."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The House Ways and Means Committee, in a step that would benefit foundations controlled by the Pew oil and Kellogg cereal families, among others, voted today to loosen a provision of the Tax Reform Act of 1969 applying to foundations.

FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 13 -- The jury in the trial of Col. Oran K. Henderson learned today that the officer once offered, "in the interest of strengthening the American people's confidence in its Army," to take the blame for any cover-up of mass slayings of civilians at Mylai, South Vietnam.
To city and state budget officials, wages and fringe benefits have emerged as the most critical components of President Nixon's planned economic controls.
BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- A Federal grand jury here inevstigating how the Pentagon papers reached the press was reported today to be moving closer to returning indictments.
TOKYO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Japanese textile industry said today it will oppose the Government's decision to negotiate a textile agreement with the United States.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- East and West German negotiators ended a day of talks about access to Berlin with a visit to the Berliner Ensemble Theater in East Berlin. They saw Bertolt Brecht's "Arturo Ui," a play satirizing the rise of Hitler.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehlke announced tonight that all slot machines would be removed from every Army post and base around the world next July. He called the machines a "corruptive influence."

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 13 -- When the pollution in New York City air increases to levels commonly reached many times a year healthy people are much more likely to feel sick and even to get sick, according to findings presented here today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., had record sales and the second highest earnings in the third quarter, its best quarter this year, the report disclosed yesterday. While nine-month sales also reached a peak, earnings were down 8 per cent from last year reflecting the severely depressed first quarter because of the mandated loss of cigarette advertising.
BUFFALO, Oct. 13 (UPI) -The Buffalo Braves of the National Basketball Association surprisingly dismissed Coach Dolph Schayes tonight, one day after the 1971-72 season opened.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Government moved today to seek contemptof-court action against three locals of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union that were defying a court order to get cargo moving in West Coast ports.

PARAMUS, N. J., Oct. 13 -- With Larry Lichstein, one of the leaders in the $85,000 Professional Bowlers' Association national championship currently under way at Paramus Bowl, the left hand doesn't just wash the right hand -- It has provided a handy income for it.
Those Madison Avenue prophets who have been saying Stever Aubrey is the man to watch at the J. Walter Thompson Company can really chuckle it up this morning.

Ambassador Douglas' Oct. 5 letter about Mr. Nixon's current 10 per cent import surcharge hits the nail on the head. He brings out dramatically the worldwide monetary collapse and the creation of other serious barriers to international trade which followed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 and their disastrous results in contributing to worldwide economic depression.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Here is a partial list of reasons Congress cannot do anything:

Scientific representatives of eight nations in the East and West have agreed to set up an international institute to focus some of the world's best brains on the complex problems arising from modern technology.
The Seattle SuperSonics are promoting their own version of Superman -- Spencer Haywood.

The New York State Racing Commission yesterday suspended the licenses of Ralph Wilson, George Poole and Johnny Campo for 30 days for misrepresentation of ownership of thoroughbred horses. Wilson is an owner of horses and Poole and Campo are trainers.

Roger Freeman, in a recent letter, attempts to prove that corporate profits have lagged badly in recent years and therefore deserve to be exempt from any current or future "freeze" edicts. His method involves comparing the percentages of national income claimed by employe compensation versus corporate profits from 1965 through 1970.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -Scientists here have described experiments in which human cells, growing in laboratory flasks, took up and used genetic material native to bacteria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- An effort will be made in Congress to require Senate confirmation for President Nixon's wage and price regulators.

During a rap session with some "revolutionists" in their apartment, John Stickney discovered that he was hearing three different records playing at once. "Yeah," his host said, "the walls are paper-thin . . . I wish just once we could get together behind one album." It's that way, the author finds, with their revolution too.

ANCHORAGE, Oct. 13 -- Although no one expected the Emperor of Japan to arrive here today with "Alaska on $5 a Day" tucked under his arm, he apparently decided not to break the tourist's golden rule, of "When in Rome, do as the Romans do."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce is soliciting new memberships from doctors to help combat what it describes as "welfarism" and the passage of national health insurance.
Interest rates continued their pronounced drive toward lower levels yesterday.

State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger criticized the city's Human Resources Administration yesterday for minimizing the significance and numbers of likely removals of relief recipients from welfare rolls under the state's new work-relief law.

A bondsman's aide was arraigned yesterday in the Bronx on forgery and grand larceny charges stemming from an alleged attempt last week to have a prisoner freed from the Bronx House of Detention with the use of forged court documents.
BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 13 -- The Conservative party conference overwhelmingly endorsed today the Government's commitment to bring Britain into the European Economic Community.

Charles Chaplin's 81st picture, "A King in New York," which has never been shown in the United States, has been acquired for release here by Oliver A. Unger, president of Leisure Media, Inc., in association with Classic Festival Corporation.

The spotty third - quarter earnings performance of New York City's major banks continued in evidence yesterday as the Chase Manhattan Corporation reported a 7.2 per cent gain from operations and the Charter New York Corporation reported a 13.5 per cent decline.

The National Security Traders Association, an organization of 5,000 over-the-counter brokers and dealers, announced yesterday in Boca Raton, Fla., that James G. Mundy has been elected president to succeed Morton N. Weiss.

The threat to slash American financial support for the United Nations if the General Assembly votes to expel the Chinese Nationalists -- a threat that originated among Congressional conservatives led by Senator Buckley of New York -- is like an anvil tossed at a drowning man.
New car sales rose in the first 10 days of October but a variety of influences made the results considerably less of an economic indicator that is usually the case.

Increased interest abroad in United States-produced soybeans attracted speculative activity in futures of that commodity on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, sending prices up sharply. Late profit taking, however, trimmed some of the gains.
High-level officials in the city administration who are also licensed professionals were prohibited yesterday from engaging in private practice while employed by the city.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 -- The fate of the 100-year-old Queen City Hotel in Cumberland, Md., remained uncertain today as different spokesmen for the owner presented conflicting views on the sale of the building, which has been ordered demolished by the Cumberland City Council.

Known as a strong "law and order" advocate with most of her legal background in criminal prosecution . . . Appointed to first judgeship seven months ago by President Nixon and now serves on the Superior Court of the District of Columbia . . .

SHIRAZ, Iran, Oct. 13 -- For a while today it looked as if the Chinese Communists, who recently established diplomatic relations with Iran, would be the first guests at the Shah of Iran's tent city extravaganza.

TOKYO, Oct. 14 -- "The Japanese, Taiwanese, South Koreans and the people of Hong Kong are together going to contribute to the campaign funds which President Nixon hopes will get him re-elected next November."

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 -- In a dual action here today, MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, Inc., announced the election of a new chairman of the board and a major diversification into the leisure field with the construction of a fleet of luxury cruise liners and a large resort hotel in Las Vegas, Nev.
The city is dangerously close to its statutory debt limit and may have to curtail $332-million in construction projects, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

Dr. Earl W. Sutherland Jr. of Vanderbilt University, winner of the Nobel Prize in Physiology and Medicine, is known to biomedical scientists as one of the scientific giants of the mid-20th century, one of the few biologists whose work is fully comparable in importance to that of the contemporary founders of the betterpublicized field of molecular biology.

Susan Rosenstiel, estranged wife of Lewis Rosenstiel, former chairman of Schenley Industries, pleaded guilty to attempted third-degree perjury yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court and was fined $500.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- The nation's largest Jewish organization moved today to cope with problems of the Jewish poor, drug use among youth and other social ills that "threaten the stability of the Jewish family."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Oct. 9 was considerably below the volume in the corresponding 1970 week. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered an increase.
The Buffalo Bills, losers in their four league games this season, are "too good" a team to keep on losing, their coach, Harvey Johnson, said by phone from Buffalo yesterday.

At least 40 indictments involving city policemen are expected to be returned, beginning next month, by grand juries acting on information supplied by the Knapp Comm ission. The commission, headed by Whitman Knapp, a Wall Street lawyer, has been investigating allegations of police corruption in the city and is scheduled to begin hearings Monday.
PERSEPOLIS, Iran, Oct. 14 -- The Shah of Iran established himself tonight as one of the world's great party givers. For sheer grandeur, his gala in a silk tent will be hard for any nation to surpass.
Joan Garrity, author of the best seller "The Sensuous Woman," sued Lyle Stuart, Inc., the book's publisher, yesterday for damages totaling more than $3-million.

The Giants and Jets play at home on the same afternoon five times this season, beginning Sunday. What's left of the Jets goes against Buffalo as favorites while Baltimore is a heavy choice over the Giants. On television, Channel 4 will show New England at Miami at 1 P.M., if there is no World Series game, and Cleveland at Cincinnati at 4 if there is baseball.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Maj. Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry, the Sudan's first elected President, announced a 26-man Cabinet today and established a one-party system for his country.

Coughing and retching, soot-blackened residents of the stately Stanhope Hotel on Fifth Avenue at 81st Street fled to the street yesterday morning as acrid black smoke from a basement fire filled the building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A bill to increase the minimum wage to $2 an hour next January for some 35 million workers was cleared by a House committee today and headed toward a certain fight in the House itself.

The traditional antagonism between China and Japan brings a certain irony to the fact that the first fashions to reach New York from the People's Republic of China are at Takashimaya, the Japanese department store at 509 Fifth Avenue, between 42d and 43d Streets.
Neighbors of the West Side block that was occupied by 35 families of squatters squabbled before the Board of Estimate yesterday over the ad visability of putting a public housing project there.

A broad spectrum of American business involved with leasing went on record yesterday as opposing highly explosive proposals to change the rules by which the accounting profession deals with leasing transactions.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 14 -- A Baltimore research team has found that more than half of black schoolchildren may be unable to digest milk properly, raising serious questions about the usefulness of school milk programs to help raise the nutritional status of blacks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee tentatively cut nearly $850-million today from the Administration's $3.3-billion foreign aid request.
A key witness testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he took a bribe from Irving B. Kahn, head of the Teleprompter Corporation, but rejected a higher offer from someone else.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -Mrs. Patricia Roberts Harris, elected yesterday as temporary chairman of the Credentials Committee for the 1972 Democratic National Convention, promised today to combat the "continuing lack of trust among Democrats" manifested in the fight over her selection.

The right ankle that Charley Harper hurt hopping from a cafeteria window during the fire scare at the New York Giants training camp at C. W. Post College this summer still bothers him a bit. But he's hoping he doesn't have to think too much about it this week because he has other worries.

Players sometimes lose their heads when faced by a bad trump break. A contract that appeared simple has suddenly become difficult, and they fail to make the most of their chances. This was the situation on the diagramed deal, played recently at the New York-New Jersey Regional Championships.

The Times on Sept. 27 carried an article on alleged abuses in the Medicaid program that involved prescriptions for orthopedic shoes. Two years ago, the Podiatry Society of the State of New York submitted a detailed plan to the city designed to prevent exactly these abuses.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Henry A. Kissinger, the White House foreign policy expert, will leave for Peking on Saturday to make arrangements for President Nixon's journey to China.

ROME, Oct. 14 -- Delegates to the International Synod of Roman Catholic bishops began today to shift the focus of their deliberations from the crisis in the priesthood to what they could do to promote world justice.
BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 14 -- The Home Secretary, Reginald Maudling, reaffirmed in strong terms today the Government's commitment to keep Northern Ireland a part of Britain.

Wells Fargo Co., parent company of the $7-billion Wells Fargo Bank, announced yesterday a major modification in its plan to acquire the $1-billion First Western Bank and Trust Company from World Airways, Inc., for $95-million in cash and notes.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 -- Nelson Briles pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates to their third straight victory over the Baltimore Orioles today with a stunning two-hitter that put the Pirates one game away from winning the 68th World Series.
Interest rates on tax-exempt state and city bonds yesterday reached their lowest levels in more than two and a half years.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 14 -- Abdul Monem Khan, former Governor of East Pakistan, died today in the Dacca Medical College Hospital of gunshot wounds inflicted by two men who visited his home in Dacca, the East Pakistani capital, last night. The assailants, after talking with him for some time, suddenly fired and escaped. They left a grenade in his house.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Interest rates charged by the nation's commercial banks dropped slightly in the two weeks following the wage-price freeze announcement, a Federal Reserve report disclosed today.

FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 14 -- Brig. Gen. Samuel W. Koster, who was demoted and censured by the Army in connection with the events at Mylai 4, testified today that his subordinates had never told him a mass slaying of civilians occurred during the attack on the South Vietnamese hamlet.
In the 15 previous seasons of the Ivy League's roundrobin football competition, Brown is the only team that has never come away from a Dartmouth game as the winner.

As a task force examined New York's penitentiaries to select a site for the maximummaximum state security prison for "hardened and dangerous offenders," Fortune Society officers charged yesterday that such a facility would constitute a denial of prisoners' rights to due process of the law.

A four-day art show, with exhibits to illustrate how man helpfully and harmfully affects his environment, opened yesterday at Battery Park under the auspices of the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration.

Monticello Raceway's television contract with the Offtrack Betting Corporation was called everything from outrageous to monstrous yesterday during an emotional four-hour hearing before the State Harness Racing Commission.
CHICAGO -- Another virtually hopeless campaign to preserve the Old Stock Exchange, one of the more famous examples of the Chicago school of architecture, got under way here this week.

Councilman Robert I. Postel and the man whose resignation he has been demanding -Albert A. Walsh, head of the Housing and Development Administration -- confronted each other in public for the first time yesterday.

At noon today, John F. Harding, clerk of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia, will open bids in the Penn Central Railroad's board room in Philadelphia for what could be the biggest real estate deal in recent history -- 22 parcels of property and buildings in midtown Manhattan, north of Grand Central Terminal.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers deplored yesterday the new Soviet pledge to strengthen Egypt's military arsenal and said that the United States would have to "carefully reconsider" its military commitments to Israel as a result.
Police and judicial officials said yesterday that they intended to look into the release without bail of a number of prisoners who were arraigned Tuesday and Wednesday night in Bronx Criminal Court.

HOUSTON -- The medical and scientific community is sharply divided over proposed legislation seeking the "conquest of cancer." There is no dispute about the need for new legislation to secure a much greater and more concerted mobilization of scientific personnel, research centers, strategy and money for a bolder assault against cancer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The question of whether a mentally retarded infant should be allowed to die of a correctable physical defect was raised in a filmed discussion here today.

Just before I leave for England and home I must say thank you for the greatest experience in my life -- my first trip to your city. I left England in the belief that New Yorkers have no time for the minor courtesies and pleasantries of life. What nonsense.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- The International Monetary Fund reported today that total reserves of the 14 major non-Communist nations rose to a record of $83,601,000,000 at the end of August from $65,746,000,000 at the end of 1970.

The Allstate Insurance Company announced yesterday that a Swedish-built automobile, the 1972 Saab 99 E, had become the first car to qualify for the company's new 15 per cent "bumper discount" on collision insurance. The auto sells for $3,807.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The lure of the 1972 Democratic Presidential nomination has produced a wave of truancy in the Senate five months before the formal competition of the primaries gets under way.

Nearly eighty years ago, Thomas B. Reed, the Republican czar of the House of Representatives, called his Democratic opponents "a hopeless assortment of discordant differences." This week's row over the chairmanship of the Credentials Committee for their next national convention shows that whether or not the Democrats quite live up to that description, they are still in there trying.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 14 -Bobby Fischer of the United States and Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union drew after 38 moves of the fifth game of their match here today.
A jittery stock market took a severe pasting yesterday as prices fell to their lowest level since the Friday before the famous "Nixon rally" on Aug. 16.
A Yonkers businessman pulled out his pistol and wounded two men who held him up with a carving knife yesterday on an IRT subway train entering the Astor Place station.

To Janet Baker's large and worshiping audience, Wednesday night in Philharmonic Hall, she could do no wrong; and, indeed, there was very little that she did do wrong. Miss Baker, as we all know by now, is the most charming and musical of recitalists.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 14 -- Earl Wilbur Sutherland Jr., a gregarious and easygoing professor at Nashville's Vanderbilt University, has known for several years that he was under consideration for a Nobel Prize. Nobody gave him inside information.
SAIGON, Friday, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A South Vietnamese armored task force reportedly clashed with North Vietnamese troops yesterday in a brief but savage battle northwest of here just inside Cambodia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- The House Education and Labor Commitee approved legislation today that would fine or jail employers for knowingly hiring illegal aliens.

Ralph Weissman, formerly merchandise manager of the women's ready-to-wear apparel division of Gimbels New York area stores, has been named vice president and general merchandise manager of all soft goods divisions.

Three persons were arrested last night when portions of a crowd that had protested the presentation of a humanitarian award to Governor Rockefeller splashed paint on and broke windows in several office buildings along the Avenue of the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The House passed by a 344-to-44 vote today a bill to create an independent Federal agency with authority to advocate and defend consumer interests, particularly in regulatory proceedings before other Federal agencies.

Lyndon B. Johnson, making a surprise appearance at rededication ceremonies for the Dwight D. Eisenhower Museum in Abilene, Kan., eulogized the late President as "a towering figure in our American national past."

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 14 -- Dr. Earl W. Sutherland Jr., a professor of physiology at Vanderbilt University, was awarded the 1971 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine today for his work in unraveling the secrets of how hormones work.
After moving in a narrow range during the bulk of the trading, prices of silver futures closed higher again for the second day on the Commodity Exchange here.

When Jack Cantwell, who had been president of two agencies that belonged to somebody else, opened his own place in March, 1970, he decided the best way to get his foot in a prospective client's door was to present him with a new product.

Jerome Rose, who is becoming an annual piano recitalist here, loves and believes in the traditional composers, and he is not afraid to program their less familiar works. On Wednesday night in Tully Hall, he played Schubert's Sonata in A minor (Op. 42), Beethoven's Sonata in D (Op. 10, No. 3) and Schumann's "Kreisleriana."

SUSQUEHANNA, Pa., -The men sit at the bar in the dim light of the American Legion post here and quietly sip whisky. A few peel open thin strips of paper they have purchased from the bartender for a dime each and look for concealed lucky numbers that pay off as much as $5.

The six-year, $100-million Ford Foundation program to improve the quality of ten private Negro colleges cannot solve the staggering problems of the nation's predominantly black campuses; but it does symbolize a new realism in dealing with an institutional disaster area. If the plan succeeds, a few front-runners in that pitifully neglected sector of higher education could emerge into the integrated academic mainstream.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- The New York Times, the Columbia Broadcasting System and Helen Gurley Brown have been named to receive the annual Distinguished Achievement Awards of the University of Southern California School of Journalism.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 14 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers and other Administration officials today stressed their confidence that the campaign to save Nationalist China's seat in the United Nations would succeed.
Merck Co., Inc., reported yesterday record earnings and sales for the third quarter and nine months.

Grete Sultan, a pianist who plays what she likes and pays little heed to repertory fads or popular taste, came to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night with a program that was stern to say the least. It consisted of Schubert's Impromptu in F minor (Op. 142) and Moment Musical No. 6, Schoenberg's Klavierstuck (Op. 33A), Wolpe's Form for Piano (1959) and Beethoven's 33 Variations on a Waltz by Diabelli (Op. 120).
Miss Lois Fredrica Meyer was married here yesterday evening to Leonard Marshall Gold. Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein performed the ceremony at the Carlyle.
A jury in Criminal Court here yesterday convicted two young men charged with possessing homemade bombs with intent to injure.
TOKYO, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -Japan and the United States opened Governmental negotiations here today on an agreement regulating Japanese textile exports to the American market.
CAIRO, Oct. 14 -- A step-up in diplomatic efforts toward a reopening of the Suez Canal was foreseen by diplomats here today following President Anwar el-Sadat's consultations in Moscow.
Warren Page, the executive vice president of the National Shooting Sports Foundation, has given middle -aged hunters cause for small rejoicing.

More than one-fifth of the office construction in midtown Manhattan between 1963 and 1971 required the demolition of housing, and more than one-fourth of that now in the planning stage would do the same, according to a report by the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., announced plans today for the creation of labor "watchdog units" around the country to monitor prices during the second phase of President Nixon's economic stabilization program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A Federal scientist charged today that the flu shots that have been taken by millions of Americans annually are ineffective and that the Governmental agency that regulates these vaccines has refused to act against them.

Dr. Joseph T. English, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said yesterday that the board of directors, after a meeting called to find ways to cope with a $30million budget deficit, had voted to begin "selective attrition" of all vacated jobs within the agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Leaders of the mutual fund industry largely rejected today a proposal that they establish rules requiring mutual funds to take into account the social policies of corporations in which they invest shareholders' money.

President Nixon's Phase Two economic plan seems like a good idea to Louis Kanter, eight years into his retirement and increasingly buffeted by inflation.

The Continental Can Company and the American Can Company, the two leaders in the metal container and packaging field, had higher sales in the third quarter and nine months this year, according to their reports issued yesterday.

A Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service spokesman said yesterday that no decision had been made yet on a mediator for an International Longshoremen's Association work stoppage that has kept virtually all Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports shut down for the last 14 days.

Can it really be 25 years, a quarter of a century, since Frankie Laine lifted himself from obscurity by singing "That's My Desire" in his tight, clipped, staccato phrases? For a fact, it is, and it is 20 years since he solidified that breakthrough by opening up those staccato phrases to an exuberant shout on "Mule Train" and "Cry of the Wild Goose."
TOKYO, Oct. 14 -- Immediately after his return home today, Emperor Hirohito told his people: "I feel deeply that further efforts will be needed to achieve international friendship and world peace."

MONTE CARLO, Monaco -- Every now and then the world's statesmen, benefiting from the jet age, seek to embellish diplomacy with motion. We have entered another season of official tourism. Even this ministate's sovereign Prince is on tour. One is reminded of the legend that President Eisenhower ordered his roving Secretary of State: "Foster, don't just do something, stand there."
Five Rockefeller brothers assembled on East 51st Street yesterday afternoon to watch their older sister, Mrs. Jean Mauze, open a 6,360-square-foot vest-pocket park.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Sipsah, an 8,000-ton Pakistani ship, has recently unloaded crates of North Korean small arms and ammunition at Karachi, well informed sources reported here today.

TRENTON, Oct. 14 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine had counted on having New Jersey's two leading Democrats publicly committed this evening to his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination. But it didn't work out that way.
A 26-year-old Manhattan patrolman has been indicted for allegedly beating a former Jordanian policeman in a prisoner van and then dumping him into the street.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 14 -The statement by Secretary of State William P. Rogers yesterday warning Chile against nationalization of United States companies' interest in large copper mines without compensation touched off a "national unity" campaign here today.
NEWARK, Oct. 14 -- Six men were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of stealing copper and liquor from New York piers in 1968.

The five hopeful faces in The Times of Oct. 6 seeking to succeed U Thant as Secretary General of the United Nations form an impressive array. The phone rang and Bing excused himself to take the call in the next room.

Clinton E. Frank, Inc., Chicago, made its first public stock offering yesterday, 150,000 shares at $15.50 a share. All shares came from 64 stockholders in the company. The new issue was completely sold, closing at $16.50 bid.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 15 -- Two policemen were killed by machine-gun fire on a busy shopping street in downtown Belfast this afternoon.

Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson has directed her department's lawyers to determine whether the city can make violations of the Federal price freeze a violation of city consumer protection law punishable by a fine or imprisonment.

SAINT-NOM-LA-BRETECHE, France, Oct. 15 -- Arnold Palmer, who remembers his every shot after a round of golf, didn't have to tax his memory too much today at the Lancome Trophy invitation tourney here near Paris.
LOS ANGELES -- Jack Combest paid his rent with a smile last month. Combest General Store in Lakewood, Calif., has sold 30,000 smile buttons since the happy face phenomenon started last spring.

OTTAWA, Oct. 15 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that the Government had embarked on its program of employment incentives and tax cuts as a mark of confidence in Canada's prospects for prosperity.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 15 -- The New York Nets have grown up. In overhauling the Pittsburgh Condors, 115-107, tonight in their season opener at the Island Garden, they brought a new image to the American Basketball Association-defense.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- More than three-quarters of the Senate joined in sponsoring a resolution today calling upon the Administration to resume the shipment of F-4 Phantom fighter-bombers to Israel "without further delay."

YONKERS, Oct. 15 -- Yonkers Raceway reopened this evening following a morning, afternoon and night of travail that must have tried the patience of nearly everyone connected with the harness racing track.

The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of Cowles Broadcasting Service, Inc., from Cowles Communications, Inc. Cowles Broadcasting Service is the licensee of a Memphis television station, WREC-TV.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15 -- If the Baltimore Orioles had their backs to the wall today, they also had a chalked sign on the wall in their locker room, and it said: "Remember the Mets. It took a year. Now we can do it in two days here."

The new-issue market turned mixed this week as this segment of over-the-counter activity resisted the sharp downward pressure experienced by the stock exchanges. Trading was light to moderate.

SEA CLIFF, L. I. -- Six years ago Mrs. Anita Flackbert, rummaging around an antiques store here, found a battered, 19th-century French credence. It was inlaid with tortoise shell and bronze scrollwork, in imitation of the style to which Andre Charles Boulle, Louis XIV's favorite cabinetmaker, lent his name, and Mrs. Flackbert saw in that worn piece of furniture "a chance to make something as beautiful as it once was."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- President Nixon is considering asking Chief Justice Warren E. Burger to select a Federal three-judge panel to hear appeals of wage and price board decisions in the post-freeze period, Congressional sources said today.

A battle for control of N. V. Rubberfabrick Vredestein, a large Netherlands tire and rubber maker, ended yesterday with a settlement in which the Goodyear Tire and Rubber has long had an interest in a subsidiary of Vredestein.

To the Editor: I regret that in the obituary for Waiter C. Baker which appeared in The Times Sept. 26 circumstances did not permit the mention of Mr. Baker's long association with and generous and effective support of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. Baker was an exceptionally active trustee of the museum from 1948 as well as being a vice president of the museum from 1960 to 1971.

A Long Island coed filed a $1-million damage suit yesterday against Vassar College, charging that she had flunked out after her first year because her roommate's all-night marijuana parties prevented her from studying.

The First Pennsylvania Corporation, the parent company of the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, Philadelphia's largest bank, reported yesterday operating earnings for the third quarter of $8.5-million, or 71 cents a share, up 11 per cent from the $7.7-million, or 64 cents, earned in 1970.

Mayor Lindsay's weekend swing through Indiana pointed up a major problem in his fledgling Presidential campaign -- the Mayor can leave New York but New York doesn't leave him.

Mayor Lindsay pinned medals of valor yesterday on the relatives of 12 firemen who died in a fire on Oct. 17, 1966.

The New York City Opera has a new Countess in its "Marriage of Figaro" production. Pauline Domanski, a Juilliard graduate with recent German opera experience, made her debut in the role at the Saturday afternoon performance.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Bobby Fischer of the United States and Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union played five hours and 42 moves tonight before adjourning their sixth chess game in the match to determine a challenger for the world title.

The state's "Big 6" Mayors will resurrect their lobbying and publicity campaign -- highly successful with the 1970 Legislature but a failure this year -- with a meeting on Wednesday at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Responding to an appeal from 59 Senators, the White House announced today that President Nixon has ordered the Agriculture Departure to "clarify" a controversial set of school lunch regulations imposed earlier this fall.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17--The Pittsburgh Pirates completed one of the most dramatic reversals in baseball history today when they defeated the favored Baltimore Orioles, 2-1, and won the 68th World Series in the seventh and final game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- In the first national comparative study of its kind, the Census Bureau has found that persons of Spanish-speaking ancestry earn significantly greater incomes than blacks, even though they have poorer educations.

The proposed $2.5 billion Transportation Bond Issue, which will be on the November ballot, is represented as a package balanced between mass transit and highways and between the needs of the New York metropolitan area and upstate. This is nonsense. The price of the much-needed transit and rail improvements proposed for the metropolitan area is completion of the enormously destructive Interstate System in New York City.

Uncertainty about wage and price guidelines in the postfreeze period has left the commercial printing industry here -- one of the area's biggest -- in a bind that is illustrative of the problems that may lie ahead.

Since Barney Josephson began booking established jazz pianists such as Mary Lou Williams, Marian McPartland and Sammy Price into his restaurant, The Cookery, West Eighth Street at University Place, last November, one could be grateful that there was a place in New York where these musicians could be heard in compatible surroundings.
A 10-year-old East Harlem girl was found murdered yesterday morning in the backyard of a tenement on East 111th Street where she formerly lived.
PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Ralph Nader impressed several hundred Frenchmen today but when his meeting with them was over it remained unclear what French consumers should do next.

The Public Broadcasting Service announced yesterday that it would televise a concert by the World Symphony Orchestra on Thanksgiving evening, Nov. 25. The 90-minute program, which will be carried by Channel 13 at a time to be announced, will be conducted by Arthur Fiedler.

United States Attorneys Whitney North Seymour Jr. and Robert A. Morse of the Southern and Eastern Districts of New York respectively, announced yesterday that new administrative procedures would be begun to cut by 30 days the time involved in Federal criminal appeals in the New York area.

The city's poor are not the principal users of the city's subways; most of the passengers have above-average incomes.

Chairman Wilbur Mills of the House Ways and Means Committee will open hearings tomorrow on the many and varied plans on Capitol Hill for modifying or revolutionizing this country's medical care system. George Foreman, unbeaten in 31 bouts, will meet Luis Pires of Brazil in a 10-round heavyweight match at Madison Square Garden a week from tomorrow.

The world champion Aces will no doubt start as the favorites in the international team final playoff in New Orleans starting tomorrow, but nevertheless they will be very narrow favorites. City and state officials agreed yesterday on a plan to save the 30-cent transit fare for two years. However, they stressed that the plan, worked out in several weeks of bargaining, depended on the passage of Governor Rockefeller's $2.5-billion transportation bond issue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted on conspiracy charges the former Grand Dragon of the Michigan Ku Klux Klan and four of his associates in the bombing of 10 school buses in Pontiac, Mich., last August.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Cuba has been accepted as the 95th member of an influential but loose grouping of developing countries that seek to formulate a joint strategy to protect their economic interests.
HERAKLEION, Crete, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Vice President Agnew, touring on the island of Crete, inspected the ancient ruins at Cnossos today, then viewed a missile base of the North Atlantic alliance.

On their beats and in the back rooms of their stations, policemen voiced resentment yesterday at Knapp Commission testimony charging widespread graft and bribe-taking on the force.

Four rifle shots were fired through a window of an 11thfloor room of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations on East 67th Street last night. The police reported no injuries to the family of six, including four children, who were in the room.

The stock market was pounded yesterday as prices showed their heaviest losses in two months. The Dow-Jones industrial average fell 12.78 points, bringing its setback over the last six sessions to 37.90 points.

TRENTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -Mortimer Nappen, chief of Atlantic County detectives, was indicted by a state grand jury today on charges of threatening a jockey with false arrest to get him to repay a loan.

DALLAS, Oct. 20 -- The politically obscure Mayor of a Dallas suburb was elected chairman of the Texas Democratic party today over the opposition of Gov. Preston Smith and former Senator Ralph W. Yarborough.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Roy Jenkins and other leading advocates within the Labor party of British membership in the Common Market will not resign their party offices in the deep party conflict over the issue.

BETHPAGE, L. I., Oct. 20 -- The slump in the aerospace industry and the termination of the Lunar Excursion Module project have jolted the Grumman Corporation, and the jolt is still sending shudders through Long Island's economy.
Stock prices buckled yesterday under the weight of dispiriting news as the market suffered its sharpest decline in two months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -President Nixon intends to name C. Jackson Grayson Jr., dean of the business school at Southern Methodist University, as chairman of the seven-member Price Commission, it was disclosed today.

Lester B. Pearson, former Prime Minister of Canada, has been installed as chairman of the International Broadcast Institute, the private group committed to improvement in global communications. He formally assumed the post on Tuesday night at a meeting at the Century Club, 7 West 43d Street.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Pablo Neruda came out of his embassy office here today and gave assembled newsmen a poet's line: "Poets believe in miracles and this time it has happened it would seem."

The City Center Joffrey Ballet is raffling off two plane tickets to Vienna at intermissions, and the fellow who distributed bouquets to the dancers Wednesday night after the premiere of Gerald Arpino's ballet "Kettentanz" was wearing lederhosen.
GTE Sylvania, Inc., has notified 1,367 employes that it might have to close its Batavia, N. Y., television assembly plant because of unusually high hourly wage scales.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., the Dallas-based conglomerate, reduced its operating loss in the third quarter and first nine months this year, but the net loss after extraordinary charges, continued at substantial amounts, according to yesterday's report.
A Brooklyn man accused by the police of being a major narcotics distributor was arrested in an East Flatbush apartment yesterday with four other persons alleged to be his confederates.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 22 (Reuters) -- The United States Army has dropped charges of willful disobedience against 29 soldiers alleged to have been involved in a fight between black and white soldiers, an Army spokesman said today.

The Ecological Science Corporation of Miami announced yesterday it had filed a suit in Dade County Circuit Court against its auditor, Haskins Sells, asking $73-million in damages. The suit alleged, among other things, that the accounting firm misled the company and caused it to be late in filing certain reports with regulatory agencies, thereby damaging the company's relationships with the American Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Prices of the common and preferred stocks of American Standard, Inc., fell sharply yesterday in reaction to the company's announcement Thursday night of a sharp drop in third-quarter profit, prospects of a substantial loss for 1971 and plans to dispose of $250-million of assets. American Standard's common stock was the second most active on the New York Stock Exchange with volume of 135,300 shares.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 22 -- The last American combat units along the Cambodian border were pulled out today from their fire base, which had been under daily enemy shelling for the last four weeks.
ALBANY, Oct 22 (UPI) -- Banks have the right to arrange for group life insurance for savings depositors, an appeals court ruled here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- United States and European Common Market officials emerged from two days of discussions today with two different notions of the conditions under which the United States would be willing to lift its 10 per cent surtax on imports.

A new promotional program designed to attract tourists to New York City was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and eight business and cultural leaders in the fog-shrouded observation tower of the Empire State Building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI)--Nine members of the black militant Republic of New Africa were indicted today on charges stemming from a fatal shooting at the group's Jackson, Miss., headquarters last summer.
About 25,000 New Jersey commuters were left without their regular bus service yesterday as 105 drivers of the Hudson Bus Transportation Company of Jersey City went on strike in a contract dispute.

Cooper Jr., demanded today that the police and the Middlesex County Prosecutor's Office investigate charges by a black leader here that officials of the Urban League of Greater New Brunswick were masterminding a student boycott and disruption of New Brunswick High School.

The Mets, who traded Art Shamsky on Monday and sold Ron Taylor on Wednesday, continued their house-cleaning yesterday by asking irrevocable waivers on Donn Clendenon and Bob Aspromonte for the purpose of giving them their unconditional releases.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- President Nixon appointed today 22 members of the Pay Board and the Price Commission, the agencies that will create and administer economic controls in Phase Two of the Administration's program to stabilize the economy.

Mystery continued yesterday to surround potential buyers for the Radio Corporation of America's computer operations as the rumor mill predicted that RCA would announce late in the day a sale to the Xerox Corporation. This did not develop.

The American Stock Exchange finished on the fence yesterday as prices ended practically unchanged in slow trading.

Whitman Knapp, chairman of the commission investigating alleged police corruption, was placed under police protection yesterday after a caller warned that a man with a high-powered rifle would try to kill him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The maker of Wonder Bread, while conceding that the product is not distinctively more nutritious than competing brands, has filed a denial of false advertising charges with Federal Trade Commission.
MOUGINS, France -- The most illustrious resident of this township will be 90 years old on Monday, and the occasion is being celebrated in Paris, Barcelona, Vallauris -- but not in Mougins.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 22 -- Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. said tonight that a brief conference in his office here this afternoon had resulted in agreement on "90 per cent of a contract" that could end the impasse in negotiations in the 22-day-old soft-coal strike, perhaps by the end of next week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- A Criminal Court judge ordered today a full and open hearing into allegations that five special prosecutors improperly influenced the Cook County grand jury that returned indictments against Edward V. Hanrahan, Cook County State's Attorney, and 13 others in the case that grew out of a raid on the apartment of Black Panther leaders.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- Speaking in the name of the American bishops of the Roman Catholic Church, John Cardinal Krol of Philadelphia charged today that the accumulation of weapons by the United States and other countries is a violation of fundamental principles of justice.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 22 -- Mrs. David M. Goldring of Maplewood, N. J., was elected president of Women's American ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation through Training) yesterday at the final session of the organization's biennial convention at the Diplomat Hotel.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 -- The Soviet Union made a "resolute" protest to the United States today over the incident in which shots were fired at the building of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations in New York two days ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (Reuters) -- The State Department today challenged reports quoting Vice President Spiro Agnew as saying that President Nixon was ready to override any Congressional ban on military aid to the army-backed Government in Greece.

NEWARK, Oct. 22 -- Barringer High School reopened today under increased security as the Essex County Prosecutor, Joseph P. Lord, began investigating reports that white adults were responsible for the persistent racial tension in the school.

The Aluminum Company of America filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the proposed sale of $150-million of sinking fund debentures. The First Boston Corporation will head an underwriting group that will sell the debentures, which are due 1996.
The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's largest chemical producer after E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., reported yesterday lower earnings for the third quarter and nine months of 1971.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- An Air Force sergeant charged earlier this week with attempting to pass classified information to unauthorized persons was apprehended before he could board a plane to Mexico City for an alleged rendezvous with Soviet agents there, Government sources said today.

ATHENS, Oct. 22 -- A Greek opposition leader who headed the country's last Parliament before the military take-over scoffed today at Vice President Agnew's contention that the Government was restoring democracy.

GTE Information Systems, Inc., announced yesterday it would enter the "third-party" computer equipment maintenance field. Leonard A. Muller, president of the subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, will have a 550-man staff to maintain other manufacturers' equipment from 90 key locations next year.

A New York City patrolman told the Knapp Commission yesterday that all but two of the 70 to 75 policemen he worked with in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn regularly took small bribes from gamblers, tow-truck operators, check cashers and supermarket operators.
The Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center announced yesterday a new fund-raising program called "Repertory 500" to serve as a base of financial support for the Vivian Beaumont Theater.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A United States District Court upheld today the constitionality of the law on which the Phase Two controls program is based.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct, 22--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union inspected the St. Lawrence Seaway from the air today while flying westward to Vancouver.

The magnificent ruins of the ancient city of Angkor in northwestern Cambodia are among the wonders of the world, an Eastern counterpart of Rome, Athens and Luxor. They are also a coveted prize in the Cambodian war, symbolizing the lost grandeur of a Khmer kingdom that once held sway over much of Southeast Asia, from the China Sea to the Indian Ocean.

Omega-Alpha, Inc., announced yesterday it has agreed to acquire the Transcontinental Investing Corporation in a transaction involving about $55-million in Omega's common stock. Only three weeks remain before the 90-day freeze on wages and prices expires, to be replaced by a more flexible and therefore much more complicated program of restraints.

There is a cold and fine madness to Yale M. Udoff's play "A Gun Play," which opened at the Cherry Lane Theater yesterday. BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 27 -- A Roman Catholic was unexpectedly appointed today to the Cabinet for the first time in 50-year history of Northern Ireland.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare's proposed experiment with an Incentives for Independence Program which is expected "to encourage a speedy return of welfare clients to independence and selfsufficiency" cannot be too strongly condemned.

Seven inmates of the Queens House of Detention for Men filed a suit in Federal Court yesterday, charging that the warden and Department of Correction officials were holding them illegally in administrative detention.

MOSCOW, Oct. 27 -- The atmosphere in Moscow's Central Chess Club was subdued tonight as fans, hunched over boards, went over the moves in the game in Buenos Aires that gave Bobby Fischer of the United States the final victory over Tigran Petrosian and a chance to challenge Boris Spassky for the world title.
Mayor Lindsay, who has been wooing Democrats as far west as California, was snubbed by Queens Democrats and upstaged by Senator Edward M. Kennedy last night.

After considerable committee study, the membership of the New York Chamber of Commerce endorsed the Governor's $2.5-billion transportation bond issue and urges citizen and business support for its passage on Nov. 2.
Two Gilbert and Sullivan fans, Ann Seranne and Barbara Wolferman, have the very model of a modern canine kennel in their Mayfair Yorkie House at Newton, N. J.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 26 -In 15 years, William H. Rehnquist's goals have shifted from winning the local toastmaster's speech contest to becoming an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I. -- Just as soon as the sitter, his sister, arrived, Gary Walter checked on the children: Ira, 8, was doing his homework; Lori, 6, was settled in front of the television set. Mr. Walter then grabbed his loose-leaf Parent's Manual and hustled his wife, Marlene, into the car.

ELY, Vt. -- Most discussion of the wage-price freeze and the coming Phase II controls has been strictly economic and operational: were they needed, will they work, how will they operate. I have recorded my own opposition to them in three columns in Newsweek.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -General concern over population growth has become so intense, a new Federal study shows, that half the public now favors liberalization of restrictions on abortion.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- Delegates to the world Synod of Bishops are moving toward a conviction that the Roman Catholic Church must broaden its understanding of sin to include the "structural" injustice of major social institutions that many people assume to be morally neutral.

A 29-year-old Brooklyn man held on a warrant charging him with nonsupport committed suicide early yesterday in a cell at the Long Island City, Queens police station by hanging himself with his blue denim jacket.
Gloria Stetnem will be editor and Elizabeth Forsling Harris, publisher, of a new monthly magazine for women "who neds and interests go far beyond the limits of home and husband."

There was more than a little drama in the ninth and final game of Bobby Fischer's triumph over Tigran Petrosian in Buenos Aires on Tuesday. The American, who had blanked two previous opponents in the elimination trials leading to the world challenge match, was determined to make his triumph over the former world champion as convincing as possible.
The Regional Plan Association endorsed the $2.5-billion state transportation bond issue yesterday, but only as a stopgap measure in any long-range plan to solve the state's transportation problems.

Joseph S. Tushinsky, president of Superscope, Inc., announced yesterday that his company had acquired 50 per cent of the capital stock of the Standard Radio Corporation of Japan. Mr. Tushinsky said that this was the first time that the Japanese Government had permitted a foreign corporation to obtain 50 per cent of a publicly owned Japanese company.

In what some consumer-law experts said was the first such case they knew of, Judge Edward Thompson began a consumerfraud hearing yesterday in Civil Court that could ultimately bring refunds to thousands of New Yorkers who bought an allegedly shoddy burglar alarm in the last two years.

The Internal Revenue Service, enforcement agency for President Nixon's wage-price freeze, since last Friday has been bringing pressure on retailers to make ceiling prices available to consumers and warning them that failure to do so would make them liable to a $5,000 fine.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 27 -Twenty-two Cubans took their ease in a roadside motel here today and steadfastly refused the United States Government's demand that they get on their airplane and go home.
DUBLIN -- Christy Brown, the Dublin - born crippled writer whose autobiographical novel, "Down All the Days," has become a bestseller in 14 languages, is half way through another book.

When a French singer sings a song, he is more concerned with the experience than the music. KANSAS CITY, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The University of California, Los Angeles, was placed on probation for a year by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today for recruiting violations.

While some women have taken to the streets to crusade for women's rights, a group of women law students at New York University has taken to the classroom to further the cause.

Alternating waves of sweet and astringent choreography coursed through the Choreconcerts program Tuesday evening at the New School. The choreographers were Gus Solomons Jr., Laura Foreman, Stuart Hodes and Richard Bull.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Israeli diplomatic sources said today that their country would not agree to join in Americansponsored indirect talks with Egypt on reopening the Suez Canal until the current United States embargo on the delivery of jet aircraft to Israel was lifted.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Chuck Hughes, the wide receiver of the Detroit Lions football team, was buried today amid the rolling Green Hills of the state where he grew up. All 49 members of the Lions team attended the funeral.

The city's Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance set a new policy yesterday by turning down a landlord who had sought to evict residents of an apartment building but had offered no proof of a "substantial" number of tenants for the office building planned for the site.
TOKYO, Oct. 27 -- Premier Eisaku Sato's Cabinet rebuffed its critics tonight by beating back two no-confidence motions in the lower house of Parliament.

Japan's Ambassador to the United States said yesterday that the "shock" of President Nixon's new economic policy had worked and urged that the 10 per cent surcharge on imports be lifted quickly.

ATLANTA, Oct. 27 -- The Knicks put themselves into a deep hole with three quarters worth of atrocious floor shooting tonight and then, when they found the range in the fourth, could not overcome their self-imposed handicap as they lost to the Hawks at Alexander Memorial Coliseum, 110-96.

Moody's Capital Fund, Inc., and Smith, Barney Equity Fund, Inc., announced an agreement yesterday under which all of the assets of the Moody's fund would be exchanged for shares of the Smith, Barney fund.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 27 -- Acting Premier Sisowath Sirik Matak affirmed today that the Government considered its suspension of Parliament as "very temporary" and pledged that it would act "very speedily" to restore democratic rule.

The State Department of Social Services said yesterday that in view of objections to a proposed welfare experiment Mayor Lindsay and others have attacked as a "brownie-point" scheme "some alternatives have been considered."

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 27 -- While conceding that the status of their Government has plummeted, Chinese Nationalist officials stressed their determination today to make the most of a new situation they called "tough but not irreparable."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -Secretary of State William P. Rogers urged the Senate today to approve a treaty relinquishing American control over Okinawa as a necessary step toward maintaining "a viable and harmonious relationship" with Japan.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Seven white students and five policemen were injured today in an apparent racial brawl at Myers Park High School that involved about 150 students.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 27 -- The United States' allies in Europe seem reconciled to an eventual substantial reduction in the size of the American military force in Europe, judging from private discussions here among defense ministers and nuclear planning experts of seven NATO countries.

A disruption of trading on foreign-exchange markets around the world is "putting a damper on international business activity," a leading United States banker warned yes terday. In a talk to a group of Italian businessmen in Milan, Walter H. Page, president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, asserted that "uncertainty and rampant official intervention have seriously impaired the ability of the markets to perform their economic function efficiently."

PEKING, Oct. 27 -- The official newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao, read by millions throughout China, gave over almost its entire front page today to reports of the United Nations's decision to eject the Chinese Nationalists and hand the China seat to Peking.

Six athletic directors in the New York area have agreed on plans for a small-college football league to be known as the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Football Conference. The conference will not be established until the governing bodies of each institution approve the charter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -Two of the nation's leading manufacturers of laundry detergents, Lever Brothers and ColgatePalmolive, urged Congress today to set "reasonable" limitations on phosphate contents of all such products.

DENVER, Oct. 27 -- A study of birth and death records in the Grand Junction, Colo., area where radioactive sands from uranium processing mills were used in construction projects, shows increased genetic problems, higher cancer rates and lower birth rates than those of the rest of the state.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -New Government figures on retail sales, productivity and other measures of the economy showed no clear trend today either in business activity or in the battle against inflation.
The Knapp Commission yesterday provided a glance into the shadowy world of certain narcotics addicts who are informants for policemen.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 28 -- The South Vietnamese Government announced this morning that it would free from prison nearly 3,000 Vietcong in the largest such release of the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Civil Rights Commission accused the Federal Government today of complicity with the private housing industry in maintaining racially segregated housing.
BELFAST, Oct. 27 (UPI) -Gunmen killed a police sergeant and seriously wounded a police constable tonight.

A situation that has been called the "gravest transportation crisis in New York City's history" has been neatly solved. No one has lost face.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -United States customs officials have seized more than 1,000 pounds of heroin in the first nine months of this year, a Treasury Department official said today.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 27 -- Nikolai P. Firyubin, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, left New Delhi today after a series of talks that apparently included discussions of Soviet military commitments to India in the event of an India-Pakistan war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Rod Jenkins, a 27-year-old professional from Orange, Va., could do no wrong today at the Washington International Horse Show and took three championships. Moreover, he rode the reserve champion in two of the divisions.

Two immensely significant bond issues require voter approval in New Jersey: one for "green-acres," which would preserve some of the Garden State's rapidly disappearing open space; the other for education, which would help meet New Jersey's scandalous deficiency in facilities for public higher education.

Y., Oct. 27 -- Secretary General Thant has chosen the United Nations delegates of Argentina, Italy and Sierra Leone for a commission to check into the Israeli Government's housing and population policies in the former Jordan area of Jerusalem, authoritative sources disclosed today.

YONKERS, Oct. 27 -- Nearly everything that happened in the $45,948 E. Roland Harriman Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight benefited the favored Super Bowl. TORONTO, Oct. 27 (Canadian Press) -- Four more banks including the Royal Bank of Canada, the nation's largest -joined others today in reducing their prime lending rate to 6 per cent from 6 1/4 per cent starting next Monday.

LOS ANGELES -- When I was a schoolboy in the 1950's, I wanted to become a scientist, but I doubted that I could. Parke, Davis Co., announced yesterday the election of Joseph D. Williams as executive vice president and chief operating officer of the international pharmaceutical firm. At the same time, Hazen L. Richardson Jr. was elected vice president of U. S. marketing, the position formerly held by Mr. Williams. PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Yves Saint Laurent, the designer who feels that he can be more influential in ready-to-wear than in haute couture, showed a 300-piece boutique collection today. The Roller Derby returned to New York on a regular basis yesterday for the first time since 1959, and its fans, apparently, are ready to re-embrace it. The crowd of 16,228 savored every elbow thrown, each fight, and all the scoring as the Chiefs, New York's team, edged the Red Devils, 31-30.

Helen Chen Lee, a Chinese soprano recently arrived in New York, and Rosemary Leeder, a Canadian mezzo who has lived here since 1962, shared a debut program at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon. LONDON -- On March 30, 1967, President Johnson had all the Democratic state chairmen to the White House for a reception. As each shook the President's hand, a photograph was taken -- to be sent to the chairman as a useful political memento.

Stock prices broke sharply yesterday to wipe out the last vestiges of the faltering market advance of 1971.
