The one major omission in the President's New Economic Policy, which he has called the most comprehensive economic program since the New Deal, has been a spelling out of the monetary policy he expects from the Federal Reserve Board.

TOYAMA, Japan, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Pat Dobson made international baseball history today as he hurled the first no-hit, no-run game of his career and gave the Baltimore Orioles a 2-0 victory over Japan's champion Tokyo Yomiuri Giants.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Despite new Administration appeals, the Democratic leadership of the Senate balked today at proposals for a 90-day extension of the foreign aid program financed at last year's $2.64-billion annual rate.
I was pleased to see your Oct. 21 editorial opposing the unfortunate pesticides bill now pending before the House of Representatives. It is indeed a weak measure.
Merchants' heavy, promotional blasts on Election Day turned stores in the city and suburbs into major public meeting places yesterday.

YONKERS, Nov. 2 -- The sale of Yonkers Raceway and its other holdings to a Pennsylvania group headed by John Rooney, the president of the William Penn Racing Association, operator of Philadelphia's Liberty Bell Park, will be consummated tomorrow, a source close to the negotiations disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 -Frank L. Rizzo, who calls himself the "toughest cop in America," swept to a solid victory today over his Republican opponent, Thacher Longstreth, to become Mayor of the country's fourth largest city.

DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 2 -- The Pakistani Government announced today that 53 of the National Assembly seats taken away from members of the outlawed Awami League in East Pakistan would be filled without contest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Major American, British and French oil companies have begun negotiations with 11 oil producing nations, most of them Middle Eastern, on the producers' demand for "participation" in the companies and for compensation for the reduced value of the dollar.

The city and Housing Authority police increased their patrols in a moderate-income housing project in Far Rockaway, Queens, yesterday following the death of an 80-yearold woman who was mugged near her building Monday morning and died that night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Following are the texts of two cablegrams received by Secretary General Thant today from the Acting Foreign Minister of China, Chi Peng-fei, regarding the composition of the Chinese delegation to the General Assembly and the Chinese representation on the Security Council. The messages were in English.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2 -- In a vast outpouring of nostalgia, 3,000 people, including some prominent political leaders, gathered in the rain today around the unmarked grave of Ngo Dinh Diem, and for the first time since he was overthrown as President eight years ago, publicly sang his official song, "Long Live President Diem."

Tony Tanner, the British musical - comedy performer and director, has been engaged to stage "Nevertheless, They Laugh," a musical based on Leonid Andreyev's "He Who Gets Slapped." It will be put on Broadway in January by the new producing team of Les Schecter and Barbara Schwei.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 2 -- The estimated death toll continued to rise today in the cyclone and tidal wave that struck the eastern coast of India over the weekend, with some officials predicting that it might reach 20,000 or more.

One of the fringe benefits of attending the World Series for past or present members of the baseball fraternity is the matchless opportunity that the postgame get-togethers offer for cutting up touches and swapping lies with old friends. During the recent resurrection extravaganza of the Pittsburgh Pirates, one such old friend encountered was Tommy Henrich, and this Yankee star of yesteryear is as delightful now as he always was.

Mrs. Serge Koussevitzky, widow of the former conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, who for years has devoted herself to helping other artists through the Koussevitzky Music Foundation, is proving to be an artist in her own right these days at the Hammond Museum in northern Westchester.
OTTAWA, Nov. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's foreignexchange reserves exceeded $5-billion for the first time at the end of October, the Finance Department reported today.

When David Rabe's "Sticks and Bones" opens Sunday in the Anspacher Theatre at Joseph Papp's Public Theater, it will be the first time that Mr. Papp's house has contained two plays by the same author. Mr. Rabe's first play, "The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel," is still running strong in the Public's Newman Theater.
Martin Feinstein has been named to the new post of executive director of performing arts of the John F. Kennedy Center in Washington.

The defeat of the $2.5-billion transportation bond issue yesterday marks the beginning of a new round of city-state negotiations to determine, by Jan. 1, what fare increases, if any, will be put into effect.
OTTAWA, Nov. 2 -- Protests against the United States nuclear test on Amchitka Island are spreading across Canada.
As Freud once observed, nearly everybody has a pet ritual in preparing for a night's snooze.
BLUE POINT, L. I., Nov. 2 -John V. N. Klein tonight was elected Suffolk's first Republican County Executive as Republicans swept most of the County Legislature and the major town offices.

Drinking was light but steady here yesterday, and indications were that when all the opinions were counted--samplings were still being taken well into this morning--the state legislative decision permitting taverns to operate on Election Day will have been overwhelmingly approved.

If reason and logic were the guiding elements in Congress, the Administration's bill to offer financial help for school desegregation should have gone through without difficulty. The purpose of the bill, which would make available $1.5 billion over a two-year period, is to reduce problems that may arise in implementing desegregation. Entirely aside from the arguments over desegregation, the extra funds would be of great advantage to any district entitled to use them.
DETROIT, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -United States auto output could exceed 8.55 million units this year, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today the suspension of the broker-dealer registration of J. W. Sparks Co., New York, for six months beginning Nov. 8 on charges that the brokerage house had failed to make and keep accurate records.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 2 -- West Pakistani employes of Pakistan's diplomatic mission here beat Bengali employes with sticks and iron bars today as they were trying to leave the mission and join the East Pakistani independence movement.
OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Superior Court Judge Lyle Cook rejected today a ruling by the judges in Huey P. Newton's two previous trials on manslaughter charges.
The world has become, in the seven years since "Fiddler on the Roof" first appeared, richly populated with Tevyes. So far there have been Tevyes in at least 17 languages.

A rabbi who heads the Jewish Activist Movement, a newly formed group said yesterday that the files and correspondence at the group's headquarters in Brooklyn had been stolen. He added that he believed the burglary might have been the work of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

HONG KONG, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- China and Peru established diplomatic relations today, the Peking radio announced. It said the Peruvian Government had recognized the Government of the People's Republic of China as the sole legal Chinese Government.

MANCHESTER, Ky., Nov. 2 (AP) -- A Republican election judge was shot to death today in an altercation at the Goose Rock voting precinct south of here, and hours later murder warrants were issued for two men.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -In the year ended Sept. 30, unions settled for pay increases averaging onefifth less than they did in the same period a year earlier, the Labor Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Experiments at a marine laboratory in Florida suggest that dolphins can be trained to attack sharks that are threatening naval personnel engaged in salvage or rescue work at sea, according to the Office of Naval Research.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Britain's two major airlines were virtually at a standstill today, the second day of an unofficial strike by ground personnel at Heathrow Airport.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov 3 (AP) -- An American Navy jet that was bombing the enemy's supply trail in Laos was reported to have darted over neighboring North Vietnam yesterday to attack an antiaircraft battery that had fired two missiles at it
Minimum basic charges for residential telephones remained unchanged here for 13 years from 1957 until last year, the New York Telephone Company said last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The White House acknowledged today that President Nixon had talked with Lewis F. Powell Jr. several days before announcing his nomination to the Supreme Court. But a spokesman said that Mr. Powell was not asked specifically to accept the nomination until the day Mr. Nixon announced it.

Democrats swept close to control of the New Jersey Assembly yesterday, with uncounted paper and absentee ballots -- and the unexpected election of a white militant independent in Newark -- clouding the outcome early this morning.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Two communications satellites were thrust into earth orbit by an Air Force rocket tonight on a mission to link the Pentagon with America's far-flung military installations.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 2 (UPI] -- Dr. Norman E. Borlaug, a Nobel Prize winner, said today that he opposed legislation to ban the use of DDT, insecticides, weed killers and chemical fertilizers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A bill designed to qualify as many as 45 million more voters in 1972 by simplifying registration procedures was approved today by the Senate Post Office Committee, 6 to 3.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 AP) -- New construction activity declined slightly in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $111.9-billion, the commerce Department reported today. It was the first downtown since January.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 2 -- Under heavy diplomatic and military pressure, India seems to be toughening her policy toward Pakistan and toward what she considers a lack of understanding by Western nations -- particularly the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today it had opened a dumping investigation into imports from Japan of deflection yokes, components used in television sets. Treasury said $1.25-million worth of the yokes entered the country in the first half of this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A guideline limiting increases in corporation dividends to 4 per cent was announced today by the committee regulating interest and dividends in the second phase of President Nixon's economic stabilization program.
HARTFORD, Nov. 2 -- The Democratic party registered a net gain in Connecticut of 10 towns and cities tonight in municipal elections across the state, according to unofficial returns.

The continuing racial polarization of many major American cities was reflected yesterday in the victories of conservative mayoral candidates in Cleveland and Philadelphia -- a repetition of the pattern set in 1967 and 1969.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- A group of Congressmen plans to introduce a bipartisan resolution tomorrow urging the Government to exempt all Canadian exports to the United States from the 10 per cent surcharge imposed by President Nixon's new economic policy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Vice President Agnew has been accused of almost everything except a lack of saying right out what he thinks, and one of the attractive aspects of this compulsive candor is that he applies it to himself.
September sales of leading chain store and catalogue organizations, as compiled by The New York Times, showed an increase of 11 per cent above the level of sales in the year before.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -The Selective Service System announced today the first major overhaul of draft regulations in four years.

HOUSTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Houston Rockets center, Elvin Hayes, missed practice today, subjecting himself to an automatic fine and a probable demotion from the starting lineup against the New York Knicks here tomorrow night.
OTTAWA, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- President Tito of Yugoslavia arrived in Ottawa tonight amid intense military and police security precautions at the start of an official six-day visit to Canada.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 2 -Westchester County District Attorney Carl A. Vergari and Mayor Alfred B. Del Bello won re-election today in the two major elections in the county.

Music for violin and cello is rare enough. A program of nothing but such music is rarer still. Yet this is what Carol Sindell and Daniel Domb elected to present in Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night. They brought so much youthful zest to their playing, making the auditorium vibrant with their performances, that what could have been monotonous and dull became rich and vital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -The Senate Finance Committee rejected today the Nixon Administration's plan to provide a tax incentive for increased exports. The action left open the possibility that the committee might approve a less costly version that has been passed by the House.

ANCHORAGE, Nov. 2 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it could not hold its Cannikin nuclear test on Amchitka Island before Saturday because of delays in filling the 6,000-foot hole in which the bomb is buried.

DPF, Inc., formerly Data Processing Financial General Corporation, announced yesterday the election of Bertram J. Cohn as chairman. Mr. Cohn, a director of the company, is president of Morgan County Metals Corporation. Harold M. Wit, executive vice president of Allen Co., Inc.; and Arthur B. Kramer, a partner in the law firm of Nickerson, Kramer, Lowenstein, Nessen Kamin, were elected directors.

Dr. Paul Jordan, the reform candidate, was elected Mayor of Jersey City yesterday, breaking nearly half a century of political domination over City Hall by the scandalridden, old-line Hudson County Democratic organization.
The Police Department, noting that street Crimes -- muggings, purse snatching and robberies -- are increasing, announced yesterday the formation of a citywide robbery division to "clean up the city."

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- For 32 years, the United States Public Health Service ran a drug-treatment hospital here like a prison, with guards and iron bars. The facility had a recommitment rate of 90 per cent.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The Angela Davis trial was ordered transferred today from the Marin County Civic Center here to San Jose, 50 miles south.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The writings of William H. Rehnquist, encased in two thick binders and lodged by him last weekend with the Senate Judiciary Committee, show that President Nixon's nominee to the Supreme Court is an unvarying conservative who believes that Justices invariably write their own views into the Constitution.

PARIS -- Many signs indicate that the political power and diplomatic policy of Premier Chou En-lai are on the rise in China and that the forthcoming visit of President Nixon is directly linked to this.

The United States Trust Company, one of the nation's largest trust institutions with close to $10-billion in assets under its management, has decided to step up its purchases of common stocks in the current market decline.

Playboy Enterprises, Inc., which in 18 years has built Playboy magazine into a $130million-a-year publishing, hotel and key club empire, will find out today how much interest the public has in its common stock.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 2 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans will visit the Soviet Union later this month for highlevel talks on ways to enlarge Soviet-American trade, the White House announced today.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 2 -- Prof. Dennis Gabor, a Hungarian-born scientist, was named today the winner of the 1971 Nobel Prize for Physics for his work in three-dimensional photography. Prof. Gerhard Herzberg, a German-born Canadian, won the Nobel Prize for Chemistry for his research in the structure of the molecule.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- Ralph J. Perk, who concentrated his campaign in white ethnic neighborhoods, swept the Republican party into Cleveland's City Hall tonight, for the first time in 30 years, with a stunning victory in the mayoral election.

The Michigan Bank in Detroit, which two weeks ago joined the First National City Bank and the Irving Trust Company in setting a "floating" prime rate, announced yesterday the details of its new low-pricing plan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Congressional investigators today reported that there were an estimated 130,000 alcoholics in the armed forces but said that the Pentagon had done little to treat them, preferring punishment instead.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2 -- A Federal immigration official ruled today that the 22 Cubans who landed here last week to attend an international sugar conference were "excludable and deportable from the United States" because they did not have visas.

It has long been common knowledge that when T. S. Eliot finished the first draft of "The Waste Land," he gave it to Ezra Pound to read and Pound persuaded him to discard at least half of it. Puzzling over this, I once asked Milton Klonsky, a poet who is a friend of mine, what he supposed Pound had cut away.

New Yorkers, weary of strike harassment by militant municipal unions, may soon get a badly needed arbitration shield against more such disruption of public services. City Council leaders predict early passage of the bill proposed by Mayor Lindsay eighteen months ago for binding arbitration of municipal labor disputes not settled at the negotiating table.
The bond market -- partly closed yesterday for Election Day -- continued to move determinedly toward higher prices and lower interest rates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -Three key members of Congress warned the securities industry today that if it did not take steps to make its services less costly to investors Congress would step in and do the job itself.

A wage increase of 30 per cent for 37,500 subway and bus employes, a four-day, 32-hour work week and increased fringe benefits are among the major demands in a new two-year contract proposal that the Transport Workers Union has approved.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 2 -William L. Waller, the white Democratic nominee, decisively defeated Charles Evers, the black independent challenger, in the Mississippi election for Governor today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The Justice Department moved today to halt the merger of five Atlanta area banks into two subsidiaries of the Citizens and Southern National Bank, the largest banking organization in Georgia.

The 64-year-old C.I.T. Financial Corporation tomorrow embarks on its first corporate advertising program.

The $2.5-billion transportation bond issue was resoundingly rejected by the state voters yesterday.
A Federal Court judge in Brooklyn yesterday rejected the Carey Transportation Company's application for a temporary restraining order against its bus drivers who are staging a work stoppage.

ATHENS, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -The Reynolds Metals Company submitted a proposal to the Greek Government for the establishment of a $100-million alumina plant in Greece, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Economy said today.

BUFFALO, Nov. 2 -Edward V. Regan, the Republican-Conservative candidate, defeated Mayor Frank A. Sedita of Buffalo, the Democrat-Liberal, in today's contest for Erie County Executive.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Anthony Barber, said today that there were signs that the British economy was now expanding at the rate of at least 4 to 4 1/2 per cent -- a rate twice as fast as the average for the last six years.

MANILA, Nov. 2 -- A gunman who held a 14-year-old American girl hostage for almost 10 hours yesterday while he arranged his escape from the police was reported captured this afternoon in Botolan, Zambales Province, not far from United States' Subic naval base.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy today accused the Blue Cross Association of starting a clandestine lobbying campaign, paid for by the premiums of subscribers, aimed at assuring the group a place in any national health insurance program that might be passed by Congress.

Willis Reed will fly to Los Angeles later this week, but not necessarily to rejoin the Knicks. While the Knicks are in Los Angeles to meet the Lakers in the third game of their four-game road trip, their captain and chief hope for a playoff berth, will have his troublesome knee examined by Dr. Robert W. Kerlan.

GOTEMBA, Japan -- The Japanese Ground Self-Defense Force has developed what is said to be the world's first tank that can change its silhouette, a type of tank many countries want and which was not expected to be developed before 1975.
Danny Kaye, the entertainer, has this to say about the United Service Organizations: "To a lonely serviceman, thousands of miles from home the arrival of a U.S.O. show is a most precious gift.

The new musical "The Grass Harp," which opened last night at the Martin Beck Theater, is unpretentious -- understandably unpretentious. It is based on the novel and play by Truman Capote that were both folsky and fey.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 2 -- The Presidents of four African countries arrived tonight to start a new peacemaking mission that the Israeli Government hopes will modify the pro-Egyptian positions previously adopted by the Organization of African Unity.
MINEOLA, L. I., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Republicans continued to demonstrate their control of Nassau County by winning almost all the contests in yesterday's elections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Israel has confronted the United States with a negotiating dilemma by her refusal to participate in indirect talks with Egypt until Washington resumes shipments of Phantom fighter-bombers, American officials said today.

Operations of Revlon, Inc., in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30 resulted in record sales and earnings, according to the report yesterday by the maker of cosmetic, fragrance and ethical products.

The Columbia Gas System, Inc., reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the nine months ended Sept. 30. Revenues were $681,832,000, against $606,218,000 a year earlier. Net income rose to $65,414,000, or $2.11 a share, from $64,675,000, or $2.09 a share.

Two injury reports and one statistic were of interest to New York Giants' followers yesterday. The reports concerned Charlie Evans, the recently discovered rookie fullback, and Bob Tucker, the chess-playing tight end.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 2 (AP) -- An emergency situation was declared today with the Mariner 9 spacecraft but was lifted five hours later. Officials decided the craft was again operating normally and on course for its rendezvous with Mars.

The other day on Jamaica Avenue in Queens, N. Y., David Johnson was killed by four shots through the head. The police disarmed and handcuffed his assailant, but then let him go. Be ing some kind of detective, he had a license for the gun, and the victim had just robbed his store.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A Senate subcommittee, concluding a three-year investigation of financial corruption in the military, filed a stern indictment today of servicemen, Pentagon administrators and big business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- President Nixon has approved the Army's recommendation for promotion of Lieut. Col. Anthony E. Herbert, whom the Army sought to oust after he charged two fellow officers with covering up alleged attrocities committed by American servicemen in Vietnam.

Sometime between Saturday morning and early next week at the bottom of a huge hole more than a mile below the surface of the barren Aleutian island of Amchitka, the United States will be setting off an explosion of unimaginable power.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--The Senate approved today, 86 to 0, a strict, far-reaching water pollution control bill designed to stop all pollution of the waterways by 1985.

A Federally funded, four-year study of public school financing has found that "great inequities exist" in the amount of funds raised and spent in the school districts of nearly every state and result in "unequal" educational opportunities.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- Mayor Kevin H. White, showing solid citywide support that cut across racial, ethnic and economic lines, easily won a second four-year term in office tonight. Mayor White, who lost his city's vote in a bid for the governorship a year ago, jumped to an early lead and was never seriously threatened by Representative Louise Day Hicks, his only opponent.
The pro football season has reached the halfway mark with four apparent two-team races and two others involving three clubs. This means there are 11 likely contenders for the eight playoff berths.
MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- Gerhard Herzberg, the Canadian winner of the Nobel Prize for Chemistry, said today that he was "very surprised and very honored and very happy" at the award.

The United States Equestrian Team, which dominated the National Horse Show by taking six championships in a row until dethroned by West Germany last year, came roaring back last night to show that it still was a power in equine circles as the National opened an eight-day run at Madison Square Garden.

Jackie Stewart has walked out on the L Lola team in the Can-Am series to join, if other pieces of a jigsaw puzzle can be put together, the Gulf-McLaren team. For the McLaren crew, which has just won its fifth consecutive Can-Am championship, signing the two-time world driv ing champion is a case of the rich getting richer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Nationalist Chinese Government withdrew the entire $59.9-million it had available on deposit at the International Monetary Fund before the vote expelling Taiwan from the United Nations, a Monetary Fund spokesman confirmed tonight.

The city Commissioner who was called a "damn fool" and a "nut" by Mayor Lindsay for opposing the transportation bond issue, said yesterday that he hoped both supporters and opponents of the issue would now unite and work together for a new bond issue devoted solely to mass transportation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Tariff Commission, with the full membership voting for the first time in an anti-dumping case, split 3-3 today on the question of whether low-price imports of sheet glass from France, West Germany and Italy were causing injury to the domestic industry.
TOKYO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Jim Palmer hurled a three-hitter and Brooks Robinson and Elrod Hendricks hit home runs as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Japan All-Stars, 7-0, today before 45,000 fans.

The Federal Communications Commission has informed the Congress of its intention to adopt long-term regulations for television during November. The proposed regulations omit a critical safeguard to the public interest which the American Civil Liberties Union, Americans for Democratic Action and the City Club of New York regard as most vital.

BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- The election returns yesterday said little about the mood of California, New York or Illinois. They said little about trends in the farm belt. They said little about the public reaction to President Nixon's new economic policy or his overtures to China or his Supreme Court nominees.
Several hundred high school students held a rally on the Central Park Mall in the rain yesterday in preparation for Saturday's March Against the War.
WARSAW, Nov. 3 -- The United States and Poland agreed today to a five-year program of research and development in the field of transportation.
A Manhattan Criminal Court judge criticized the state's gambling laws yesterday and urged, in effect, that "such activities" as gambling and bookmaking be legalized.

N.E.T.'s "This Week' now has several editions to its credit as one of the more ambitious additions to this season's Public Broadcasting Service schedule. As a laudable attempt to put topical news stories in broader perspective, it misses. But it comes close and seems to be coming closer, enough at least to merit attention.
Long before the current upsurge of interest in things Chinese, a few people here were deep into an exercise called Tai Chi Chuan (pronounced Tie Jee Chwan). It's usually called simply Tai Chi.
The Board of Education is looking into the possibility of charging local school districts for state aid lost by the city because of their unauthorized school closings.

Carlo Gambino, who was formally told on Monday that he would be deported from the United States tomorrow, was reported to have suffered a heart attack yesterday morning and was taken to Victory Memorial Hospital in Brooklyn.
MONTREAL, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Jacques Lemaire scored once and set up two other goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens spoiled the coaching debut of Bill McCreary by defeating his St. Louis Blues, 5-1.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., Nov. 3 -- There was this state fair in Greensboro, N. C., last month, and Gary Wichard wandered over to a booth with rubber tires dangling in the background.
DETROIT, Nov. 3 -- Gov. William G. Milliken announced tonight that Michigan would appeal a Federal court ruling that could lead to cross-busing among white suburban and black city school children.
The city's plan to buy and renovate Yankee Stadium was advanced by the City Planning Commission yesterday in an unscheduled vote at City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Senate Finance Committee decided today to divert permanently to the Highway Trust Fund some of the money raised by alcohol taxes.

For the first time since over-the-counter volume figures became available on Monday, the stocks of two companies that are listed on the New York Stock Exchange but are also traded in the third market, were among the 10 most actively traded issues yesterday in the counter market.

Fresh Alibhai spurted in the final few strides to take the $34,950 Knickbocker Handicap over a soupy course at Aqueduct yesterday. Johnny Ruane, keeping his mount just off the pace through the running of the 1 5/8-mile turf event, guided Joseph Nash's representative to success by a nose over Specious of the Elmendorf Farms.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Senate passed by an 89-to-4 vote today legislation to require manufacturers to build automobiles that are less susceptible to costly damage in crashes and easier to repair than current models.

Carol Hofmann of Elmont, L. I., one of the leading riders in the world and a member of the United States Equestrian Team gave a sensational performance at the National Horse Show last night as she took the international class event.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its proposed new commission schedule had been approved by its membership. The vote on amendments to the exchange constitution was 773 to 98.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- New York State's experimental plan for requiring welafre mothers to work for their benefits at public service jobs "looks like it can be put together," a high Administration official said tonight.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3 (AP) -- H. John Heinz 3d, 33-year-old scion of the H.J. Heinz food family, has won Pennsylvania's 18th Congressional District seat by a landslide.
In his recent Op-Ed column entitled "The Nonwar War," Herbert Mitgang stated that the President has succeeded, not in winding down the war but merely the opposition to it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A civil rights organization charged in Congressional testimony today that the Lindsay administration had flagrantly violated its own commitment to disperse low-income housing throughout New York City.
ATLANTA, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- The Chicago Bulls, taking advantage of 13 fouls in the third quarter, broke open a close game tonight and beat Atlanta, 113-100, in the National Basketball Association.

Whether you are a student of botany, an accomplished woodsman or a backyard naturalist, the three-volume paperback edition of Britton and Brown's monumental "An Illustrated Flora of the Northern United States and Canada" (Dover Publications, Inc., $5 a volume) will provide a lifetime of enjoyment.

The entire staff of 14 attendance teachers who check on truancy is being laid off by the Community School District 2 in Manhattan despite a warning from the central Bureau of Attendance that such action is illegal.

Jaeger seems to have chosen the right time to open a shop in New York. The current craze in fashion is for such classics as sweaters, tweeds and blazers -- and that's exactly what Jaeger specializes in.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 3 -- Mayor Alfred B. Del Bello's 8,200-vote re-election victory in Yonkers yesterday gives him clear title, for the first time, as one of the most important Democratic figures in Westchester County.

The overwhelming defeat of the proposed $2.5-billion transportation bond issue leaves the State of New York confronting a budgetary crisis of major proportions. Existing taxes have failed to produce as much revenue as expected. Some $300 million in anticipated revenues from the bond issue were unwisely included in Governor Rockefeller's budget in the expectation that the proposition would be approved by the voters.
TORONTO, Nov. 3 -- From Halifax to Vancouver, tens of thousands of Canadians expressed their opposition today to the Amchitka test.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- An extensive court-ordered busing program to desegregate this city's schools got under way this fall, and at their first opportunity -- yesterday's elections -- San Franciscans showed they didn't like it.

RICHMOND, Nov, 3 (AP) -- Henry E. Howell Jr., an independent, was a decisive winner in the three-way race for Virginia's lieutenant governorship, defeating George J. Kostel, Democrat, by about 32,000 votes and completely running away from George R. Shafran, a Republican.
The Congressmen and generals who protect us here in the United States from our foreign enemies are having great difficulty these days because nobody can agree who our foreign enemies are.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers has ruled that United States passports will be denied those American who refuse to take an oath of allegiance to the Constitution. A department spokesman said today that Mr. Rogers had made the decision in a memorandum to the Passport office after he had been compelled by a Federal judge to decide whether to retain the oath or waive it.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 3 -- In an attempt to head off a threatened strike by policemen, Prime Minister Brian Faulkner today ordered that members of the 1,000 - strong Royal Ulster Constabulary Reserve be armed and that army guards be posted at police stations.

The most cosmopolitan bridge game in town this week was played at the Hotel Edison Monday night. The occasion was a visit to New York by a group of players from Rome, the Club Amici Dei Bridge, and they played in a duplicate game with New York enthusiasts.
State officials began yesterday an urgent survey of highway construction to see what projects should be halted because the voters rejected the $2.5-billion bond issue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The nomination of Howard P. Mace, former State Department personnel chief, as Ambassador to Eierra Leone was "passed over" by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee at a closed session yesterday.

PEKING, Nov. 3 -- China set a theme tonight for her participation at the United Nations by affirming that she would "stand together with all the countries and peoples that love peace." But she left no doubt that she remains committed to world revolution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Prime Minister William McMahon of Australia said today that he had been assured by President Nixon and Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird that the United States would provide a "counterbalancing force" to the growing Soviet naval power in the Indian Ocean.
HARTFORD, Nov. 3 -- Although Democratic gains exceeded those of Republicans in municipal elections yesterday in Connecticut, veteran politicians said they could see no clear trends in the results.
Robert N. Rickles, the only Lindsay administrative official on the winning side of the transportation bond issue vote, sat alone and unusually quiet in his office yesterday morning.

PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Horton S. Semple of Sewickley, Pa., held a one-stroke lead after a second-round 80 today in the North and South women's seniors golf tournament at the Pinehurst Country Club.
Somewhat in the manner of two conquering Hannibals, Pennsylvania's Senators, Hugh Scott and Richard S. Schweiker, collected on a World Series bet by riding past the Capitol on the backs of elephants.
YONKERS, Nov. 3 -- The sale of Yonkers Raceway to a Pennsylvania family was delayed today. It was said that details remained to be ironed out.
JAMBU, India, Nov. 3 -- "It has been five days since we have had anything to eat," an old man, Bhaga Bathbarman, said to a Government visitor here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The United Nations has often been called wordy and inefficient, but after this week it can hardly be accused of being insensitive about the accusation.

The transportation bond issue failed at the polls. Representative Edward Koch says 27 major companies are planning to move their headquarters out of Manhattan. Mayor Lindsay seeks a Canadian League football franchise to help push the purchase plan of the Yankee Stadium through a reluctant City Council. The $200-million sports complex for the Jersey Meadowlands faces several hurdles inside and outside the courts.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- With his impressive re-election victory yesterday, Mayor Joseph L. Alioto achieved what he wanted most -- a vote of confidence.

ATLANTA, Nov. 3 -- The United States Army instructed Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert today to refrain from speaking with members of the news media without specific permission from his commanding officers.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Nov. 3 -- The Atomic Energy Commission began its second series of hearings today into the Long Island Lighting Company's controversial proposal to build a nuclear-power plant on Long Island Sound at Shoreham.

In the scattered elections around the country Tuesday, voters tended to turn away from one-issue candidates and opt for experience or personal strength, regardless of party label or ideological commitment.
As a linebacker and a player representative, Larry Grantham of the Jets is caught between the devil and the deep blue grass.

An incapacitated 74-year-old widow living in a hovel-like basement apartment in the Morrisania section of the South Bronx recently was given a bath for the first time in months and had the knots cut and combed out of her silky gray hair.
A transmitter hidden in a shoe was used to tape conversations that helped indict three former state troopers and seven members of a gambling ring, it was disclosed yesterday in Federal Court here.

Joe Paterno, believing togetherness is strength, has devised the most powerful front unit in his six years as head coach at Penn State. He converted a substitute quarterback, Bob Parsons, and a good offensive tackle, Bob Rickenbach, to tight ends, placed them at opposite ends of the line and compressed the unit to eliminate the wide split end.

KISHINEV, U.S.S.R., Oct. 28 -- "If you could put the whole population of the world at one long table, every person would have a bottle of Moldavian wine," Zhenia Ruvner, a round-faced, red-haired Intourist guide boasted happily.

The New England Telephone Company announced yesterday that Allen G. Barry has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company unit. Mr. Barry has served as president since 1963. The utility also announced that William C. Mercer, vice president-personnel of A. T. T., was elected president, chief operations officer and director of the company.
The chairman of the State Public Service Commission warned yesterday of a potential shortage of electricity this winter in the face of expected peak demand in New York City and Westchester County.

With their usual adaptability, the politicians who unanimously supported the transportation bond issue in Tuesday's election were just as united yesterday in deciding why the voters did not agree with them.

The Administration's request that dividend increases next year be held to no more than 4 per cent met yesterday with general, if unenthusiastic, approval from a number of bankers, brokers and economists.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 3 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird arrived here tonight and voiced confidence that Congress would restore the foreign aid program because "this is a time to show strength, not weakness."

A management strategy of using the courts to reopen Atlantic and Gulf ports closed by a dockworkers' job action continued yesterday as stevedore representatives and the International Longshoremen's Association held their first formal meeting since Oct. 1, when the walkout began.

ROME, Nov. 3 -- Shortly after 9 o'clock every weekday morning a dozen people from almost as many countries gathered around a square red table in a fourth-floor room near the Piazza Navona here for an hour of intrigue.

In the Paris of the Roaring Twenties, when Russian emigres drove taxicabs or worked as seamstresses amid a frenzied artistic and literary life, one of the celebrated romances that sprang from the emigre colony was that of Igor Stravinsky and Vera de Bosset, a costume designer for Stravinsky's friend and patron, Sergei Diaghilev.
Millions of people today are building estates by buying either mutual funds or life insurance. Millions more would love to be able to buy both but find the cost too much of a financial strain.

A church-sponsored group that applied in 1968 for a municipal loan to rehabilitate two tenements on the Lower East Side has spent $110,000 of church money on the buildings while awaiting the loan, the group's head said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Representative Emanuel Celler asked the New York State Attorney General today to look into the possibility that brokerage firms are using their customers' money in ways that violate the laws regarding the responsibilities of fiduciaries.

The cause of the energy crisis that so many of your correspondents deplore is not conservation-limited supply but extravagant demand. There is no end to the argument that people must have as much energy as they want -- except the suicidal end (just now coming into view) that results not from having too little energy but from having too much.

The creation of a high-level public commission to study the breakup of the International Business Machines Corporation was urged yesterday by two top officers of the Memorex Corporation, a manufacturer of peripheral equipment for computers.

DUBLIN -- It seems to be the Karma of Ireland and England that the two countries must always misunderstand and torture each other. In microcosm the conflict and obfuscation may be seen in the pages of a small, highly confidential army manual now being "extensively revised" by the British authorities in Belfast.

HOUSTON, Nov. 3 -- Elvin Hayes and the New York Knickerbockers both came back tonight. Houston's all-star center apparently settled his differences with his club and maintained his perfect record of starting while the Knicks rebounded from a loss to Philadelphia, with an easy 117-98 victory over the hapless Rockets.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Nov. 3 -- The defeat of a County Charter amendment that would have been a major step toward preserving more than 1,000 miles of Suffolk County's shoreline was attributed to the transportation bond issue.
NORTHEAST HARBOR, Me. -- "You have the course from Guam to Manila. Now let's plot the route along the Chilean coast, bearing in mind that Magellan did much of the trip at night."

James M. Roche, board chairman of the General Motor Corporation, announced a new company policy yesterday under which employes who are alcoholics could be required to seek treatment or lose their jobs.

Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Powers, for the last half-dozen years, have been prominent figures around the dog show circuit. "Before that, we spent a good deal of our leisure time on the golf course," said Mrs. Powers.

Officials of "Yes" for Transportation in New York State, Inc. -- the bond issue proponents who received a ringing "no" from the voters on Tuesday -- denied yesterday that much as $3-million had been spent in their effort to stir popular approval.

The Western Electric Company announced yesterday that it has raised prices on some of its manufactured products. The action restores the prices to levels that existed before a series of reductions in December, 1970, and February and May, 1971.

Director Clint Eastwood's first movie is the story of a California disk jockey (Eastwood( who one night meets Evelyn (Jessica Walter), a good-looking devoted listener who has always called to ask that he play Erroll Garner's "Misty" for her, and begins what is to be a short-term casual affair without complications.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Marco Cervantes, a 17-year-old boy who moved from Mexico to live with his older brother and attend school in Chicago, died today of brain damage suffered in a high school football game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The manufacturing sector of the economy continued sluggish in September, new Commerce Department figures disclosed today.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday ordered a special grand jury investigation into the rebellion at the Attica Correctional Facility. Forty-three inmates and hostages died during and after the five-day prisoner revolt, which began last Sept. 9.
ROME, Nov. 3 -- Josyf Cardinal Slipyj and 15 bishops of the Ukrainian Catholic Church were reported today to have voted to form a "permanent synod" of five prelates to govern their church.

City and state budget experts agreed yesterday that the voters disapproval of the $2.5-billion transportation bond issue would mean retrenchments in state spending on aid to local governments and schools, political donnybrooks in the 1972 Legislature and a state program next year devoid of innovation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The nation's older citizens got a bit of advice today from a man who parlayed his first $105 Social Security check into a $2-million fortune.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers suggested to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the Nixon Administration might accept a ceiling on aid to Cambodia but otherwise refused any compromise with the Senate on a new foreign aid bill.
Two coin dealers were arrested here yesterday on charges of possessing 100 counterfeit $1 gold coins seized by Secret Service agents at the Jeweler's Exchange, 21 West 47th Street.

The first round of the women's candidates' matches to determine the next challenger for the world chess title held by Nona Gaprindashvili of the Soviet Union made it plain that the woman's championship would remain in Soviet hands.

The silver futures market here rallied in response to the sharp rise in the stock market yesterday. Fairly good trade support and speculative short covering also helped the silver futures.

The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it will televise live, starting in February, eight world championship professional tennis tournaments featuring many of the outstanding men players.

Listening to the cheers at Philharmonic Hall on Tuesday night when Magda Olivero came on stage for the first time, one would have htought she was one of the best-known singers in the world. A citywide coordination council representing major Jewish agencies is being set up to help indigent Jews form neighborhood groups and obtain anti-poverty money.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 3 -- The Lebanese, who have turned to the West until now for their purchases of arms, announced today the conclusion of their first arms deal with the Soviet Union.
DETROIT, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Earl Lloyd, who played in the National Basketball Association for 10 seasons, was given a two-year contract today to coach the Detroit Pistons.
National Airlines announced yesterday that it had arranged a new $175-million revolving credit agreement with a group of banks led by the Chemical Bank.

Stock prices rocketed higher yesterday in a sudden burst of optimism as the market posted its best recovery since the record-shattering Nixon Rally of Aug. 16. Leading glamour issues scored hefty gains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Pentagon categorically denied today a charge by the North Vietnamese Government that the United States Air Force had extended its bombings to include the northern province of Laichau, 160 miles northwest of Hanoi.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Newly enfranchised young voters upset the political establishment in a number of scattered communities in yesterday's off-year elections, but party leaders remained unsure about what their collective impact might be next year.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 -- The surprise victory of the Republican nominee, Ralph J. Perk, in the mayoral election here yesterday was symptomatic of a general collapse of Democratic organizations in Ohio's major cities.
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, which plans to expand its banking operations in New York statewide, announced yesterday its intention to form a new banking subsidiary in Syracuse.

ROME, Nov. 3 -- The world Synod of Bishops has reaffirmed the principle of celibacy for Roman Catholic priests but has rejected a conservative draft resolution that strongly discourages the ordination of married men in some situations.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 3 (Agence France-Presse) -- Emperor Haile Selassie announced land-reform measures today to speed Ethiopia's agricultural development and turn the country into the granary for the Middle East.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 3 -- Charles Evers, the black candidate defeated yesterday for Governor of Mississippi, led scores of other black candidates here today in announcing they would challenge the statewide elections in the Federal courts. Mr. Evers called for Federal troops to supervise new elections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Dr. John R. Hogness, president of the Institute of Medicine, is working to develop a program for American doctors to go to China to study not only traditional Chinese medical techniques like acupuncture and herb therapy but also developments in modern Chinese public health programs.

The Pelto Oil Company announced yesterday it proposes to acquire 55 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Empire State Oil Company, which is owned or controlled by Husky Oil, Ltd. Pelto is a subsidiary of Southdown, Inc.

Two guards were indicted by a Kings County grand jury yesterday on charges of beating to death a 37-year-old inmate of the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men. The jury absolved two other guards who had been suspended.

Ferguson Jenkins of the Chicago Cubs, a 20-game winner this year for the fifth season in a row, was named the outstanding pitcher in the National League yesterday by a wide margin over Tom Seaver of the New York Mets.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 3 -- Nassau County Republicans were jubilant today in the wake of yesterday's elections, in which they not only won almost all the contests but also wrested control of Long Beach from the Democrats for the first time in the history of the city.

A police sergeant on extended leave was appointed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as an aide in charge of special community problems. He succeeds Barry Gottehrer, who has resigned from the administration effective Nov. 19.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 3 -- A Government spokesman said today that Indian troops had "strict orders" not to cross the border in their confrontation with Pakistani troops.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Nov. 3 -- Despite the continuing threat of an Indian-Pakistani war in Kashmir and a series of mid-October border clashes that caused alarm and made people flee their homes, surprisingly little tension is noticeable in the villages along the Indian side of the 22-year-old ceasefire line in the Kashmir valley.

Two years after taking over the chief executive's slot at Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer, Inc., James T. Aubrey Jr., president of the giant film corporation, came to New York to talk about the next few years.
Two proposed amendments to the State Constitution that the Legislature had twice approved went down to defeat Tuesday with the $2.5-billion transportation bond issue.
Sears, Roebuck Co. and several other leading retail chains reported yesterday increased sales in October over the year-ago month.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Political squabbling over the Common Market issue continues at a shrill level in Britain. CAIRO, Nov. 3 -- Egypt appeared today to be moving toward the stage of decision-making in the conflict with Israel after many months of discussion, debate and weighing of alternative lines of policy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused the maker of Listerine mouthwash of falsely claiming that the product cured, prevented or lessened colds and sore throats.

A big, big advertiser increased sales for one of its products in two test markets using outdoor advertising instead of spot TV to support its network television advertising according to a study released yesterday by the Institute of Outdoor Advertising.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -- West Germany's basic balance of payments showed a provisional surplus of 809-million marks in September compared with an August surplus of 367-million marks and a September, 1970, surplus of 345-million marks, the nation's central bank said today.

AMCHITKA ISAND, Alaska, Nov. 8 -- The last of hundreds of small aftershocks from Cannikin occurred at 6:54 A.M. today, Eastern standard time, when the underground bomb cavity and rock "chimney" above it collapsed to form a small depression on the surface of the island as the gasses in the cavern cooled.

HONG KONG, Nov. 10 -- John Stewart Service, a specialist in Chinese affairs and former State Department officer, arrived here today after six weeks in China and a talk with Premier Chou En-lai, and predicted that Taiwan would be the toughest issue on the agenda when President Nixon meets Chinese officials in Peking next year.
Murry Bergtraum, a member of the Board of Education, suggested yesterday that the board "get out of the transportation business" and turn over school bus matters to an outside agency.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10 -- The secret police were reported today to have said that the Government was planning to put on trial soon a young Russian dissident, Vladimir A. Bukovsky, whose arrest and detention incommunicado since last March has become a minor cause celebre among Soviet dissidents and intellectuals concerned with human rights.

President Nixon committed a serious error in assigning certain administrative responsibilities under the new economic program to the Internal Revenue Service. This is another example of the loss of Congressional authority over taxation to the executive branch as to which Representative Charles A. Vanik (Republican, Ohio), a member of the Ways and Means Committee, expressed concern in recent testimony before the Senate Finance Committee.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 10 -- Dartmouth College has canceled varsity hockey games with Army, Colgate and New Hampshire because the three institutions will permit freshmen to compete on their varsity teams this season.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 10 -- Lebanon recognized Communist China today and announced that the two countries would establish diplomatic relations immediately and exchange ambassadors within three months.

The New York Stock Exchange is investigating recent trading in the shares of the General Motors Corporation and is considering disciplinary action against one or more member firms, including the specialist in the stock.

Mayor Lindsay and other public officials broke ground for a new Family and Criminal Courts Building in the Bronx yesterday. The building is one of several -- some have already been built -- in a $200-million project.

Gimbel Brothers' 10 department stores in the metropolitan area are engaged in an aggressive trading-up program aimed at raising profit ratios and at achieving "our more rightful share of the market," Paul A. Salomone, the new president of Gimbels New York, said yesterday.

The Ampex Corporation announced the election of Arthur H. Hausman as president and chief executive officer succeeding William E. Roberts who continues as chairman. Mr. Hausman, 47 years old, has been chief operating officer and executive vice president of the company. Mr. Roberts's decision to resign was prompted by a recent heart attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The intricate puzzle of cable television policy appears once again to be on the verge of falling or being hammered, into shape in industry meetings tonight and tomorrow.

PATTERSON, N. Y. -- George Lang is a Hungarian par excellence. Though he has worked in the United States as a chef and restaurant consultant since the end of World War II, and made a considerable reputation in the non-Magyar food world, his true obsession has been the cooking of his native land. And now after 15 years of research and testing, his extraordinary Hungarian cookbook is about to appear.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A 23-year-old woman who emigrated to Israel from the Soviet Union 20 months ago told a House subcommittee today that while Russian Jews may not live in concentration camps, "our spirit is in terror."

The possibility of a growing squeeze between supply and demand in the paper industry over the next three years was indicated yesterday in a report that projected a substantial slowdown in the expansion of productive capacity in the industry.

Way back before the Beatles, before Elvis Presley, before Frank Sinatra, before Benny Goodman, before Rudy Vallee, there were the Revelers. The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue a report this week.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 10 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba arrived in Chile today on his first trip to Latin America in 11 years and received an enthusiastic welcome in the streets of this capital. WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The nation's corn crop is estimated at a record-hurdling 5,551,769,000 bushels, 35 per cent more than last year and 3 per cent more than forecast in October, the Agriculture Department announced today.

They crowded into a small second-floor room at the Madison Hotel in the nation's capital to hear presentations by most of the major contenders for their party's nomination.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Johnny Green scored 22 points and pulled down 12 rebounds tonight as the Cincinnati Royals remained in first place in the Central Division of the National Basketball Association by defeating the Golden State Warriors, 110-101.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Three goals in the final period carried the Detroit Red Wings to a 6-3 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in the National Hockey League today.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 13 (AP) -- San Jose State's defense, led by Dave Chaney, set up two touchdowns and turned back numerous Stanford scoring threats today as the Spartans upset the Rose Bowlbound Indians, 13-12.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 13 -- The Democratic State Committee of Arkansas has adopted a loyalty oath designed to prevent supporters of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama from seeking delegate seats to the 1972 Democratic National Convention.

Few figures in the arts led quite so dreary a life as did Vincenzo Bellini. His career followed a steady, rising line from obscurity to acclaim. Whatever time he had left from his work as a composer was skillfully spent in the kind of machinations every artistic creator must conduct.

MODERN Irish painting is not a subject that looms very large -- except to the Irish perhaps -- in any serious consideration of 20th-century art. In Ireland, all the talent seems to have gone into literature and the theater or else (if abundant witnesses are to be believed) into sheer talk.

GARDEN CITY, L.I. -- Long Island's community-oriented television station takes a giant step Tuesday when it begins showing its first locally produced documentary, a 10-part series on the problems of pollution control and the environment, on Channel 21.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 13 -- The Nebraska Supreme Court has upheld a $325,000 verdict against the Ford Motor Company over an allegedly defective steering gear in a 1960 Falcon.

WASHINGTON -- The withdrawal of Fred Harris from the Democratic Presidential competition further clears the field for the coming primaries. The "clowns" at the talks, and in the entire Vietnam situation, have been the Americans themselves, tragic clowns.

WITH pessimism pervasive and no significant buying support on the scene, the stock market fell hard last week in a resumption of its autumnal slide. ALTHOUGH the evanescent "sakura" or cherry blossom of spring is the national flower of Japan, the "kiku" or regal and endurable chrysanthemum of autumn has long symbolized Imperial Japan. The chrysanthemum, with 16-ray flowers (or showy petals), is the Emperor's flower and has served as the crest of the Imperial Family for over a century.

Herman Wouk has written a long, mildly interesting, moderately informative novel about the beginnings of World War II, from the signing of the Soviet-Nazi act in August, 1939, to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center turned up a fine rarity in its concert in Tully Hall on Friday night. This was Moszkowski's Suite in G minor for two violins and piano. A delectable old-fashioned concoction, as sweet and elegantly put together as a piece of French pastry.

THE tremendous increase in home and apartment burglaries during recent years has caused more and more people to become interested in purchasing and installing security hardware -- door locks, night latches, window locks, entry alarms, door chains, locking bolts, etc -- and has led to a comparable increase in the introduction and general availability of products of this kind in local hardware and department stores.

Roger Hanks of Midland, Tex., conquered rough seas and 14 other ocean speedboat drivers yesterday to capture the Hennessy Key West offshore race, the last one on the list of world championship events.

After 90 days of frozen wages, prices and rents, Americans move this morning into Phase Two of President Nixon's attempt to stop the inflationary spiral -- a phase in which they will have to learn to live with governmental controls over pay checks, profit margins and most other aspects of economic activity.

Kuchel, a former Republican Senator from California, has been named to the five-member advisory commitee that will name major Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidates who will be eligibile for Secret Service protection.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A group of 700 elderly Negroes gathered here this week in an effort to focus national attention on their problems.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Top-ranked Nebraska regained its composure after a mild early scare and routed Kansas State, 44-17, today behind the superb passing of Jerry Tagge in the Cornhuskers' final tune-up for their Thanksgiving Day showdown game with second-ranked Oklahoma.

MIAMI, Nov. 13 -- South Florida horseplayers are a hardy breed. They have to be. Having struggled through a 129-day summer session at Calder Race Course, the players have exactly eight days respite before plunging back against the mutuel machines for 138-day winter session that opens at Tropical Park next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A report prepared for a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee states that morale at the United States Embassy in Athens is "very low" and that the staff is "distressed at the steady development of the military government."
