OTTAWA, Nov. 14 -- The unease that has afflicted Canadian life and politics since President Nixon's "disturbing" economic program was inaugurated three months ago, was aroused anew last week by the first snow of the year and the publication of a mixed report on inflation and unemployment.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the new president of Rutgers, the State University, will drive to Trenton tomorrow to address an extraordinary joint session of the New Jersey Legislature and shake rather than bite the hand that feeds the school.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Representative Shirley Chisholm told a women's political conference here today that she would carry her campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination to primary contests in North Carolina and Florida as well as several other states.

Stainless steel and other specialty steel manufacturers in the United States welcomed last week's Congressional action that appeared to pave the way for the eventual resumption of chrome ore imports from Rhodesia.

JACKSON, Miss. -- A number of black Mississippians are saying that violence, harassment, intimidation and theft caused 244 of 284 black candidates to lose in their attempts to win elective offices in this month's general elections.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 14 -- Len Dawson, the Kansas City quarterback, had the aching elbow of his passing arm soaking in a galvanized bucket again today after the Chiefs had beaten the Cleveland Browns, 13-7, in one of the less memorable contests of the season.

The hearings on one six-year term for the President provide little fuel for the fires of reform in the Presidency. The two-term limit, as expressed in the 22d Amendment, was intended to curb the so-called excesses of the Presidency, as Franklin Roosevelt's tormentors aver. However, the "reformers" found little solace when it was Eisenhower who was first subjected to its consequences.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- When the Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec Douglas-Home, left for Rhodesia today, an unmistakable figure boarded the Royal Air Force jet with him. It was Lord Goodman, whose considerable physical dimensions add emphasis to his remarkable role in British life.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 -- Soviet trade officials are expected to approach Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans later this month for American export credits to help finance American participation in a major truck factory here.
A group of dissidents in the New York City Taxi Drivers Union charged yesterday that supporters of Harry Van Arsdale Jr., the union's president, had conducted a dishonest election.

ATLANTA, Nov. 14 -- For sheer hard work and soul-satisfying result, the New York Giants will rarely surpass the 21-17 victory they scored today over the Atlanta Falcons on Fran Tarkenton's touchdown with 31 seconds to play.

Neil (Doc) Simon and Mike Nichols are together again with "The Prisoner of Second Avenue." Testifying to the fruitfulness of the collaboration, there are long lines outside the Eugene O'Neill Theater (Neil Simon, prop.), and loud laughter inside.
The Federal Government has caught a national magazine trying to raise its subscription price 27 per cent and has forced it to roll back the price.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The first deadline is next Friday for those who want to take advantage of bargain postal rates for mailing Christmas presents to servicemen overseas.
" It's a perfect marriage," the National Guard company commander said. "The city doesn't have the money to fix up the park, and my engineers need as much practical experience as possible."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Earl L. Butz, who has been nominated by President Nixon to be Secretary of Agriculture, said tonight that he had notified four corporations that he was resigning from their beards of directors.

Fined in the past for their outspoken comment, the Jets maintained official silence yesterday after viewing films of two controversial plays that affected the outcome of their game with the Baltimore Colts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The House passed today, by a vote of 350 to 5, a major cancer research bill that differs sharply from one passed earlier by the Senate with backing from the White House.

The National Broadcasting Company has expressed fear that the stability of radio and television is threatened by challenges from citizen groups and has proposed "reluctantly" that the Federal Government adopt a quantitative standard in renewing licenses to use the air.

Butler Aviation International, Inc., told its stockholders yesterday that a "monumental conflict of interest" is involved in a proxy battle for control of the company started by its former president and chairman, Paul S. Dopp.

UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 15 -- With the muted militance of a poem by Mao Tse-tung, one of Peking's supporters today acclaimed the long diplomatic march that ended as six-Chinese in Mao tunics quietly took their seats in the General Assembly's Great Hall.

NEWARK, Nov. 15 -- A Federal grand jury here today indicted a top French counterespionage official and a man described as one of his former aides on charges of conspiring to smuggle $12-million in heroin into this country in a Volkswagen camper.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- All the family was gathered around the blazing fireplace celebrating the end of Phase One (alias "The Freeze") and dreaming of the new consumption we would all enjoy now that Phase Two was upon us and "the freeze" had given way to "devil take the hindmost."

TOKYO, Nov. 15 -- A delegation of Japanese businessmen began discussions today with authorities in Peking in an intensifying effort to build the foundation for a long-term expansion of Japanese exports to China.

TRENTON, Nov. 15 -- Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the newly inaugurated 17th president of Rutgers, the state university, told a joint session of the New Jersey Legislature today it would have to increase appropriations if the university was to meet the sttae's educational needs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Kentucky Colonels, one of the most successful American Basketball Association teams, may go out of existence next season unless the league is permitted to merge with the National Basketball Association, a principal owner of the team predicted today.
Jason Robards, who has distingished himself as a stage and film actor for more than a decade, will play his first Broadway musical role this season.

The exhibition of "Two Hundred Years of North American Indian Art," which Norman Feder has organized at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is extraordinary in several respects. First and foremost, it brings us a great many unfamiliar objects of rare beauty.

Eleven days after a mysterious fire destroyed part of the electrical control system at The Consolidated Edison Company's new nuclear power plant at Indian Point, near Peekskill, workmen and inspectors yesterday were still scrubbing soot from the blackened walls and picking among the charred wires and dismantled components, trying to determine the extent of the damage.
Brenda Monk, a New Yorktrained soprano, and David Katz, a tenor who came here several years ago from his native London, shared a New York debut Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.
Prices again went mostly downward yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market in slower trading.

In announcing yesterday that Dr. H. Guyford Stever, the president of CarnegieMellon University, had been nominated as director of the National Science Foundation, the White House linked two names only vaguely familiar to the general public.

Following is the official transcript of the proceedings in Manhattan State Supreme Court in which Justice George Postel ordered the trial of Carmine J. Persico closed to the public and the press. Speakers in addition to Justice Postel are Maurice Edelbaum and Samuel A. Yasgur.
A New York Times survey of supermarkets and other stores in the metropolitan area showed prices moving up and down yesterday, as they have throughout the freeze -- with little discernible pattern.

A witness testified yesterday that an admitted briber had indicated that $100,000 for the quashing of stock-fraud indictments would be paid to Senator Hiram L. Fong and members of the Justice Department.

First place will be at stake in three "money" games for pro football on Sunday, with a second place -- not far from first -- involved in a fourth. In Washington, the Dallas Cowboys, with two straight victories behind them and a new resolve, take on the sagging, injured Redskins, who lead them by half a game in the Eastern Division of the National Conference.

Taxi Commissioner Michael J. Lazar said yesterday he would attempt to remove 4,400 "gypsy" taxicabs from the city's streets, but he made it clear he did not consider the bulk of the city's nonmedallioned drivers to be "gypsies."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Following is the text of the address delivered in the General Assembly today by the chief Chinese representative, after speeches by other delegates welcoming the Peking delegation to the United Nations.

Bess Myerson, who quit television to become tile city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, will return to TV with a syndicated five-day-a-week program, "What Every Woman Wants to Know." She will retain her city post.
There was a time when Gulf and Western Industries did a lot of juggling when it reported quarterly earnings.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The United States gross national product probably will rise 9 per cent next year to $1.14-trillion, Murray L. Weidenbaum, a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, predicted tonight.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 15 -- A political fight on national party lines is tearing apart the University of Chile, this country's principal institution of higher learning.
No one at Sotheby's or Parke-Bernet wanted to talk about the floating dollar, but the season's most important jewel auction is being held in Zurich and the bidding's being held in Swiss francs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Sponsors of a bill to relax regulation of certain gun ammunition abruptly abandoned plans for a House vote today.

Richard T. Davies, Deputy Assistant Secretary for European Affairs, may have intended with his testimony to a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee [news story Nov. 10] to take the sharp edges off Jewish protests in order to facilitate President Nixon's forthcoming discussions in Moscow.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Mrs. Madeleine Bittel Richards of Geneva and A. David Walker Jr. of Greenwich were married here this afternoon in the Round Hill Community Church by the Rev. Dr. Jesse E. Thomas.

New York City's mass transit system hurtles toward financial disaster as fare-box revenues fall farther and farther behind operating costs. Union negotiators are pressing for pay increases far in excess of Federal guide-posts. Even with a noninflationary settlement, prolonged neglect and accumulated deficits now require an estimated $440 million more in revenues over the next two years than the present thirty-cent fare will generate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- Alger B. Chapman Jr., a spokesman for the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, said today that a poll of members favored a network of independent, diverse, broker-dealers, with a quality sales force.

I would like to supplement the story in your edition of Nov. 10 on my testimony the previous day before Representative Rosenthal's subcommittee on Europe on "Denial of Rights to Soviet Jews." It seems to me that the following salient points from my statement would give your readers a fuller comprehension of what I said.

In announcing that he would not seek reappointment as president of the New York Stock Exchange, Robert W. Haack has forced Wall Street to decide whether it wants to set its own house in order or whether it wants the job to be done -- if it can be done -- from the outside.

BUFFALO -- The Studio Arena Theater, an exceptionally pleasant theater, incidentally, has built itself a reputation for producing new American plays. It was here, for instance, that Edward Albee's experimental "BoxMao-Box" started, and now the theater is giving a new play by Lawrence Roman called "Buying Out."

DETROIT, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Auto sales, spurred to a record end-of-October pace by the price freeze and the promised repeal of the Federal excise tax, slacked off in the first 10 days of November but were up from the comparable 1970 period, sales figures showed today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court acted today to protect railroad workers swept up in mergers by giving the Interstate Commerce Commission broad authority to look after them.

A United Nations General Assembly committee has voted overwhelmingly to censure actions in the United States Congress that would violate the sanctions imposed by the Security Council against the white racist regime in Rhodesia. Only the dimension of the vote -- 93 to 2 with 12 abstentions -- was a surprise. It was one of the most crushing defeats suffered by the United States in the 26-year history of the United Nations.

National Educational Television and Channel 13 here were the recipients yesterday of substantial grants for the production and presentation of special programs, helping to offset recent financial cutbacks by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

ATHENS, Nov. 15 -- A group of seven Greek intellectuals published a collection of political short stories, essays and poetry today voicing open opposition to all dictatorships, including the military-backed Government of their own country.
Bob Wheeler is still undecided between the 800 and 1,500 meter runs as his Olympic event for next summer's United States track and field trials.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Government proposed today a ban on the use of paint containing more than 1 per cent lead on residential structures constructed or rehabilitated with Federal funds.
Ten members of the Congressional Black Caucus visited 10 military bases across the country yesterday, looking into charges of racial discrimination in the armed forces.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A virus identified as herpes type 2 has been isolated from cells grown artificially from a specimen of human cervical cancer, scientists reported today.

Nearly a century after the passage of the first state civil service law in 1883, the spoils system is still flourishing in many parts of the country. Political patronage continues to dominate the allocation of hundreds of thousands of public jobs at every level, with the holders expected to contribute money as well as campaign effort to support the party in power.

When Lewis F. Powell was nominated to the Supreme Court many civil libertarians were satisfied. Not elated or even pleased. But satisfied. Despite his mixed record in Virginia on civil rights, he was apparently a conservative lawyer who, like Justice John M. Harlan, would bring learning and professional competence along with a high sense of purpose to his new office.

RENO, Nov. 15 -- The National Congress of American Indians opened its 28th annual convention today hoping to heal a critical rift between reservation Indians and urban Indians and exhibiting a mild disillusionment over "the Great White Father" in Washington.

Hugh Mulligan, the bookmaker who is a major figure in a grand jury investigation of police corruption here, suffered an apparent heart attack yesterday, minutes before he was scheduled to be sentenced to four years in prison.

While there are substantial differences of opinion as to whether medical care and general health services in America are as good as, or better than they are elsewhere in the world, there is general agreement that financing such care grows increasingly difficult for more and more millions of Americans.
The stock market greeted Phase Two of President Nixon's economic program yesterday by wobbling to another 1971 low. The initial phase had expired over the weekend.
EAST CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 15 -- Dick Brennan, an antique-gun enthusiast, has the distinction of having "enjoyed" his shortest hunting season in New Hampshire. It lasted 15 minutes.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest general-merchandise retailer, continued its strong performance of the second quarter with a third-quarter earnings gain of 18.1 per cent on a sales increase of 8.2 per cent.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 15 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi asked a hawkish Indian Parliament today to be patient over the military confrontation with Pakistan to see if Western leaders could persuade Pakistan to reach a settlement with the Bengali secessionists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A copy of the first specific regulations for Phase Two of the Administration's economic stabilization program is available from the Government Printing Office for 20 cents.

Faced wtih increasing pressure from both sides of the net, top officials of the United States Lawn Tennis Association huddled here yesterday to seek a formula that would preserve open tennis for next year.

The Arthur Lipper Corporation, a well-known institutional investment house, has decided to leave the brokerage business because of what it calls the "bleak future prospects" of the securities industry.

George Crumb writes personal, strange and yet deeply affecting music. Consider his "Black Angels," for amplified -- or, as he puts it, electric -string quartet. Dated 1970 and subtitled "Thirteen Images from the Dark Land," the grim but poetic work was given its first New York performance Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall by the Bowling Green String Quartet.
PARIS, Nov. 15 -- The United States Embassy put polite pressure on the French Government today to cooperate in the prosecution of the New Jersey heroinsmuggling case.
When Jack Egers returned from the hospital yesterday, where his wife had just given birth to a girl, he learned he was no longer a Ranger.

Chase Econometric Associates, an economic consulting arm of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, questioned yesterday the accuracy of the McGraw-Hill capital-spending survey, which is widely followed as an indicator of future business plans to acquire new plant and equipment.
LOUISVILLE. Ky., Nov. 15 -About 75 per cent of the nation's 100,000 soft-coal miners did not report today on the first day of work since the signing of a new contract last Saturday night.
Three government agencies are investigating possible wrongdoing in the awarding of a multimillion - dollar contract by the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation to the Computer Sciences Corporation.

Two unions representing 37,500 subway and bus employes began negotiations yesterday with the Transit Authority on new contracts to supplant those that expire Dec. 31, with Federal wage and price guidelines emerging as key factors in the talks.

Former President Lyndon B. Johnson, making his first public statement here since leaving the White House, warned yesterday that if the United States slipped into isolationism, "we are going to find out that we are the ones who are isolated."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A member of the Canadian Parliament and tile Canadian Wildlife Federation petitioned the United States District Court here to be allowed to intervene in a suit aimed at halting construction of the trans-Alaska oil pipeline.

A 35-year-old man sentenced to 50 years in prison in Louisiana for selling $5 worth of marijuana in 1967 will be freed from the Queens House of Detention today or tomorrow, according to a spokesman for Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Dr. Earl L. Butz of Purdue University, President Nixon's choice as the new Secretary of Agriculture, said today that he was prepared to defend his record against charges that he favored big business over farmers.

Opening a program with Bach's florid "Jauchzet Gott" takes a good deal of nerve, but Sandra Washington met the challenge unflinchingly in Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night. The six accompanying instrumentalists came to grief here and there, but Miss Washington's silvery soprano and precisely articulated coloratura never faltered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The deficit in the United States balance of international payments, measured by two of the four definitions now used, increased to a record level in the third quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Hal Laycoc, his bitterness barely concealed behind a kindly face and spectacles, lashed out yesterday at the structure of the National Hockey League that since 1967 has produced eight new teams -- hardly any of them competitive.

A player competing in his first tournament topped a field containing a galaxy of international stars in a major charity event played Saturday in Chicago. Fifty two players competed in an individual championship, a rarely played contest, and the Foundation for Hearing and Speech Rehabilitation benefited to the extent of some $20,000.
President Nixon's statement that "profits make jobs" is a succinct summary of the trickle-down theory, but the theory is upside down.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 15 -- Sir Alec Douglas-Home, the British Foreign Secretary, arrived in Rhodesia today and began what is expected to be a lengthy exploration of the chances for a settlement with this breakaway colony.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Nixon intervened personally with Congressional leaders today in an effort to rescue the foreign aid program in the face of the scheduled expiration of spending authority at midnight. Senate action was promised later in the week.

MANILA, Nov. 15 -- Foreign Secretary Carlos P. Romulo said today that the arrest of the Filipino diplomat Domingo S. Canieso in New York last week as a heroin smuggler was "another blot, a stain on our foreign service."

The state's Welfare Inspector General yesterday sharply criticized the city administration of the welfare program and said that frauds were made easier here by laxity and permissiveness on the part of Social Services Department personnel.

The Research Library of the Performing Arts of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center announced yesterday a series of five "Nine O'Clock Crisis Concerts" to raise funds to keep its arts research collections from closing after Jan. 1, 1972.

When the Boeing Company in Seattle got down to the line for deciding which of six competing ad agencies to select from, they apparently had a warm feeling for both Cole Weber, a local agency, and for Doyle Dane Bernbach.

The Union Pacific Railroad Company, the biggest money maker in the railroad business, had third-quarter operating revenues of $151,142,641, down from $175,794,786 in the corresponding period last year, the report disclosed yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 15 -- Housing experts in the government and private sector agreed today that production of shelter for American families next year would continue the surprising showing of 1971.

The Gulf Oil Corporation has announced executive changes affecting its Far East operations: W. W. Finley Jr. has been named president of the Gulf Oil Company-Asia, a new division that absorbs Gulf Oil Company-East Asia and Gulf Oil Company-South Asia. Mr. Finley, formerly vice president and coordinator of refining operations of the Gulf Oil Corporation, will continue to have headquarters in Pittsburgh.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 15 -- Preliminary data from the Mars-orbiting Mariner 9 provided scientists today with evidence that the planet's thin, storm-whipped atmosphere is apparently "thick with dust" of fairly coarse-grained, sand-like particles.
A bill to prohibit discrimination against homosexuals in employment and housing was reported yesterday to be in trouble in the City Council's 15-man Committee on General Welfare.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 15 -- The South Vietnamese Government began an intense effort this evening to enlist public support and to offset the expected public outcry against a rise in prices expected as a result of economic reforms announced early today.

Yet if a new law on this subject is to become effective in the 1972 political struggle -- already in its beginning stage -- then a responsible decision by the House is imperative.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Peking, making its formal entry into the United Nations, declared today that all member countries must handle the organization's affairs instead of allowing the superpowers "to manipulate and monopolize" them.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The United States command reported yesterday that two American helicopters had collided about 70 miles northwest of here, killing the four crewmen aboard one and injuring the four on the other.
Corporate and tax-exempt bond yields were increased yesterday, while rates on Treasury securities -- helped by Federal Reserve action -were pushed down a little.
Joe Torre, the National League's most valuable player, and the rest of the St. Louis Cardinals will open a 1972 Shea Stadium schedule of 79 dates on April 11, the New York Mets announced yesterday.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 15 -- The Israeli press has finally won a lifting of the ban on the personal strories of intelligence agents who participated in a mysterious sabotage mission inside Egypt in 1954.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The head of the organization of the congregations of American Conservative Judaism today assailed the "complete domination" or Orthodoxy in Israel over all religious matters, particularly those relating to marriage, divorce and conversion.

At last resigned to the loss of Willis Reed for an indefinite period, the Knicks will attempt to maintain the momentum of their last outing, a 127-105 rout of the Detroit Pistons, tonight at Madison Square Garden against the Phoenix Suns.
ROME, Nov. 15 -- President Franz Jonas arrived here today for the first visit to Italy by an Austrian head of state since 1875.

Armed with shotguns, 10 members of the Bronx District Attorney's squad seized seven men yesterday who were described by District Attorney Burton B. Roberts as suspects in the robbery of $1-million from about 100 supermarkets.

That seems to put him on top of two of the three big issues -- Mr. Nixon's personality is the other -- with which the Democrats might defeat him next year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled today that Capt. Susan Struck, the first Air Force officer in history to give birth while on active duty, can be discharged because of "a compelling public interest in not having pregnant female soldiers in the military establishment."

The final accounting of the 1970-71 appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund showed yesterday that a total of $1,055,877.91 was received from 14,988 donors.

After their dramatic upset of the Falcons in Atlanta on Fran Tarkenton's ad lib two-yard touchdown dash with 31 seconds to play, the Giants received news yesterday that brought them brusquely back to earth.

The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company announced yesterday their intention to sell six of 24 major realty parcels the railroad owns in the Grand Central Terminal area for a total of $59,548,462. Each of the sales is subject to approval of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Unanswered questions and unclarified regulations about wage and price controls created widespread confusion today, the first business day of Phase Two of President Nixon's economic stabilization program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -The Illinois Democratic Presidential primary, largely meaningless in recent years because of the power of Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago, may take on some significance next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church declared today that the right of parents to educate their children in nonpublic schools was threatened by a recent Supreme Court decision denying Government assistance for teachers' salaries in parochial schools.
LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP) -Two women in Hong Kong will become the first women priests in the Anglican Church, all official announcement said today.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15 -Westchester County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian urged enactment today of a 2 or 3 per cent county sales tax to balance a proposed $220-million budget that he said would otherwise require a 25 per cent increase in the county property tax rate for 1972.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Senate passed amendments to the tax bill today that would reimburse parents of students for part of the cost of higher education and would let many middle and upper-income working couples take tax deductions for some child-care expenses.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- Calling the Administration's new economic policy "heavy handed," Carl Albert, the Speaker of the House, declared today that the surcharge on imports "may blow up in our faces" and set off a trade war.

MOSCOW, Nov 15 -- The Soviet Union today backed up reported shipments of arms to India with an appeal to Pakistan to seek the restoration of good-neighborly relations with India "in the interest of international security."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia reversed today the Federal Communications Commission's decision that the Republican party should have fre television time to reply to a Democratic telecast that itself had been a response to President Nixon.

Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, said yesterday that as a result of a six-day visit to Japan he had switched back to relying on incinerators as a means of handling the city's garbage problem.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Government's Committee on Interest and Dividends issued refinements today in its general guideline permitting dividend increases next year of no more than 4 per cent.

The first two volumes of JeanPaul Sartre's "The Family Idiot: Gustave Flaubert From 1821 to 1857" will be published in translation here by Pantheon Books, Andre Schiffrin, its managing director, announced yesterday.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- A Roman Catholic girl who was tarred and had her head shorn because she had dated a British soldier married him today behind a shield of military secrecy.
The Chesapeake Ohio Railway, which laid off 1,800 employes during the seven-week coal strike that was settled on Sunday, yesterday omitted its dividend for the fourth quarter.

HAMBURG, West Germany, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The news magazine Der Spiegel says the Pentagon has suppressed a study by the Rand Corporation that concluded that high ideological motivation was behind Vietcong battlefield successes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The automobile industry and other major businesses lost today the right to raise prices during the remaining seven weeks of this year without the Government's prior approval.
SAN DIEGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -Dennis Partee kicked a 45-yard field goal as time ran out and the San Diego Chargers beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 20-17, tonight in a nationally televised game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) Senate-House conferees reached final agreement today on a $6-billion bill extending the antipoverty program two more years and containing a broad new child-care provision.

OTTAWA, Nov. 15 -- At last half of the premiers of Canada's 10 provinces vigorously oppose the proposal advanced this weekend that the Federal Government take steps to limit foreign investment in Canadian development.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 15 -- If an experiment that begins tomorrow evening is successful, the tape-recorded "screams" of killer whales may save some species of porpoise from extinction.

ROME, Nov. 16 -- A wellknown leader of American Roman Catholics was asked several days ago how he thought history would treat Pope Paul VI. He replied without hesitation. "He'll go down as a good Pope -- so as he quits next year."

Roesch, president and chief operating officer, has been elected to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1, 1972. He will succeed William J. Stephens, who is retiring from active service on Dec. 31 after reaching the mandatory retirement age of 65.

The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange announced plans yesterday for a far-reaching consolidation of their communications, clearing and automation facilities into a new, jointly owned subsidiary corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The nation's total output of goods and services -- the gross national product -- rose a little more in the third quarter than previously estimated, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Congress agreed today to extend spending authority for the foreign aid program to Dec. 8 to give time for an agreement on a regular authorization bill by both legislative branches.

Leonard Bernstein began a five-week session with the New York Philharmonic Thursday night at Philharmonic Hall, and his first program was a contribution to the survey of Liszt's music that is occupying much of the orchestra's time this season.

Much critical claptray has been written on minimal art. The catalogue introduction to the current exhibition of Robert Mangold, the minimalist artist, at the Guggenheim Museum is yet another bombastic example of this.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Senator Henry M. Jackson officially became a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President today, running on a platform of law and order and a rekindling of the New Deal.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (Reuters) -- The Administration's current estimate of the 1971 balance-of-trade deficit is that it will reach and possibly exceed $2-billion, Peter G. Peterson, assitant to the President for international economic affairs, told a news conference today.
Charles Greeves, in his cowboy hat, boots and beaded buckskin jacket, was one of the more flamboyant bidders at the auction of the Green collection of American Indian art at Parke-Bernet yesterday.
MOSCOW -- My wife and I are, I believe, the first Americans to make a personal visit to the Committee on Human Rights of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- While strip mining of coal in the United States continues to be embroiled in conservationist controversy, Soviet planners have laid out an ambitious plan to expand the coal industry on the basis of surface operations to meet mushrooming energy requirements.
The docks on Buttermilk Channel that mark the western boundary of South Brooklyn's Red Hook section have been silent now for 50 days.
Ask Rudy Anderson of Streator, Ill., what he thinks about Ross Perot's back-office brokerage management and he'll give you a wry Midwestern smile.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Government announced today that it was imposing price controls to curb rises that followed devaluation of the plaster.

The city's Department of Water Resources indicated yesterday that there had been no health hazard in rust-tinted tap water that generated hundreds of complaints by residents of the Flushing and College Point sections of Queens Thursday night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Depending on one's perspective in the foreign-policy debate, Congress is impotently marching up the hill and down again or is gradually encircling a once-powerful Presidency.

ROME, Nov. 10 -- The 19-year-old from Salt Lake City pushed the buzzer on the gate of a small villa in the Monte Sacro section of Rome. When the owner appeared on the second-floor balcony the youth anounced in halting Italian: "We are missionaries from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints and we'd like to talk to you."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Democratic and Republican Senators, at political swords points for three days over the financing of political campaigns, agreed tonight to take a final vote Monday on a proposal for public funding of the 1972 Presidential race.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The House of Representatives approved an Administration-backed measure today that would provide funds to keep Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe alive for at least two more years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to review a lower court decision that United States Steel is owed $250-million in tax refunds.

Sickle cell anemia, a hereditary disease that strikes hundreds of thousands of people -- black and white -- throughout the world, requires much more basic laboratory and human research before doctors can discover a cure for the blood disorder, experts concluded after a two-day symposium that ended here yesterday.

Despite the seemingly endless number of singers who turn up in New York's nightclubs, those who have a really distinctive talent are so rare that a listener who comes across such a singer can scarcely believe his ears.

City Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath, considered a penal "reformer" when he took office early in the Lindsay administration, leaves the city's penal system in a terribly overcrowded and largely unreformed state. Perhaps he did not fight fiercely enough for the funds necessary to carry out badly needed improvements, but in any event he was never given adequate resources in a city budget already strained to meet what doubtless seemed more urgent priorities.

In reading your recent editorial "Middle East Roulette" I was struck by the discrepancy between the editorial and your news story of Oct. 16. That story accurately reported that 78 Senators -- 44 Democrats and 34 Republicans -- joined in sponsoring a Senate resolution calling upon the United States to resume deliveries of Phantom F-4 aircraft to Israel.

WILMINGTON, N. C., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Jim Colbert chipped in twice, shot a six-under-par 65 and moved into a three-way tie today for the top spot in the second round of the $35,000 Azalea open golf tournament.
Madison Square Garden's first fling at auto racing produced smog, noise, little excitement and many angry drivers last night. Luckily for auto racing, only 4,500 fans turned out.

The English rock group Ten Years After has always sounded more like a soloist with accompaniment than a well-integrated musical unit. In their concert at Madison Square Garden Thursday night they moved a few more giant steps in that direction, with Alvin Lee, guitarist / singer, dominating the show.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 19 -- The small contingent of New York players attending the Fall National Championships, which began here this afternoon with the mixed pairs, were able to watch a pre - tournament exhibition match between the world champion Aces and an Arizona team.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- As Senator James L. Buckley was announcing last Tuesday that Secretary George W. Romney had promised to review plans for a controversial low-income housing project in Forest Hills, Queens, he appeared to be startled when asked if he had carried that area in last year's election.

God may be dead but it's reassuring to find out that the power of evil is alive and well in The Times. There he is, disguised this time as Kenneth B. Clark, offering to solve all our problems ("anxieties, tensions, hostilities") [Op-Ed Nov. 9] and it will only cost us our souls.

Yosef Yankelev, violinist, and his wife, Yvonne Figueroa, pianist, made their first joint New York appearance in a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night, presented by the Manhattan Chapter of the Brandeis University Women's Committee.
LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Julie Heldman of New York upset Evonne Goolagong of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, 6-0, 0-6, 6-1, today and gained the singles final of the Dewar Cup tennis tournament.
WARSAW, Nov. 19 -- Polish leaders indicated today that Parliament would be given legislative power to veto any changes made by the Government in the nation's five-year economic plan.

DALLAS, Nov. 19 -- After a recent meeting of the quarterbacks to examine the game plan, Roger Staubach, in the tradition of naval officers, strolled down the hall of the Dallas Cowboy offices to the coffee room. Moments later, when Craig Morton arrived there, Staubach departed without a word or a glance. On the sideline during a game, the same situation prevails. They co-exist as rivals more than they confer as teammates.

Under a carefully planned ride by Braulio Baeza in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, Stanley Joselson's Accohick registered a popular triumph. In the stretch of the six-furlong sprint, Accohick overtook Sigmund Sommer's Pete Rose just in time to score by a head.

A suspended patrolman testified yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx that a fellow policeman had taken possession of a brown paper bag containing about $45,000 in large bills that subsequently disappeared.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- For the first time in its 106-year history, the Secret Service is considering women for its chief investigative job: special agent.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 19 -- The Campbell Soup Company has been able to duplicate in over 300 recent tests the spoilage in a product that resulted in a botulin toxin and has concluded that the problem occurred when several "unusual" conditions occurred simultaneously, William B. Murphy, president, said at the annual meeting here today.

In reports on the nation's 1976 Bicentennial, The Times has noted that the national American Revolution Bicentennial Commission, preferring a multicity celebration, has been reluctant to hold and fund an international exposition in any city. The shambles of Philadelphia's planning for a major exposition, however, is chiefly -- and significantly -- due to local community opposition to a succession of sites.
Vincent M. Canty, the Acting Fire Commissioner, warned yesterday of possible difficulties in maintaining full fire protection if the number of firemen on medical leave continued to grow.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Nov. 19 -- Rick Barry scored 51 points, his high for the season, to lead the Nets to a 129-127 victory over the Carolina Cougars before 6,089 in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

Organized labor no longer seeks to disguise its basis for participation in President Nixon's anti-inflation program. The resolution adopted by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention and the keynote speech by George Meany make it plain that the aim of the labor members on the tripartite Pay Board is to defeat the goal of wage stabilization.

" Joiner," James Whitehead's first, has all the characteristics of what many will consider the typical Southern novel: red-necks, silent men of goodwill, blacks, cowed and militant, a well-meaning but careful sheriff, an indifferent population on the side. The setting is a mill town, 50 miles from Jackson, Miss., with its easy access to easy women.

At least two high-ranking officials in the Nixon Administration and other politicians in Washington, Albany and New York are among the people the Manhattan District Attorney's office intends to question about the possibility that they were blackmailed because of their associations with an East Side brothel.
Henry A. Kissinger a fashion trend-setter?

Directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share, thus halving the payout of the three previous quarters. The reduced payment will be made on Dec. 20 to holders of record Nov. 29.

Conflicting testimony was presented yesterday about alleged business ties between a former head of the Municipal Loan Program and two developers for whom he approved loans while he was in office. The testimony was later referred to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan by Edward I. Sadowsky, chairman of the Council committee that is investigating the program.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 19 -- In a country full of contradictions, one of the most surprising institutions is the University of Rhodesia. It is an outpost of multiracialism in a world of white supremacy: This year there are 526 white students, 395 Africans and 66 of Asian or mixed ancestry.

Although he has donned a uniform and moved into military offices, President Anwar Sadat prudently refrained from belligerent rhetoric in his address some days ago at the opening session of his country's new People's Assembly. The Egyptian leader clearly is not eager to commit himself to the suicidal military action which he has repeatedly threatened for his self-proclaimed 1971 "Year of Decision" if no progress is achieved on the diplomatic front.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 19 -- The leaders of organized labor are President Nixon's most outspoken critics but they beiieve that he will be extremely difficult to beat in next fall's election. In fact, if the economy picks up as the President predicts, many labor leaders here see little chance of defeating him.

Following are excerpts from the transcript of President Nixon's speech yesterday at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. biennial convention, Bal Harbour, Fla., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

The RCA Corporation reached agreement yesterday to dispose of at least part of its computer operations. Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and chief executive officer, and J. Frank Forster, chairman of the Sperry Rand Corporation, announced late yesterday afternoon that Sperry Rand's Univac division would "assume responsibility for RCA's existing general-purpose computer customers in the United States, Canada and Mexico.
HOUSTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Ken Rosewall defeated fellow Australian John Newcombe, 7-5, 6-2, 5-7, 6-3, tonight in the quarter finals of the $100,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

Burgess Industries, Inc., announced yesterday in Dallas that Donald L. Rogers was elected president at a special shareholder meeting. He succeeds D. W. Maclay, who remains as chairman. The two men will share the responsibility of chief executive officer, formerly held by Mr. Maclay.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market turned in their third consecutive loss yesterday as both lists declined in lighter trading.

There are about 180 school days in the school year. On every one of these days, more than one million children ride or walk to about 1,000 New York City schools. Not so long ago, these schools were safe places to learn and grow and have fun in. They aren't safe any more.

OTTAWA, Nov. 19 -- The Canadian National Energy board announced tonight its decision that Canada's growing energy needs required that no additional supplies of natural gas be made available for export "at the present time."
Short-selling activity on the New York Stock Exchange increased in the month ended Nov. 15, the exchange reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- China accused India today of interfering in Pakistan's affairs and of obstructing efforts to restore peace on the subcontinent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee concluded three days of hearings on President Nixon's nominee for Secretary of Agriculture today and scheduled an executive session on Monday to consider further action.

Philip Cho, the young Korean tenor who gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night, showed a sensitive regard for the infinite subtleties of sadness, especially in Faure's sweetly mournful "Poeme d'un jour." Mr. Cho found a persuasive tone for this romantic little triptych, avoiding the darkly tragic accent that could have destroyed the music's gentle charm.

ATHENS, Nov. 19 -- The former investigating magistrate whose 1963 inquiry into the murder of Gregory Lambrakis, a leftist Deputy, was portrayed in the film "Z," was freed tonight after spending 11 months in jail on charges of plotting to overthrow the military-backed Government.
A Federal judge in Philadelphia yesterday blocked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's take-over of the Penn Central's Harlem and Hudson commuter divisions.
Commissioner of Correction George F. McGrath, whose department has been under increasing criticism, resigned yesterday but said that suggestions he had been dismissed were "totally false."

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 19 -- Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn said today that his seizure of power in a coup had been made necessary by increasing resistance to Government economic policies by Parliament, by growing confusion
The Phelps Dodge Corporation took the lead late yesterday afternoon and announced that it was cutting the price of whole plate copper cathode by 2.50 cents to 49.75 cents a pound, effective today.
The annual turning of the tables on the captains of industry, business and government was enacted here last night in the Financial Follies of 1971.
YONKERS, Nov. 19 -- Long-distance harness racing on an experimental basis will be offered to the public three nights each week for the balance of the Yonkers Raceway meeting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- State Department officials said today that Secretary of State William P. Rogers had discussed the recent Soviet deliveries to Egypt of aircraft and air-to-surface missiles with Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambassador here.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 19 -President Nixon's chief environmental adviser said today that the action in Birmingham yesterday in which 23 companies were ordered to halt production to cut air pollution is only the beginning of greater Federal involvement in the battle to control contamination.

A show-cause order was obtained yesterday by Monticello Raceway calling on the State Harness Racing Commission to tell why it has jurisdiction over any planned televising of races from that track to the metropolitan area.

John Mandel, who is having his first one-man show at the Max Hutchinson Gallery, 127 Greene Street, is a very good painter right now and might become an important one as well if the return to figure painting is really on the way to becoming the effective counterrevolution that it promises to be.
Stock prices wobbled downward yesterday to finish only an eyelash above their poorest closing level of 1971.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- Judge Otto H. LaMarchia, in Superior Court here, brought the two-year-old Panther murder case to an end today when he imposed suspended sentences on the last two defendants, Rory B. Hithe and Landon R. Williams.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Representative John A. Blatnik, chairman of the House Public Works Committee, announced today that he would reopen hearings on a water pollution control bill.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- The director of a Government foreign aid agency thought to be a front for intelligence work said today that he believed that narcotics traffic had been organized by French secret service agents.

The New York Civil Liberties Union, acting on behalf of a reporters' association here, is joining the legal fight to force State Supreme Court Justice George Postel to reopen the trial of Carmine J. Persico to the public -- even though the union agrees with Justice Postel that press reports mentioning such items as Persico's prior record are unjustified.
The National-Standard Company reported yesterday that its profits in the year ended Sept. 30 dropped to $4,458,000, or $1.74 a share, from $7,486,or $1.03 a share, from $7,486,preceding year.

The Columbia Broadcasting System was accused yesterday of consistently misrepresenting the number of minority-group performers it employs on day-time serials and of misleadingly by listing minority movie extras and beauty contestants as its own performers.

BUFFALO -- Once again attention is focused on the propriety of potential Supreme Court justices. The entire question of courtroom behavior is under review by the bench and bar. Courtroom disruption began to slip from public memory as the Black Panther conspiracy trials settled into memory.
TOKYO, Nov. 19 -- Six days of protests by radical youths reached a peak today with rioting that led to one death, extensive destruction and 1,785 arrests.

State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist issued a temporary stay yesterday enjoining central school authorities here from taking action against Community School Board 3 in Manhattan for defying citywide regulations on the dismissal of personnel.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 -- Americans increasingly initiate telephone calls to listen rather than talk.

In Lewis F. Powell's article reprinted on your Op-Ed page of Nov. 3, he concludes his discussion of the rights of defendants in criminal cases by stating: "Rather than 'repressive criminal justice,' our system subordinates the safety of society to the rights of persons accused of crime.

CAMDEN, S. C., Nov. 19 -- In a town where only the laundromat stays open past 10 P.M., relaxation continued to mount here today as racing's beleaguered steeplechase set prepared for tomorrow's second running of the $100,000 Colonial Cup.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 19 -- President Salvador Allende Gossens today ordered criminal prosecution of the rector of the University of Chile and of a group of opposition legislators who oppose Marxist control of the university.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -The Pay Board approved a wage increase of at least 15 per cent for the nation's coal miners today despite a stern warning from its public members that such raises would endanger economic stabilization efforts.

A large number of companies took advantage of a relatively strong new-issue market this week to make first public offerings of their stock. Investors, however, proved very selective and by week's end only four of the 16 issues were displaying premiums above the initial price.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -Rich Schultz, a Swarthmore junior, and John Heil, a Lehigh senior prevailed by slim margins today in winning the college and university titles with record clockings in the 16th annual Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Athletic Conference cross-country championships.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Financial officials of 23 developed nations arrived at a consensus today that if the monetary crisis is not resolved within a reasonably short time, the world business climate would deteriorate into a generalized recession.

Rogers Groups, that popular form of mass-produced late 19th-century American sculpture, are looking their best in the current survey of the sculpture in the collection of the New-York Historical Society.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday that consumer prices in the metropolitan area rose moderately in October, the second full month of the wage-price freeze. But most of the rise was attributed to "technical" increases.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 19 -A changing weather pattern ended the week-long pollution threat to this industrial center today, and a Federal court lifted its order cutting production at local steel and cement mills.

Willie Williams balled up a piece of used tape and tossed it toward the trash box in the New York Giants locker room yesterday. Bennie McRae, sitting with his head down less than three feet away, reached up and instinctively intercepted the object.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Nov. 19 -- The Long Island Jewish Medical Center said today that it expected to continue its affiliation with the Department of Pediatrics at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn when it took over the staffing of the New Children's Medical Center of New York on its grounds here.

A new license plate exclusively for taxicabs will be issued by the state for 1972. Created at the behest of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, the new "T" designation plate will replace the present "O" license plate, which will go out of existence.

NONGOMA, South Africa, Nov. 6 -- This town of cattle breeders in the hills of northern Natal Province has a king-sized logistical problem because more than 50,000 tribesmen are expected to converge on it next month for the coronation of the new Zulu King.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 19 -- The Paraguayan high court ruled here today that a French-born former Gestapo agent could be extradited to face charges of being the kingpin in a large heroin smuggling operation in New York.

While embittered residents of Forest Hills, Queens, insisted yesterday they would block construction of a low-income housing project in their middle-class area, Mayor Lindsay denounced the community's torch-burning and rock-throwing at the site on Thursday night.

Trading in platinum futures accelerated here yesterday as prices rose by $2 to $4.50 an ounce. The biggest gains were trimmed by as much as $1 in later profit taking. Sales totaled 528 lots, including 400 switches to other contracts in the same commodity.

The Times' recent field coverage from South Vietnam has persistently omitted reference to the highly successful land reform program, even though you editorially referred to it upon passage in 1970 as "probably the most imaginative and progressive non-Communist land reform of the twentieth century" (April 9, 1970).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- "If ever there was a community that had the potential for understanding the needs of minority groups and deprived persons, the folks in Forest Hills have that potential," Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal said today.

CAMDEN, Ala., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Some 300 predominantly black demonstrators, seeking more school integration and better jobs were arrested today for marching without a permit, Wilcox County Sheriff F. R. Albritton said.
An electronic county fair camped for 12 hours yesterday in the 69th Regiment Armory, and television upstaged the other arts in the Eighth Annual New York Avant Garde Festival.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had censured Walston Co., a major brokerage house, and had fined it $75,000 for violations of exchange rules in connection with dealing in the stock of one of the concern's investment-banking clients.

Four undefeated teams do not play today, but the bowl bids expected to be extended to them at 6 P.M. will undoubtedly arouse more interest than the results of the many games on the schedule as the curtain comes down on the 102d college football season.

For the first time since they exchanged Dave Stallworth, Mike Riordan and an undisclosed amount of cash for Earl Monroe, nine days ago, the Knicks will meet the Baltimore Bullets, Monroe's former teammates, tonight at Madison Square Garden.

The controversial housing project proposed for 108th Street and 62d Drive in Queens had its philosophical origins late in the administration of Mayor Robert F. Wagner and its official origins early in the administration of Mayor Lindsay.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- New orders for durable goods stayed essentially flat in October at a level well below last summer's peak, the Commerce Department reported today.
Every Saturday afternoon at 2:30 -- despite measles, family vacations, birthday parties or scout meetings -the show goes on.

The new paintings that Helen Frankenthaler is showing at Andre Emmerich's two very spacious exhibition galleries -- uptown at 41 East 57th Street, downtown at 420 West Broadway -- are something of a problem for the artist's admirers, of whom the writer is one.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -The Consumer Price Index rose slightly in October despite the wage-price freeze, but the chief cause was normal and allowable seasonal increases for new cars and clothing, the Labor Department reported today.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Nov. 19 -- Gov. William G. Milliken of Michigan, the new chairman of the Republican Governors Association, urged his party today not to "isolate ourselves from the poor, the young and the black."

The First National City Bank, the largest bank in New York, said yesterday that its minimum, or "base," lending rate for business loans would be 5 3/8 per cent for the week beginning Monday, down from 5 1/2 per cent this week.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- The U.S. called today for an international study to determine to what extent the post-World War II trading system had been eroded by departures from the rules on which it was founded.

With an unbeaten string of 14 games, including victories in their last six, the Rangers will resume National Hockey League competition tonight at Bloomington, Minn., against the surprising Minnesota North Stars.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 19 (Agence France-Presse) -Foreign Secretary Sir Alec Douglas-Home of Britain and his full team of negotiators met in the morning and afternoon with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia and his negotiators in the attempt to settle the Rhodesian independence dispute.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to delay the trial of 25 persons on charges growing out of the Kent State University disorders of May 4, 1970.
MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- The Soviet Union, apparently concerned over the latest developments in China, said today that there was evidence of a grave crisis in the Peking leadership.

Commissioner of Investigation Robert K. Ruskin announced yesterday that he had begun an investigation to determine whether a crime had been committed when Sanitation Department policemen were asked by a deputy commissioner to sell tickets to a fund-raising dinner for Mayor Lindsay.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -No radiation has been detected entering the environment of Amchitka Island as a result of the Cannikin nuclear test of Nov. 6, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.
The air-fare compromise reached in Honolulu yesterday means that travelers will almost certainly be paying less next year, but will not be getting the bargains that have been advertised.

The two-day work stoppage last June that caused massive, chaotic traffic jams when city employes opened drawbridges and abandoned trucks on major highways was ruled yesterday a strike in violation of the state's Taylor Law.

OLD FORGE, N. Y. -- At the conference on the Adirondacks at St. Lawrence University, it was agreed that under the present policy of "forever wild," lack of management of the northern hardwood on state lands in the Adirondack Park was resulting in practically pure stands of beech and hemlock.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- "It's very tiring. You feel the tension and the fatigue," Chia-ching Fan murmured as he lit another cigarette.
While the status of Joe Namath remained questionable yesterday, there was no doubt in the mind of J. D. Hill, Buffalo's wide receiver, about his plans for tomorrow.
AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 19 -- The State Inland Fisheries and Game commissioner, Maynard F. Marsh, ordered an early closing today to the deer hunting season to protect the dwindling herd.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Manufacturers of automobile, trucks and aircraft tires are inspecting them for imperfections with X-ray equipment on which patents were issued this week to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh.

Portraying professional football as a sport that would be corrupted by legalized gambling, Pete Rozell, National Football League Commissioner, opposed yesterday legislation to permit this, at the second and last day of hearings by the State Commission on Gambling at 270 Broadway.

Birgit Nilsson, undisputed queen of Wagnerian singers in her generation, enjoys scaling vocal heights, but no other kind. So, the Swedish soprano was upset when she found recently that the Metropolitan Opera's mechanically spectacular new production of "Tristan and Isolde" called for her to be hoisted high above the stage on a hidden elevator.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Government officials said today that high Cambodian officers had flown to Saigon to ask for South Vietnamese engineers and artillery to help relieve enemy pressure on a Cambodian task force cut off northeast of Pnompenh.

MILWAUKEE -- The more I watch the plays of Georges Feydeau the more I admire them. He is dramatic comic technique raised to the level of the transcendental. His plays are machines for acting in -- and such perfect, beautiful, happy machines that we can only wonder and admire.
BONN, Nov. 19 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt's Social Democratic party stepped to the left yesterday and today at a special convention here aimed at deciding upon a platform for the coming decade.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 -- Joe Fargis of the United States Equestrian Team rode San Lucas to victory in the international jumping competition at the Royal Winter Fair horse show tonight, but the Canadian Equestrian Team held onto a slim lead for the championship.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 19 -- Gov. Preston E. Smith, who had been expected to step aside after two terms, surprised Texas Democratic politicians today by announcing his candidacy for a third two-year term.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 19 -- President Nixon appealed to organized labor here today to cooperate with his Phase Two economic controls, but declared that he would proceed with his program "whether we get that participation or not."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church approved today a resolution calling for an end to the Indochina war "with no further delay."

HONG KONG, Nov. 19 -- What appears to be the fall of Defense Minister Lin Piao, for years the closest collaborator and chosen successor of Chairman Mao Tse-tung, has already seriously upset the power structure in China and seems likely to cause still wider disruptions.

Daniel, a "very large" black great Dane, and his owner, Mrs. Muriel S. Mayhew, a slender widow in her late 50's, won the right in State Supreme Court yesterday to remain in their Greenwich Village basement apartment.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 19 -- Scientists reported today that Mariner 9 had returned data showing Mars has a huge bulge at its equator and wide irregularities in its gravitational field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Donald L. Miller, a Brooklyn shipbuilding executive and former Army major, was named today as Assistant Secretary of Defense for Equal Opportunity and charged with the responsibility of trying to end racial strife in the armed forces.

Everybody for some time now has been wondering when the Metropolitan Opera was going to make full use of its stage facilities, facilities that, we were assured when the house opened, were the most modern of any major opera house in the world.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 19 -- The President of the United States did not really walk into a lion's den when he entered the Americana Hotel here this morning to address a convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Henry A. Kissinger, the President's national security adviser, may not think of everything his employer needs, but he seems to try hard. Mrs. Richard M. Nixon disclosed that Mr. Kissinger, returning from a trip to China, where he made preparations for the President's visit, brought her a recipe for chicken and walnuts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Following are the texts of the Pay Board's decision approving the first-year provisions of the coal contract, of a supporting statement by business members of the board, and of a dissenting opinion by the public representatives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Congressional Black Caucus's conference for black elected officials, aimed at uniting Negro Americans "around the issues that affect our people," opened on a note of discord this morning when Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn complained that she was not being allowed to lead political workshops.
RENO, Nev., Nov. 20 -- The University of Nevada board of regents voted today to retain Dr. N. Edd Miller as president of the Reno campus.
Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery warned yesterday that the "abnormally high number" of injuries that fire fighters were continuing to report on their return from fires posed great risk to the city.

Miriam Beerman of Brooklyn was a portrait painter until she found out that her sitters were becoming unbearably bestial in expression. She then looked for more humanity in beasts and found it, she says. She calls her current exhibition of "The Enduring Beast" at the Brooklyn Museum the most human and the most gentle of all her paintings.

" Beyond Freedom and Dignity" has evoked an angry response from Richard Sennett on the front page of your Oct. 24 issue. My only hope is that my book will be better understood by those who read it dispassionately.

Its back cover on which a lumpy stylized folk figure spits out curlicues and Spanish words is a fair introduction to this volume. The prose is as corkscrewed and striated as the pictures, and gracelessness of approach is matched by that of style.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 20 -- At his office desk overlooking the surf sliding up the sand, Don Quixote was wearing an orchid shirt with a black, pink and orchid striped tie.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 20 -- Adelphi University, dropping football at the end of this season, lost its last varsity football game today to bowl-bound Bridgeport University, 35-0.

Sweetbreads Florentine, despite the name, is not an Italian recipe. "Florentine," as a culinary expression, has nothing to do with the city of Michelangelo's David and the Ponte Vecchio. Young and articulate Mr. Rehnquist has had his victories over the controlling liberal group in the Senate, and these men do not forget defeat easily.

To thaw a frozen turkey, place the bird on a tray in the refrigerator in the original wrap, which has been punctured, for two to four days or about 24 hours for each five pounds of turkey.

TOKYO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Mark Spitz of Santa Clara, Calif., won his third event, the men's 200-meter free-style, today, but Japan ended up winning 12 of the 22 events in the two-day Tokyo international swimming meet.

WASHINGTON -- The Sinai peninsula occupies a critical position in the making of peace -- and war -- in the Middle East. A solution for Sinai would provide the essence of a settlement between Egypt and Israel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- So Dallas, which replaced Washington in the American League late in the baseball season, now has taken this beleaguered city's spot at the head of the National Football Conference's Eastern Division. Except for five heavenly Sundays when the Redskins won 'em all, this has been an autumn to try the souls of the most sanguine of the capital's sports fans, even including that incurable buff who lives at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Monday, Nov. 22 -- A big South Vietnamese military column, spearheaded by armored cars and including several thousand troops, has rolled over the border into southeast Cambodia, military sources said today.

BUFFALO, Nov. 21 -- When Bob Davis, running out of bounds to escape a Buffalo tackler, skidded in a mud puddle and got his foot stuck under a wooden fence, it appeared that the bad things that always seem to happen to the Jets in Buffalo were happening again.

LUGANO -- This lakeside resort has been transformed into one of the principal financial centers of Europe rivaling Zurich and Geneva, as a result of the almost irresistible appeal of the dependable Swiss franc.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks received first-period goals from Stan Mikita, Bobby Hull, Pit Martin and Andre LaCroix, then cruised to a 7-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight.

It is an old chess aphorism that, when a master gives an exhibition of simultaneous play, the hardest thing about it for him is the walking from board to board. There is some truth in this. The master may walk five miles in the course of an evening -- quite a distance for a man who probably leads a sedentary life.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21 -- The Palestinian resistance movement is shifting its strategy from regular army operations to urban-guerrilla action inside Israeli-held territory, according to a leading Palestinian theoretician here.
HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 21 -- Dartmouth College, a 202-year-old school that has awarded undergraduate degrees only to men, decided today to institute coeducation and year-round operation by next fall.

WARSAW, Nov. 21 -- Last month, Poland signed a $400-million contract with Fiat, the Italian company, to produce a popular-priced small car. The decision to sign the pact resolved a longstanding source of Polish consumer frustration.

PUNTA ARENAS, Chile Nov. 21 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba came to this southernmost city in the world today and was given one of the most enthusiastic receptions so far on his state visit to Chile.
Unionized lay teachers, who bargain for more than half of the instructional staff at the 329 schools of the Archdiocese of New York, voted yesterday to strike this morning.

Proposals to narrow the differences in petroleum industry accounting practices have stirred up sharp opposition, particularly among small and medium-sized companies who charge that the changes would reduce earnings, retard their ability to raise capital and cause a reduction in exploration for oil and gas.

The United States Commission on Civil Rights has hit on the useful device of rating the performance of a wide variety of Government agencies in the battle against discrimination and social injustice. Unfortunately, the initial report card is far from encouraging. Few of the agencies have risen above a failing mark.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A potentially serious clash is shaping up in the International Monetary Fund between the United States, on one hand, and the other members, together with the Fund's staff, on the other.

The New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. yesterday urged the State Insurance Department to mandate increased medical and hospital benefits in its proposed new regulations for accident and health policies.

Sending the Golden Seals goalie to the bench in tears, the Rangers last night scored the most decisive victory in their 46 years, a 12-1 pasting in which they broke one National Hockey League record and tied another.

The New School for Social Research has won community board approval to build a combination city affairs institute, public library and neighborhood meeting rooms on the site of the abandoned Women's House of Detention in Greenwich Village.

HONG KONG, Nov. 21 -- China's nuclear arsenal was brought up for special mention by Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam in a speech in Peking yesterday.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Nov. 21 -- "We have good water, good people, pretty girls," said Rolf Johannessen, "but bad geography."

Tom Fleming, a junior from Paterson State College, posted the second fastest time of the annual Nine-Mile Cross-Country Memorial Run yesterday, defeating 135 other runners at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

The program with which the Cosmopolitan Young Peoples Symphony Orchestra opened its season, in Philharmonic Hall on Saturday afternoon, was unusually sophisticated. It was performed so well, it really deserved to be heard by adults.

Nineteen persons were killed in three early morning fires yesterday in Michigan, California and Alaska. The authorities said the Michigan blaze was the work of an arsonist. Fifteen of the victims were children.

HOUSTON, NOV. 21 (AP) -- Australia's Rod Laver, the leading money-winner on the pro tennis tour, overcame a second-set lapse today to defeat Arthur Ashe of the United States, 6-3, 1-6, 6-3, 6-3, and earn a spot opposite Ken Rosewall in the $50,000 final of the World Championship Tennis tour.

The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board pledged over the weekend that his agency -- which regulates the $200-billion savings and loan industry -- would use its powers to prevent "excesses and abuses and extremes" in a key area of conflict of interest among savings associations.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 -- Demand for steel was still disappointing last week. With auto companies starting to place orders for January delivery, total bookings remained at depressed levels.

DES MOINES, Iowa -- The susceptibility of human nature to the mystique of conspiracy has afforded a fertile field for the assassination sensationalists. Kennedy and Dallas police officer J. D. Tippit.

CAMDEN, S. C., Nov. 21 -- When the 15 magnificent horses burst over the final barrier yesterday and surged toward the finish, the crisp, clear Carolina air was suddenly heavy with the mass mutual frenzy of the thousands who had come to watch the country's premier steeplechase, the $100,000 Colonial Cup.

ABSECON, N. J. -- Nov. 21 -- Big Business got fairly high marks this weekend, from James J. Needham, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Angry and frustrated over what they call long-standing city neglect of their neighborhood parks, some Brooklyn residents and their Assemblyman led parks officials yesterday on a depressing tour of burned-out comfort stations, shattered fountains and wading pools, torn fences, missing swings, broken benches and weedgrown asphalt play lots.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22 (AP) -- An employe of a paint brush factory in southwest Baltimore opened fire inside the plant this afternoon, killing five co-workers and wounding a sixth and a policeman before being critically wounded by the police.

A 20-month study by the Urban Design Council of New York has concluded that the architectural services rendered to the City of New York fall far short of the highest standard and recommended a radical revision of building processes.
TOKYO, Nov. 22 (AP) --Premier Eisaku Sato's governing Liberal-Democratic party and two moderate opposition parties adopted a resolution today calling for a ban on nuclear weapons on Okinawa.
Final approval of the controversial low-income housing project planned for middleclass Forest Hills, Queens, was reaffirmed last night by George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

Star Envoy once more demonstrated that he can go all the way in a turf race as he took the 1 1/16-mile grass event at Aqueduct yesterday. The 3-year-old colt owned by Lloyd Miller hooked up with Sigmund Sommer's Big Shot II in the test for older horses, and scored by two lengths.
RICHMOND, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A Federal district judge today ordered a new election of Richmond's nine-member city council to provide a better racial balance in the vote of the city's 249,621 population.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -The Supreme Court unanimously struck down today an Idaho statute that gave men preference over women in administering deceased persons' estates. It marked the first time the Court had invalidated a state law on grounds of sex discrimination.
Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, attacked yesterday proposals that bank holding companies be allowed to acquire savings-and-loan associations.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 22 -- Two young New York experts led the field of 60 pairs into the final session of the life master men's pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nations here tonight.
ARLINGTON, Va., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Thousands of people climbed a grassy, windswept hillside today to pay tribute to John Fitzgerald Kennedy on the eighth anniversary of his assassination.
TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 23 -- Military sources reported yesterday that at least 5,000 troops are involved in new South Vietnamese drive into eastern Cambodia.

C. W. Post and Delaware, the two most explosive small college football teams in the nation, accepted bids yesterday to meet in the fourth annual Boardwalk Bowl game at Atlantic City's Convention Hall, Dec. 11.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A revolutionary new political plan under which the full cost of Presidential campaigns could be financed from Federal funds instead of private contributions was approved tonight by the Senate.

In a recent column Tom Wicker deplored passage of legislation prohibiting use of Federal funds for busing programs. He charged the House members variously with demagoguery, abandonment of leadership and failure to act as they should.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 22 -The Opposition Christian Democratic party today denounced the Government's proposed constitutional reform that would creates one-chamber legislature to replace the Senate and Chamber of Deputies.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 22 -- The Westchester County Board of Legislators voted today to sell 25 acres of county-owned land on the future campus of New York Medical College to the New York State Urban Development Corporation for the construction of 375 apartments.
