Wall Street's annual yearend round of top-level executive changes began yesterday with announcements from Loeb, Rhoades Co., Eastman Dillion, Union Securities Co. and E. F. Hutton Co.

FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 22 -- A retired officer who had been censured by the Army for his role in the Mylai 4 incident said today that he had no knowledge of atrocities carried out by American troops when he ordered Col. Oran K. Henderson to investigate the attack.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- A recent United Nations report that said juvenile delinquency was increasing in both developed and underdeveloped countries led today to a unanimously adopted resolution committing the General Assembly to deal with the "serious problems" facing much of the world's youth.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 22 -- The British-Rhodesian talks hung in the balance tonight as Ian D. Smith, Prime Minister in the white minority Government, met with his Cabinet.

Itoh Co., a Japanese trading concern that is also the world's largest textile company, are currently exploring mutual activities that may lead to the establishment of a new, jointly owned textile company in the United States.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Responding to fierce political charges of economic bungling, the British Government announced today an accelerated program of public spending to alleviate high unemployment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A Chicago lawyer who was one of the main authors of the new Illinois income tax law will be named soon as Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Policy -- a key policy-making post.

Just before the start of yesterday's featured race at Aqueduct, Bobby Ussery's weight was announced at 115 pounds. It was the lightest the seasoned jockey had been since riding at 114 pounds in Florida last winter.
BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Judges Edward J. DeSaulnier and Vincent R. Brogna of Superior Court denied under oath today that they had been bribed to keep a convicted swindler out of jail.

CAIRO, Nov. 23 -- The Egyptian Government's chief spokesman, Tahsin Bashir, said tonight "peace could be saved in the Middle East" if Israel gave evidence of intention to implement the United Nations Security Council resolution of Nov. 22, 1967, which called, among other things, for Israel to withdraw from occupied Arab territories.

An audio cassette collection designed to provide a better understanding of the theater, narrated by Walter Kerr, Sunday drama critic of The New York Times, is now available from the Library Services Division of The New York Times Company.

The Catholic lay teachers' union and the Archdiocese of New York made conflicting statements yesterday on the success of the teachers' strike as a state mediator initiated discussions in an attempt to resume bargaining.

By any standard, Eugene Istomin's piano recital at Carnegie Hall Monday night rated respect. Mr. Istomin, though rarely as interesting a soloist as he can be in ensemble roles, played with utter honesty and more refinement than one customarily finds in piano recitals.

LONDON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Assailing what he termed artificial trade barriers, a special envoy of President Nixon said tonight that they were erected by the European Common Market and other economic groups for selfish ends. He called for cooperation in building a new world commerce system.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 23 -- They make barbed wire and wash G.I. fatigues. They raise fighting cocks and sit on tiger-skin rugs. They own banks and hold high Government office. They are South Vietnam's most powerful and persuasive minority -- its two dozen or so millionaires.
The New York Yankees announced yesterday that they would open their 81-game home schedule next April 6 against the Baltimore Orioles, three-time champions of the American League.

A Federal mediator said yesterday that negotiations between shippers and longshoremen to end the 54-day North Atlantic dock strike had recessed indefinitely without agreement and that Taft-Hartley action by President Nixon was "a real possibility."

Tomorrow night at 10, near the close of another Thanksgiving Day, the Columbia Broadcasting System's news department will offer a portrait of one American family with, seemingly, every reason in the world to give thanks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A member of the Federal Reserve Board said today that achievement of a goal of which more rapid growth in the economy next year, as widely predicted, would not create "any basic problem for monetary policy or the money supply."

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- A New York rabbi who flew here for the funeral of the Chief Rabbi of Moscow expressed confidence today that the vacant post would be filled soon despite a shortage of trained rabbis in the Soviet Union.

TORRANCE, Calif., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Toyota, the Japanese automobile manufacturer, announced today the second increase in two months in the suggested retail prices of its passenger cars sold in the United States.

John E. O'Toole, president of Foote, Cone Belding, reports that he hasn't received a single negative letter as a result of his recent talk in which he called on the nation's TV industry to put a five-minute minimum on paid political campaign messages.

Displaying an ego and flippancy missing from boxing since Muhammad Ali was known as Cassius Clay, Terry Daniels yesterday predicted his "balance of speed, power and style" would help him upset Joe Frazier and take away the world heavyweight championship.
BAGDA, India, Nov. 23 -- Large numbers of Indian troops pushed toward the nearby East Pakistani border today and, according to their officers, crossed into East Pakistan.
The Board of Higher Education has approved the proposal to create a Center for the Performing Arts at City College.
Almost two-thirds of the city's 132 leased day-care centers are owned by a small group of landlords -- with one owner listed for 29 of them -- Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

The New York Knicks, apparently struggling only a couple of weeks ago, rolled over the Cincinnati Royals 125-110, at Madison Square Garden last night for their fourth straight victory.
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 23 -- "They shouldn't have let the old guys vote," shouted the husky blond worker in the hallway of his union headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A $1.5-billion fund to combat drug abuse on the state and city level and for such special projects as fighting addiction in industry was added today to a bill to create a White House action office against drug abuse.
Wall Street is going into the life insurance business.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- A proposal to build a supermarket directly across the street from the home of the late Franklin D. Roosevelt is stirring considerable controversy here where anything connected with the late President has been controversial for decades.

RAVENNA, Ohio, Nov. 23 -- The jury selected for the trial of the first of 25 persons indicted in the 1970 Kent State University disorders toured the campus at Kent today under a heavy escort of sheriff's deputies.

Mrs. John V. Lindsay announced yesterday a campaign by city agencies to amass holiday gifts from municipal employes for distribution in orphanages, municipal hospitals and nursing homes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Nixon announced today the appointment of 14 persons to be members of the Rent Advisory Board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Several years ago, a brand new member of the staff of the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation sat listening to testimony at a Congressional hearing. The new staff man agreed with what the witness was saying and, unconsciously, began nodding his head in affirma tion.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans met today for three hours with the Soviet Minister of Foreign Trade and then said that he was beginning to realize "the problems involved in trade between two countries with different political systems."

The corporate bond market perked up yesterday as investors enthusiastically purchased a new issue of double-A utility bonds priced to yield 7.54 per cent, the same return they shunned on Monday for a comparable new offering.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 23 -- The so-called revolution in Thailand is a week old now, and as its military leaders explain their disenchantment with democracy, they are also saying something about the inadequacy of American policies and inspirations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A Senate panel was told today that corporate secrecy was help ing big business gain increasing control of farming.

Acceding to community requests, the City Planning Commission yesterday approved an increase in the number of apartments for low-income and moderate-income families scheduled for the Ruppert Brewery urban renewal project.
Stock prices kept retreating yesterday along a wide front, although a rally led by glamour issues reduced some losses in the final hour of trading.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 23 -- The country and western music stations cry "Today's Teardrops are Tomorrow's Rainbows." Jack Mildren says, no sweat, Oklahoma's rainbow will be a victory over Nebraska here Thursday in their battle of unbeaten college football powers.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Every great political and economic event can be regarded in two ways -- as a unique turning-point or as the repetition of an historical pattern. PEKING, Nov. 23 (Reuters) -Mao Tse-tung made another public appearance last night, receiving Pham Van Dong, the Premier of North Vietnam, and other visiting North Vietnamese officials.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Senate voted overwhelmingly today in favor of providing $500-million in military credits for Israel, earmarking half the sum to cover the purchase of F-4 Phantom jet fighters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A bill to permit the Secretary of the Interior to increase the fee for the migratory bird hunting stamp from $3 to $5 was supported at a Senate hearing today.

Thanksgiving is one of the few national holidays that still have a genuine air about them. It is also the oldest American festival. Not counting the Virginia declaration of 1619 (see Op-Ed), this is the 350th anniversary of the traditional feast day that began at Plymouth in 1621, attended by a handful of exhausted Pilgrims who had survived a year in the wilderness and by some ninety Wampanoag Indians who had helped them survive.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 -If Fred Stuvek of Navy and J. Kingsley Fink of Army are the starting quarterbacks, as expected, in the 72d annual Army-Navy game Saturday, it will be the first time since the 1940 game that both academies opened with sophomore quarterbacks.

HARBORSIDE, Me. -- Barrels of flour and sugar in the pantry were ordinary staples for New England country dwellers a hundred or more years ago. Molasses was kept by the pailful, dried beans and peas by the peck. Soda crackers, oyster crackers and ginger snaps were stocked in ordinary households by the barrel.
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 24 -- Pakistan announced today that she was calling up her military reserves and said that heavy fighting with Indian forces was continuing in the eastern region.

Thanksgiving Day sprang from our own beginnings at a time when those first settlers were grateful to be alive and have enough to eat. They asked little of life, but much of themselves. They were thankful for the strength to put down the roots of settlement, to build the beginnings of security. They had dreams, but they knew dreams are hopes for tomorrow and without today there would be no tomorrow.

YONKERS, Nov. 24 -- Most of the horsemen and railbirds were surprised to see Strike Out, a promising pacing son of Bret Hanover and Golden Miss, working in the cold at Yonkers Raceway this morning. With John Hayes Sr. in the sulky the colt paced three separate one-mile trips, the fastest in 2:07 4/5.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -President Nixon will confer with President Pompidou of France in the Azores next month regarding Mr. Nixon's forthcoming trips to China and the Soviet Union, the White House announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -Officials of the Pay Board worked today to explain the agency's explanation of its ruling on whether the 5.5 per cent general guideline would apply to merit wage increases.

Phase Two of President Nixon's new economic program has not yet offered the ingredients essential to a good environment for the equity market, Henry Kaufman, partner and economist of Salomon Brothers, said yesterday.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 24 -Bob Devaney disclosed Nebraska's plans for defensing the celebrated "Wishbone" offense of Oklahoma tomorrow afternoon in their showdown game for college football's No. 1 spot.
The new champion of West Germany is Grandmaster Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A judge dismissed drug - possession charges against a teen-age girl in the second day of a trial before a jury of fellow high school students.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market posted their first advances in six sessions yesterday as both lists made small gains in slow trading.
